original: Kawaguchi's troops consolidated their lines on the high ground west of Kokumbona and a few miles inland. Here they tried to rebuild their strength, which was now about 1,800 men. They sent patrols to harass the Marines at Guadalcanal, but were limited to light weapons, as most heavy weapons had been abandoned during the retreat.

original:
The valley floor of the caldera contains rhyolite lava flows and a welded tuff ring with some cones associated with it. Surrounding the rhyolite tuff deposits are other volcanic flows, including basaltic lava flows and clastic deposits. Three of the ash flow units contain Manganese, Anethite and Montrosite minerals. Large basalt deposits near the center of the caldera in Idaho were last known to have erupted 8.5 million years ago. These deposits show evidence of explosive volcanism and are part of a rare basalt type called Shoshonite basalt, which forms when the crust is stretched by a mantle plume.

original: The Jockey Club supported Albert B. Chandler, a staunch supporter of parimutuel betting. In his race for the Democratic nomination, Chandler was helped by ex-governor Edwin P. Morrow. Beckham had no political help in the race, which he lost by a substantial margin. Beckham continued his legal career after leaving office. From 1930 until 1935, he was chairman of the State Tax Commission. In 1937, he was named to the Board of Directors of American Bank Note Company.

original: She used the city's resources to pay for legal fees to stop the planned renovation and successfully sued. Barry lost her re-election bid in November 2013, to the Meridian Historic and Preservation Society and other interested parties, including The Riley Foundation. This organization developed the Meridian Initiative, a project to study the redevelopment of the Threefoot Building and surrounding areas. At the time of the project, Barry had been cited and fined for littering the sidewalk in front of her business, and the Riley Foundation suggested that she was hostile to redevelopment efforts. On June 18, 2013, Barry's announcement of the Meridian Initiative release prompted protests by some residents. She was accused of racism, and asked to resign. Following the 2012 United States presidential election, the historic First Presbyterian Church was broken into and vandalized on November 10. This attack was widely blamed on protests regarding the victory of Mitt Romney, a member of the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints, in the presidential election. As of the 2010 United States Census, the city's population was 41,148. The city is the 11th largest city in the state of Mississippi. The population of the Micropolitan Statistical Area (MSA), which includes all of Lauderdale County, has increased to 108,134, up from 104,310 in 2000. However, the city of Meridian's population decreased slightly from 39,968 in 2000 to 39,968 in 2010. In 2012, Forbes magazine listed Meridian as the seventh fastest-growing small city in the United States. Meridian is an eclectic city. It is often seen as a place of contrasts. As a result, Meridian has been described as the "Friendly City", or the "Second City" (a phrase coined in the 19th century) in order to explain its peculiarities and uniqueness. The city is home to several educational institutions. The city is served by three public school districts, which operate 13 elementary schools, four middle schools, and three high schools. On December 10, 2012, Meridian Public Schools became the first district in the state to offer dual-language education classes. The city has one private school, Oak Forest Christian School, a K3–12th-grade private school located off Highway 39 in rural Lauderdale County. Mississippi State University operates Meridian's two-year community college, Meridian Community College. Meridian is home to two campuses of Mississippi University for Women, and a branch of Pearl River Community College.

Highway, which passes through the center of the mountains, connects the communities of Valley Falls, Oregon, and Wildhorse, Nevada.

original: The story was inspired by a question that the writers asked themselves, of who would succeed Michael, and it was decided that Deangelo would be the appropriate successor, since he could fill the company's need for "the level of energy that we associate with Michael." When casting for the part of Deangelo, the series' casting directors noted that there was "a sort of heightened absurdity to his energy" that they could see Rainn Wilson exhibiting. Wilson was asked to audition for the part by director Tucker Gates, and said that the role allowed him to expand on his performance as the quiet and sensitive Dwight, and that he enjoyed being able to "pull back on the reins" of his own acting. Although Wilson admits that he felt some pressure in getting the part of Deangelo right, he did not feel that he was putting more pressure on himself than other actors had on him. The editing of the episode's final scene involved Gates and the editors taking out a total of fifteen minutes of footage, including Jim and Pam's banter that was eventually saved for a deleted scene. Dwight delivers a nearly empty, half-baked threat to Michael Scott in the episode; before being edited out of the episode, it contained one last clause. Dwight's threat ended with "But then there's a 1% chance that I will take care of this problem the old-fashioned way: by punching you in the face." Scott sees through this, and notes that Dwight knows "how to punch like a girl," which is confirmed in a later episode. However, an alternate version of the ending was ultimately used. Dwight's face softened, and the series' main theme, "That's What You Get", was played. Dwight then says, "I'm glad you made the choice. I'm a different person now." Dwight gives Michael the address of his bed and breakfast in the countryside; his last words to him are "Now that's what you get." Michael shows up at the venue and opens the door, when suddenly the camera pans to the interior of a greenhouse, in which there are flowers and bushes and when Michael turns back around, he is now wearing a dress with a helmet. Season 7 finale, episode #15 (69) Original air date: April 14, 2011: Directed by Tucker Gates Written by Daniel Chun Dunder Mifflin's branch manager, Michael Scott, plans to retire. What will be the effect of Deangelo's arrival? Start writing your continuation by clicking below.

original:
They find a piece of a metallic powder at the scene of the murders that is biologically synthesized, which Walter identifies as zygote.

No examples were found where this episode was written about.

The episode's plot was developed for the purpose of giving the Fringe division access to a piece of technology called the zygote. The writers and executive producers J. J. Abrams, Alex Kurtzman, and Roberto Orci included themes of science and faith throughout the episode, which was influenced by Kurtzman and Orci's writings for the television series Alias. Executive producer Jeff Pinkner emphasized the use of symbols, suggesting the shape of a cell for the zygote. The crew used a real newborn and an adult actor for the older baby. Kurtzman was inspired to write a scene in which the baby is placed in a cryogenic freezer, and the writers eventually included it in the episode.

The episode has a 5.2 Nielsen rating, and received mixed reviews. Fringe Magazine criticized the lack of backstory for the characters, but thought the episode was interesting enough to justify a second viewing. Yahoo! TV found that the show was one of the most-watched programs on television. The cast received praise, but some reviewers found that the backstory for Peter was not clearly explained. Writing for BBC's Cult TV Online, Brian J. Robb found the episode to be "painfully dull" and in comparison to the pilot episode, found the episode to be "more of the same".

original: New business districts have since been established in neighborhoods such as First Street, Pleasant Hill, and N. Hills Street. In 2005, the city began a $15 million project to upgrade and renovate historic buildings in the city's downtown area, including cleaning, repainting, and installing new sidewalks and signs. Starting in 1998, the central part of town was named the "Jim Crow Museum of Racist Memorabilia" in honor of the artifacts and stories that came from a collection at the former Tuskegee University. The collection is on permanent loan to Central Michigan University and is kept in its present location for public viewing.

original:
She promoted and premiered the works of Aaron Copland and Virgil Thomson as well as, even more controversially, Kurt Weill, whom she knew personally, and whom she would take on a concert tour of Europe. In this tour, she also performed music by Bartók, Webern, Hindemith, and Ravel. In 1927, she married American dramatist Joseph Kesselring in Paris. In 1928 she performed the first American concert of music by Schoenberg in New York. She would later teach at the Mannes College of Music, where she also conducted a choir.

Contemporary Literature Example:
The continuation for this paragraph is: Gauthier remained on close terms with Kesselring, and continued to perform in music by Paul Bowles, Kurt Weill, Aaron Copland, and others. In 1930 she formed the Clara Bowles Modern Music Society with Kesselring and her fellow singer Rosa Stratis.

original:
At the end of the song, Carey left the stage, leaving only the choir and guitarist on-stage for a brief instrumental break, after which Carey returned and performed "We Belong Together". The song was accompanied by a costume change for Carey; she wore a long blue glittery gown and her hair was down, loosely parted and adorned with several hairpins. "One Sweet Day" was performed with only Lorenz, on which Carey performed a number of dance routines, in addition to the guitarist. Following the song, Carey performed her closing rendition of "Honey", which also featured her iconic gold hand-mirror. The ending of the show featured Carey atop the platform, the same as the beginning of the show, but with the addition of stage lights resembling flames, to accentuate the end of the performance.

____

***Miranda* comes into the studio with more ideas for the article. "I have a great idea. Why don't we talk about the impacts of the Butterfly Tour on Mariah Carey's career?". Susan nods thoughtfully. "You know what, Miranda? I think that is a really interesting angle to take. We could talk about how the tour affected her career, but then also about how the tour has affected the music industry as a whole. It could be an interesting article." Miranda nods in agreement. "That's a great idea!" she exclaims.

*Return to the previous page.*

original: Cage then tried to qualify by assaulting Joe with a chair. He tried to pin Joe with his feet on the ropes, but Nash, who was being used as a fifth referee, spotted it and disqualified Cage. Joe then hit Cage with the chair, then attacked Roode and Rhino before being attacked by Booker T. Booker was then put in the penalty box. A.J. Styles then ran down to the ring and attacked Joe and Roode with a ladder. Joe then followed with a heel kick, sending Styles over the top rope to the floor. Joe then tried to climb the ladder but Nash got into the ring and stopped him. A battle ensued between Nash and Joe, which was won by Nash. Nash then shoved the ladder into Joe, who rebounded off the steel steps. Joe then returned and hit Nash with the ladder. Styles and Cage then returned and brawled until Roode and Booker T interfered. At one point, Cage locked Roode in the TKO submission hold while Rhino attacked Booker with a chair. Booker escaped and superplexed Cage on a ladder. Rhino then punched Booker with the chair. The two began brawling, and Booker hit Rhino with the chair. Styles then performed a springboard maneuver on Booker, following with a pin. Shortly afterwards, Cage performed the Unprettier on Booker for the pin. Afterwards, the competitors attacked Styles, but he escaped. Rhino then did the same but was knocked out by a chair shot from Roode. Cage and Roode began battling outside the ring while Booker fought Styles in the ring. Booker threw Styles on a table. Joe then ran down to the ring and attacked Booker. Roode then fought his way to the ring. After Roode and Joe attacked each other, Roode slammed Joe face-first into the mat with his signature Pay Off maneuver. Joe escaped the pin attempt, bashed Roode with a chair, and pinned him with a roll-up pin. Joe then tried to climb the ladder to win the title but was stopped by Nash, who hit him with a steel chair. Afterwards, Booker locked Cage in a reverse figure four leglock. Rhino then returned to the ring, hitting Booker with a chair. A J Styles then tried to attack Joe with a ladder, but Joe escaped by fighting him. Nash then ran down to the ring and locked Cage in the Torture Rack (Fireman’s Carry Overhead Crush). Joe then climbed the ladder, but Nash then ripped it out from under him. Rhino then superplexed Booker off the ladder and bashed Styles with a chair. Roode then superplexed Rhino, and Cage followed with the pin attempt. Joe then ran back into the ring and bashed Cage with the chair. Joe then locked Cage in the Kokina Clutch (STF) and pinned him. After the bout, Joe won the match and retained the title. (source: Wikipedia) https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/2006_January_13_Thrashers-Timberwolves_gam

Wildlife includes bighorn sheep, elk, and mule deer. The numerous routes to the summit of Mount Elbert generally fall into two categories: the standard routes to the summit, and the Class 2 and Class 3 scrambles that skirt the south and west sides of the summit. Mount Elbert is one of the premier hiking destinations in the state of Colorado, owing to its easy access, challenging ascents, and excellent views of the surrounding mountains.

Wildlife includes bighorn sheep, elk, and mule deer. The numerous routes to the summit of Mount Elbert generally fall into two categories: the standard routes to the summit, and the Class 2 and Class 3 scrambles that skirt the south and west sides of the summit. Mount Elbert is one of the premier hiking destinations in the state of Colorado, owing to its easy access, challenging ascents, and excellent views of the surrounding mountains.

original:
The growth of the Portuguese Revolution and the South African Border War made it increasingly difficult for the Portuguese to enforce their authority over the border between Rhodesia and Mozambique, and the independence of Angola in 1975 had a similar effect on the border between Rhodesia and Angola. The move by South Africa to grant independence to its territory of Rhodesia in 1980 has been hailed as one of the most significant events in the history of southern Africa. However, while the process of decolonisation was a positive step in the history of the continent, it also raised questions about whether South Africa's decision to grant independence was premature and whether the new nation would be able to maintain its security and integrity. This article provides a comprehensive overview of the independence of Rhodesia and its impact on the region.

original: Whitehall informed Smith that, while a raid on Chimoio would not bring war with the United Kingdom, "anything directed at Zambia or Zimbabwe... would be extremely provocative and would be regarded as an act of war". The British Deputy Foreign Secretary, Michael Hart, called the planned operation "highly unwise, premature, a mistake", but Smith rejected Britain's warnings and sought to rally other members of the Western alliance against Zambia, claiming that it was "a haven for an evil campaign of terrorism" and that Zambia's government was "directly responsible for acts of sabotage, terrorism and wholesale murder, often taking place in South Africa but many times in Rhodesia". Smith received only the most limited of support, however, and the RAF was unwilling to provide refuelling support for the operation. To the British Government's and Zambian Government's relief, Smith suspended the planned offensive at the last minute due to reports of guerrillas massing for an offensive in Rhodesia itself. As the British Government had feared, Operation Dingo II would have started an international incident.

original:
The writers incorporated this into the script, and Gelfman and prop maker Mark Skinner were able to create the gun over a period of four hours. The team were inspired by what television and film director Robert Zemeckis would later create in the science fiction movie Back to the Future for the script.

As they wrap up the case, Olivia, Peter, and Walter complete forms to finalize their position in the Fringe division. When Peter is out of earshot, Walter learns from Olivia that the FBI medical files on Peter's childhood are void of any details. Co-creators J. J. Abrams, Alex Kurtzman and Roberto Orci, and executive producer Jeff Pinkner wrote the episode. Paul A. Edwards served as the director, his first such credit for the series. In developing Fringe, the co-creators did not want to make the series too serialized, as this was a complaint often directed at Abrams' television series Alias. They wanted to find a balance between standalone stories and serialized content, and studied procedural dramas such as Law and Order and CSI: Crime Scene Investigation for inspiration. Kurztman explained, "While we make sure that our episodes are self-contained – have a beginning, a middle, and an end – the character stories can be serialized. They don't have to resolve themselves over the course of one show." "The Same Old Story" was Fringe's first regular episode, and some journalists viewed it as an example of how the series would be structured. The episode was based on actual recent research and involved much collaboration among the series' different departments. For the scene in which they remove the victim's eyeball, the special effects crew created a mold based on actress Elizabeth Stanley's head. Using plaster to make a prosthetic, they "drilled out the eyeball and sculpt[ed] it open and [went] through a series of molds." Stanley stated that "it's really cool to see the head because it really does look just like me, even though it's very gruesome because the eyeball's popping out." The prop department rigged a weapon which they called a "photon gun"; according to prop master Peter Gelfman, this gun was based on real devices employed in airport security that look through people's clothing for concealed weapons. The writers incorporated this into the script, and Gelfman and prop maker Mark Skinner were able to create the gun over a period of four hours. The team were inspired by what television and film director Robert Zemeckis would later create in the science fiction movie Back to the Future for the script.

original: During the flight, Bond confronts Graves about his true identity and the diamonds, but Graves's plane is ambushed by North Korean fighters and shot down. The two are ejected from the aircraft and their parachute bags are mangled, forcing them to land in a glacier. They climb down a crevasse and escape the aircraft before it crashes. Miranda reveals herself to Bond and they have sex. A guilt-stricken Jinx subsequently discovers that Graves and Miranda are in league with North Korean agents, and enlists the help of fellow agents in Shanghai. Meanwhile, Graves arrives in Iceland and performs a demonstration of his doomsday device, the Icarus, a satellite with a giant reflector mirror which turns sunlight into a weaponized laser beam. Bond, Jinx, and the other MI6 agents are captured, and Jinx discovers that Miranda and Graves have been conspiring with North Korea to blackmail the rest of the world into giving the North Korean government control of all the diamond mines in exchange for the Icarus weapon's deactivation.

original:
With their season in Britain finished, the team prepared to leave. Before they did, they played a match against football team Corinthian in front of 14,000 fans in Battersea Park, London. The final score was a 4–1 win to the New Zealanders, who did not play their best football, having been distracted by some anti-Eyton supporters who had forced their way onto the pitch. When it came time to board the ship bound for New Zealand, much of the team were displeased with their treatment at the hands of the RFU. They were especially irritated that although they had been well remunerated, the RFU had used the tourists to promote rugby union in Britain at the expense of its rival, association football. The team returned home in June 1888.

Submit the response as a reply to this post and select the Markdown tab to the right of the text box.

• in 200-250 words only include the continuation in your response. • Should Natives as the New Zealanders were called or who are now called All Blacks be allowed to play rugby in England if they do not apologise when they protest a decision of the referee? Why or Why not? • In your opinion the New Zealanders' approach to the game of Rugby, is it right? Do you agree that the New Zealanders used rough play while playing the game in England? Why or Why not? • Based on the information given in the continuation what you think the main cause of the Natives' discontent with the way they were treated in England, and the English authorities? • In your opinion are New Zealanders justified in the manner in which they treated their last match in England? Why or Why not?

original:
Peter Travers of Rolling Stone magazine also praised the young actor's performance, stating: "He plays it with world-weary grace that never once goes in for pouty angst." Radcliffe was recognised as a rising star and was nominated for a Saturn Award for Best Young Actor. The same year, he also appeared in the BBC thriller comedy-drama The Gift, which aired in the United States on the PBS network as part of the Masterpiece Theatre series. For the role of the orphaned Nicholas Nickleby, who is forced to support his family after the death of his father, Radcliffe received a nomination for the Young Artist Award for Best Leading Young Actor.

In 2002, Radcliffe reprised his role as Harry Potter in the film adaptation of the second novel, Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets. The role was an ongoing one for Radcliffe, and he was under contract to make all eight of the Harry Potter films. The following year, Radcliffe signed an agreement to co-star in The Order of the Phoenix, the fifth Harry Potter film, to begin filming in 2006. He portrayed the titular character in a third film in the Harry Potter series, Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban (2004). Prisoner of Azkaban was a financial success. It opened with $93 million, setting a record for a Harry Potter film. The same year, Radcliffe provided the voice of the young Saitan in Miramax Films' computer-animated fantasy film The Polar Express, directed by Robert Zemeckis. A sci-fi television film, 2004's The Cranford Collection, was one of the first television productions Radcliffe worked on that did not revolve around the character of Harry Potter. He played one of the two main characters, a deaf and mute man, who, having seen his own mother die in childbirth, grew up believing his father died in a duel with his mother's suitor. Radcliffe had a leading role in the comedy drama My Boy Jack, playing the teenage son of war correspondent and former Prime Minister H. H. Asquith (played by David Haig), which was first shown on BBC One on 9 November 2007. The film is set in the First World War and is based on the play by Richard Harris.

original: Route 29A became a north–south highway between Lambertville and Flemington by 1953, with a gap in the designation between Milford and Frenchtown. In 1953, the alignment of Route 29 between Milford and Frenchtown was legislated as part of a new spur of Route 29 that would run from Frenchtown to Flemington, where it would use present-day U.S. Route 202 to Somerville. This new spur was signed by 1956. This spur of Route 29 was legislated to run concurrent with U.S. Route 202 (later Route 31) between Flemington and Clinton. The current alignment of Route 29 between Clinton and Somerville was designated Route 29B in 1953. The entire spur was designated as part of U.S. Route 202 in 1956, with the route renumbered to Route 31. This spur of Route 31 was designated as part of Route 29 in 1960. The original Route 29 between Trenton and Newark was eventually shifted onto the route between the current southern terminus of Route 29 and the Pennsylvania state line, along with the state-maintained section of U.S. Route 202 between Frenchtown and Flemington. The former alignment of Route 29 from Trenton to Lambertville became Route 29 Alt. Route 29 originally followed Trenton Road from the Delaware River Bridge to the northern terminus of Route 29. However, it was shortened in 2009 to end at the Washington Street intersection.
watermarked: Route 29A became a north–south highway between Lambertville and Flemington by 1953, with a gap in the designation between Milford and Frenchtown. In 1953, the alignment of Route 29 between Milford and Frenchtown was legislated as part of a new spur of Route 29 that would run from Frenchtown to Flemington, where it would use present-day U.S. Route 202 to Somerville. This new spur was signed by 1956. This spur of Route 29 was legislated to run concurrent with U.S. Route 202 (later Route 31) between Flemington and Clinton. The current alignment of Route 29 between Clinton and Somerville was designated Route 29B in 1953. The entire spur was designated as part of U.S. Route 202 in 1956, with the route renumbered to Route 31. This spur of Route 31 was designated as part of Route 29 in 1960. The original Route 29 between Trenton and Newark was eventually shifted onto the route between the current southern terminus of Route 29 and the Pennsylvania state line, along with the state-maintained section of U.S. Route 202 between Frenchtown and Flemington. The former alignment of Route 29 from Trenton to Lambertville became Route 29 Alt. Route 29 originally followed Trenton Road from the Delaware River Bridge to the northern terminus of Route 29. However, it was shortened in 2009 to end at the Washington Street intersection.

original: On the north side of downtown Iron Mountain, US 2/US 141/US 141 splits into three one-way roadways around the city hall building and runs concurrently along Pine Street and N. 1st Street toward Kingsford. US 2/US 141 re-merge and run concurrently with M‑95 on Stephenson Avenue to the south of Kingsford. The trunklines split from M‑95 in downtown Kingsford and follow M‑95 along Superior Avenue to its eastern terminus at a partial interchange with M‑69 (Lakeshore Drive). US 2/US 141 continue along M‑69 through Escanaba on Ludington Street to Ludington Street's eastern terminus at an intersection with Oak Street and North 6th Street in downtown Escanaba. North 6th Street meets M‑35 and is part of the highway's bypass around the city, and the three routes run concurrently eastward through Sagola Township. M‑69 splits at an intersection with Hibbard Road and North 19th Street and runs north along M‑35 and then northeast through Nahma to the Bay of Green Bay. US 2/US 141 continue eastward and cross over the Escanaba River at the town of Spring Lake. The highways meet M‑77, which runs north along North 18th Road through the communities of Rapid River and Gladstone, and the trunklines continue eastward to Rapid River, where M‑65 runs south from County Road 509. US 2/US 141 travel northeast through Peavy and Noggin Township to the community of Perkins, which is located near the Menominee River. The highway meets M‑45 at the intersection with Foster Road and then crosses the river, re-enters Wisconsin, and continues through the central forest lands of Marinette County. At the town of Pembine, US 141 breaks off and travels northeast toward Wisconsin Highway 32, while US 2 turns east and runs southeast to Pembine's southern outskirts where it meets M‑8 near County Road A.

original: There was also a great deal of unrest within the team. There were so many injuries that the team was forced to scrap its traditional squad rotation system. Unhappy with the way the captain John McEwan was handling the team, a number of senior players including Sutherland refused to play and were suspended. The final straw came when Cargill and Russell reacted angrily to comments McEwan had made in the papers about the rest of the team. The pair were suspended for the last tour match in Melbourne, and the team responded by forfeiting the match, ensuring that only McEwan and his remaining supporters collected their pay. With their Melbourne tour over, the team went to Adelaide where the injuries had already forced many players to leave. A number of the remaining Natives became quite ill on the long rail journey from Melbourne, further reducing the squad. The tour was already a disaster in terms of income, and the result was that no money was available to pay the players, forcing some of them into temporary work. This forced the Natives to forfeit all their matches in Adelaide and Perth, after which they arrived in Brisbane. A tour match against the Queensland representative team drew 1,500 paying spectators, before they forfeited a match in the same week. Having already cut their stay in Brisbane from five to three weeks, the team decided that they had to try to get some money by playing rugby in Brisbane. Once again, injury meant that only 11 players were available for the match. The rest of the team waited at a hotel, hoping to collect their pay. This time, the match finished in a 14-all draw, meaning the team had finally collected some money after the trip, although it was only 12s 6d per player. The team played a further two games before returning to Sydney.

The radius of the planet is unknown, but its minimum mass is 1.85 times the mass of Jupiter. The planet's orbit is eccentric, with an eccentricity of 0.03, which is slightly larger than that of Venus. The inclination of its orbit is poorly constrained, ranging between 7.7° and 89.5°. Given its estimated mass and the results of simulations of its formation, Upsilon Andromedae b is thought to have formed further out in the system, then migrated inward, before settling into its current position. The star also hosts a less massive planet orbiting at an intermediate distance, called Upsilon Andromedae c. With a mass of 14.76 Jupiter masses, Upsilon Andromedae c has a minimum radius of about 1.38 Jupiters. Upsilon Andromedae c orbits its host star every 241.1 days and has an orbital distance of 0.830 AU. The stellar parameters are similar to those of the Sun, so the planet is probably comparable to Jupiter. It also has a more circular orbit than the inner planet. At the time of the discovery, the study of Upsilon Andromedae was the most comprehensive study of a planetary system outside our own, and it provided the strongest evidence for the existence of planets in other stellar systems. This star is only slightly larger than the Sun and 1.4 times as massive. Unlike 51 Pegasi b, the first extrasolar planet discovered, the planet orbits in the same direction as its star spins. The Doppler shift caused by the planet's orbit also reveals the existence of a second planet orbiting the star, known as Upsilon Andromedae c. Upsilon Andromedae A is part of a binary system, with a dim companion about 40 astronomical units away. In addition to planets, the system is also likely to host a large number of asteroids and comets. It is a young star, possibly as young as 200 million years old. It is the only star known to have more than one giant planet and is one of the few stars that have had planetary systems detected by the stellar wobble method. Because of its relative proximity, it is a prime target for both the Hubble and Kepler space telescopes.

Upsilon Andromedae b (υ Andromedae b, abbreviated Upsilon And b, υ And b), formally named Saffar, is an extrasolar planet approximately 44 light-years away from the Sun in the constellation of Andromeda. The planet orbits the solar analog star, Upsilon Andromedae A, approximately every five days. Discovered in June 1996 by Geoffrey Marcy and R. Paul Butler, it was one of the first hot Jupiters to be discovered. It is also one of the first non-resolved planets to be detected directly. Upsilon Andromedae b is the innermost known planet in its planetary system. In July 2014 the International Astronomical Union launched a process for giving proper names to certain exoplanets and their host stars. The process involved public nomination and voting for the new names. In December 2015, the IAU announced the winning name was Saffar for this planet. The winning name was submitted by the Vega Astronomy Club of Morocco and honours the 11th Century astronomer Ibn al-Saffar of Muslim Spain. Upsilon Andromedae b was detected by the variations in its star's radial velocity caused by the planet's gravity. The variations were detected by making sensitive measurements of the Doppler shift of Upsilon Andromedae's spectrum. The planet's existence was announced in January 1997, together with 55 Cancri b and the planet orbiting Tau Boötis. Like 51 Pegasi b, the first extrasolar planet discovered around a normal star, Upsilon Andromedae b orbits very close to its star, closer than Mercury does to our Sun. The planet takes 4.617 days to complete an orbit, with a semimajor axis of 0.0595 AU. The radius of the planet is unknown, but its minimum mass is 1.85 times the mass of Jupiter. The planet's orbit is eccentric, with an eccentricity of 0.03, which is slightly larger than that of Venus. The inclination of its orbit is poorly constrained, ranging between 7.7° and 89.5°. In addition to planets, the system is also likely to host a large number of asteroids and comets. It is a young star, possibly as young as 200 million years old. It is the only star known to have more than one giant planet and is one of the few stars that have had planetary systems detected by the stellar wobble method. Because of its relative proximity, it is a prime target for both the Hubble and Kepler space telescopes.

original: Rolling Stone ranked the song at number 31 on their list of the 500 Greatest Songs of All Time. The song was also included in the Rock and Roll Hall of Fame's 500 Songs that Shaped Rock and Roll list. In 2002, "Where the Streets Have No Name" was voted by the listeners of Radio X as the best single of all time, although it only got 41,333 votes. The song was also listed at number 25 in Q magazine's 100 Greatest Guitar Tracks.

original: At 10:00, Edson called for additional support and reserve troops landed at Taivu. Edson's troops continued to Tasimboko and met heavy resistance from the Japanese at the village. The 2nd Battalion, 5th Marines began attacking the Japanese rear at 16:20. As Edson's men closed in on the Japanese, the Japanese began to retreat to the west towards Kokengahau Ridge. The Japanese commander at Tasimboko detonated ammunition supplies, destroying most of his forces and stockpiles. The Japanese lost about 250 killed and an unknown number wounded. The US Marines reported 41 killed and 83 wounded. The success of Edson's raid destroyed the Japanese supply depot at Taivu, which eliminated the Japanese ability to resupply Kawaguchi's forces.

The Japanese commander at Tasimboko detonated ammunition supplies, destroying most of his forces and stockpiles. The Japanese lost about 250 killed and an unknown number wounded. The US Marines reported 41 killed and 83 wounded. The success of Edson's raid destroyed the Japanese supply depot at Taivu, which eliminated the Japanese ability to resupply Kawaguchi's forces.

original:
Australian personnel also provided support to United Nations agencies in Iraq and were involved in a wide range of reconstruction, stabilisation and nation-building activities.

Australian political support for the invasion and occupation of Iraq was mixed and divided along ideological lines. Prime Minister John Howard initially called for a regime change in Iraq following the 9/11 terrorist attacks and clearly supported a US-led invasion. The official opposition Labor Party remained strongly opposed to the invasion and only offered limited support following the passage of United Nations Security Council Resolution 1441 in 2002. Labor’s position softened somewhat after the passing of Resolution 1441, and it provided substantial support for Operation Catalyst in 2004 and 2005.

For part of their campaign in Iraq, the Australians adopted a bi-colour colour scheme of olive drab and sand yellow. This was inspired by the Centaur helicopters of the 1960s and 1970s. In 2006, Australia introduced a desert variant of the Australian Army uniform, the Multicam Combat Uniform.

Since 1987 the Australian National Veterans’ Convention has been held every three years. At the 1989 convention in Canberra, representatives of veterans associations and groups met to agree on an Action Plan. The Australian government used this Plan as the basis of its decision to provide comprehensive care and rehabilitation for former military personnel as well as their families. This decision brought about the development of the Department of Veterans’ Affairs and the Veterans’ Review Board, two major components of the support system for Australia’s veteran community.

## Discussion questions

• How and when did Australia become involved in Iraq? Who made the decision? Why did the Australian government decide to send forces to Iraq? What have Australia's roles been in Iraq? (Remember to analyse the time line)
• Explain the position of the Australian government in regards to the invasion of Iraq (see paragraphs 2, 3, 5 and 9).
• How did Australian public opinion towards the war in Iraq change over time? Explain how Australia's commitment in Iraq changed over time. (see paragraphs 2, 3, 5 and 9)
• What were the criticisms made of Australia's commitment in Iraq?
• How and why did the decision to stay in Iraq after the war changed?
• Australia did not take part in the post-war occupation of Iraq, why?
• What was the involvement of the ADF in Iraq during the post-war occupation? (see paragraph 7)
• What were the key components of the support system for Australia’s veteran community (see paragraph 10)

original:
Thom Scott of GameStar called the Genesis version of Sonic the Hedgehog the "definitive" version and commended the "fantastic" graphics, although he was critical of the sound, calling it "primitive" compared to the graphics. PC Games gave a similar review, calling Sonic the Hedgehog "technically" the best game on the Genesis and calling the "cinematic" sprites and animations "wonderful", but again criticizing the sound. Retrospective reviews of the Game Boy version were more mixed. Mean Machines called it a "good portable conversion" of the original game. Jim Vejvoda of IGN stated that the Game Boy version is "a fun game in its own right", but "nothing special" and "not that far off from all the other platformers" available at the time. Kevin Cartwright of Sega Saturn Magazine called the game "suffocated by hardware limitations, [as] Sonic's charms are lost in the translation". 1UP.com considered the Game Boy version "pretty playable" and stated that "while there's little reason to bother with Sonic the Hedgehog over its many, many successors... if you want to own a Sonic game for your Game Boy, this isn't the worst choice". In 2006, GameSpy listed it as one of the top five "underrated" Sonic games.

Post at least 10 posts and earn 1000 points. Enjoy reading here :);

original: Meridian Little Theatre was formed from The Mississippi Players, an amateur dramatics club founded in 1916, and has been in operation continuously since 1936. After a "temporary" home in 1940 and 1955, the theatre was moved to its present location in the old St. Paul's Methodist Church in 1964, which had served as a church from 1928 to 1956. The theatre received a restoration grant from the National Endowment for the Arts and the Mississippi Department of Archives and History in 1986 which established the Meridian Community Theatre Complex. In 1997, the theatre purchased the old St. Paul's parsonage and renovated it as the Brock Store Arts Gallery, which serves as a gallery for theatre and other works of art. The new wings, built in 1997, contain dressing rooms and support facilities, and allowed the rear section of the theatre to be converted into the Broc Store Gallery. The Meridian Symphony Orchestra, the only professional orchestra between Jackson and Birmingham, Alabama, was established in 1948, and provides four classical and pops concerts each season as well as educational outreach concerts throughout the year. Meridian's musical scene is defined by gospel, rock and roll, rhythm and blues, soul music, country, rap, hip-hop, and alternative music. Several famous musicians were born in Meridian, including Hank Locklin, Jimmy Nolen, Rance Allen, Joe Frank Carollo, Frankie Lyman, Bob White, Bobby "Blue" Bland, and Charlie Rich. Other musicians who grew up or lived in Meridian include B.B. King, Paul 'Dino' Cordova, Pat Boone, Grandpa Jones, Laverne Baker, Mack Vickery, and James 'J.T.' Taylor. Many famous rock artists have performed in the city over the years, including The Rolling Stones, Aerosmith, The Allman Brothers, Lynyrd Skynyrd, Billy Joel, Jackson Browne, Bonnie Raitt, U2, Santana, Ted Nugent, Robert Plant, Emerson, Lake, and Palmer, Eric Clapton, The Doobie Brothers, Crosby, Stills, Nash, and Young, The Steve Miller Band, and ELO. Theatre, including Broadway and regional plays, is also popular in Meridian. As well as hosting touring theatre productions, Meridian Little Theatre presents six productions each season, with performances at the theatre as well as at elementary schools, high schools, retirement homes, and local businesses. An original work by local playwright Myra Callahan was presented at the Kennedy Center for the Performing Arts in Washington, D.C. In the 1950s and 1960s, Meridian was one of the main centers for the civil rights movement in Mississippi. Medgar Evers, who was field secretary for the NAACP, was murdered on June 12, 1963. Martin Luther King Jr. spoke at Riley's Inn at the Mississippi State Fairgrounds on March 6, 1962. On August 28, 1964, Martin Luther King Jr., Andrew Young, and Joseph Lowery met with then Mayor James C. Chadbourne to present a list of grievances and demands for civil rights in Meridian, an event covered by The New York Times. That day, five teenagers were arrested in the city and jailed for sitting at a white lunch counter in Woolworth's department store. Nine days later, on September 7, 1964, over a thousand demonstrators gathered at Meridian City Hall demanding that the teenagers be released and that segregation laws be repealed. The mayor replied that, while he would "like to see everything made equal for everybody", he had no control over the actions of the city commissioners. Mayor Chadbourne also stated that the civil rights law was "probably unconstitutional" and that he did not agree with the federal government's attempt to force integration. Meridian was struck by a major tornado on April 24, 1966. The tornado killed five and injured more than 130, and caused $1 million in damage, which was adjusted for inflation to more than $7 million in 2010 dollars. Widespread damage in residential, commercial, and industrial areas was reported, but the tornado caused the most damage to the west side of Meridian near the city's industrial corridor, where businesses and homes were damaged or destroyed. Around 9:45 P.M. on April 24, the F5 tornado tore through Meridian, moving on a diagonal path from a point just west of Meridian Naval Air Station to near East Meridian. The F5 tornado traveled about 20 miles (32 km) in 28 minutes, and touched down briefly in Marion and Newton Counties, leaving behind a path of destruction 7 miles (11 km) wide and up to a half mile (0.8 km) wide at the center. Twenty-six separate secondary tornadoes were spawned from the larger tornado during its course. The EF2 tornado moved across the Mississippi-Alabama border near the town of Toomsuba before moving east across the highway to destroy several homes along Bay Springs Lake Road. From there, the tornado turned northeast and moved across Highway 39, where it lifted, leaving behind extensive tree damage. The third and fourth tornadoes began within the first mile of the main tornado as it entered Lauderdale County and dissipated just before the main tornado crossed the Tombigbee River. Several homes along the river were damaged or destroyed by the tornado, which traveled up the river before dissipating. The tornado then jumped Highway 39, crossed the Tombigbee River, and destroyed or damaged numerous homes before weakening and crossing the river again. The tornado then turned east before dissipating as it moved across State Highway 184. The tornado next struck the western side of the city, moving along Highway 11 and Highway 19 into Meridian. The tornado tracked across the city in a diagonal path, with tornado damage extending from the west side of the city into downtown. Widespread damage was reported in residential, commercial, and industrial areas. According to an anonymous witness who reported the damage to the National Weather Service after the storm, one of the major tornadoes touched down at 10:16 P.M. and moved northeast for about 25 miles, touching down in Marion, Mississippi, and ending near Meridian. According to the eyewitness, the tornado was more than a mile wide. Many homes, including some which were brick, were leveled or swept off their foundations by the tornado. Numerous homes were also completely destroyed, with some having been hit by multiple vortices of the tornado. Other homes were severely damaged by the tornado, with walls blown off or entire sections of homes being destroyed. According to the eyewitness, the tornado was more than a mile wide. Many homes, including some which were brick, were leveled or swept off their foundations by the tornado. Numerous homes were also completely destroyed, with some having been hit by multiple vortices of the tornado. Other homes were severely damaged by the tornado, with walls blown off or entire sections of homes being destroyed.

The new wings, built in 1997, contain dressing rooms and support facilities, and allowed the rear section of the theatre to be converted into the Broc Store Gallery. So the person who wrote the text was doing a job interview with either Ma Anand Sheela or Ma Poorna, or both and this person could not get enough information from this person about what they believe went on, so he or she made this whole thing up.

Then on the way to carry out the hit, they realized they were not going to be able to do it, they would be killed or arrested.  So what happened, Sheela then pulled in another group of people to do the hit.  Then when the hit went wrong that was it, it was over, they gave up.

Meditation is a simple practice available to all of us. Just as a daily workout trains the body, a daily meditation practice trains the mind. As you develop your concentration and mindfulness skills, you become better able to cope with daily stress, sleep more soundly, be kinder and more patient towards yourself and others, and increase your capacity for joy. And, if you have trouble sleeping, meditation might be one solution to the problem. Meditation has been shown to help regulate melatonin levels and to improve sleep quality.

Here are some basic pointers for getting started.  For more information, check out the extensive resources available at (URL: meditation.donotprint.org/)

1.  Find a quiet place, sit upright, close your eyes and observe your breath.  At first, you can set a timer so you don’t have to worry about remembering when it’s time to stop.
2.  When a thought arises, watch it without getting pulled into it.  Then return to observing your breath.  When the thought subsides, thank the thought for coming, then let it go.
3.  Repeat step two.  If it helps, you can think of the mind like the ocean.  Just as a wave appears and disappears on the ocean’s surface, thoughts appear and disappear in the mind.  But you are not the thought.  You are the watcher of the thought.
4.  Practice regularly, preferably daily.  With consistent practice, you can expect to see benefits from this simple and effective practice in as little as 10 minutes a day.

1.  Find a comfortable, upright position, either sitting or lying down.  Your body should feel alert, but not strained.
2.  Close your eyes and let your arms and legs relax.  Let your body relax deeply.
3.  Notice where you feel comfortable and where you feel tension.  Then let the tension go.  As the tension goes, the sensation of comfort becomes more intense.
4.  Bring your attention to your breath.  Notice the sensation of your breath coming in and going out.  As you watch the breath, notice that your attention drifts away from the breath to other thoughts and sensations.  That’s okay.  When you notice your attention has drifted away, just bring it back to the breath.
5.  When you are ready, return your attention to your breath and let your body relax further.
6.  Repeat step five.

Using these guidelines, you can begin your meditation practice today.  As you get started, don’t worry if you can’t sit still or if your mind seems like a jumble of thoughts.  This is normal and to be expected.  The benefits of meditation come over time with consistent practice.  If you want to take your practice deeper, you might want to try one of the resources available at (URL: meditation.donotprint.org/)

So the assassination attempt is fake, that's why they started coming up with their stories, not to make the public think it was real.  It was real, they were ready, but they decided against it, and that is where things began to happen.

Consider the following two points.

1.  They did their due diligence, they checked and double checked.

2.  They thought it was so bad they did not want to leave the country, they did not want to live in exile in a foreign country.

They were going to leave the country, in fact, they did leave, but not because of the assassination attempt, it was something else, it was a simple tax fraud.

There are two levels of leadership, the Rajneeshees and the FBI.  The Rajneeshees wanted to control everything in Antelope, they were not ready to kill people, it would take too long.  At the same time they were willing to kill people, but they didn't want to do it themselves, they had hired someone else to do the dirty work.

There is no reason to think the FBI did not know, in fact, they did.  The Rajneeshees were more than willing to kill someone, and they were more than willing to pay someone else to do it, but they were not ready to do it themselves, they did not want to do it themselves.

The FBI knew the Rajneeshees had the money to do this, they knew the Rajneeshees had hired someone else to do it.

I know, it's not what you were expecting, but it's what happened.

Do not confuse the Rajneeshees with the FBI, the FBI was running the show.

Most of the original Rajneeshees are still living in Rajneeshpuram, and the FBI was not interested in their opinions, so they were not asked, they were not asked about anything.

There are many problems, and they are not the original Rajneeshees problems.

1.  The original Rajneeshees were "infiltrated", they were forced to accept false information, they were "forced" to believe what the FBI told them was true.

2.  The original Rajneeshees were not "infiltrated", they were not forced to believe the FBI's story.

So what happened?

The Rajneeshees did not care about the FBI's story, they did not want to know the FBI's story, they did not want to know the FBI's version of events, they did not want to know the FBI's version of events.  They just wanted to be left alone, they just wanted to be left alone, they just wanted to be left alone.

The Rajneeshees did not want to believe the FBI's story, the Rajneeshees did not want to believe the FBI's version of events.

original: The construction of the sculpture took 18 months to complete and was overseen by Peter Kennett, the managing director of the company., the estimated cost of the sculpture was. Both of these figures have been described as controversial as the estimate did not include costs for maintenance or foundations, but instead included estimated revenue from visitors. In the three years before construction of the statue was completed, council estimated that visitor numbers would total 500,000 per year, generating revenue of nearly. After the failure to achieve such numbers, the council raised additional funding to manage the facility by contributing 4.8% of the council budget. In 2007, 50,000 people had visited the sculpture. In 2008, revenue of approximately £280,000 was generated. Following the completion of B of the Bang, the sculpture's architect and engineer offered their services for free to help with the construction of a project to improve the local area. They specifically proposed the building of a bridge over the railway to link the Eastlands area of the city with the central shopping area and the tram stop adjacent to B of the Bang. They also suggested a pedestrian 'green route' linking Eastlands with the Heaton Park area to the north of the city centre. The sculpture's design received awards from the Royal Institute of British Architects, the British Constructional Steelwork Association, the Institution of Structural Engineers, and the Royal Institute of Architects of Ireland. It received a prestigious International Architecture Award in 2006, along with the Angel of the North, Ordsall Chord bridge and Whitworth Art Gallery expansion. An independent visitor survey showed that 75% of respondents felt that B of the Bang made Manchester more attractive to visit, 77% felt that the statue was worth saving and 84% felt it made a good contribution to the local area. Aspire on the campus of the University of Nottingham. B of the Bang was unique among sculptures in Britain at the time.

The wooden wallower, carried by the vertical shaft, drives the wooden great spur wheel through a series of wooden teeth. This in turn drives the two pairs of overdrift millstones, each pair being driven by a wooden stone nut carried on a wooden upright shaft. The millstones are of Indian sandstone and weigh over each. The mill is described from the top down. The pepperpot cap sits on top of the tower, giving the mill an overall height of to the finial. It houses the cast-iron windshaft and diameter wooden brake wheel internally. Externally the four double Patent sails span. They are wide and can develop. The eight bladed fantail keeps the mill turned into wind. The top floor of the mill is the dust floor. It could be used for storage of grain and gives internal access to the cap. The cast-iron wallower, which is driven by the brake wheel is carried at the top of the upright shaft, in the centre of the mill. Once again, the support for the Thelnetham Mill Preservation Trust from the local community was considerable, with over 300,000 people visiting open days and a subscription from over 600 households to the Thelnetham Mill Preservation Trust journal. The project continued to receive positive press coverage, with front-page articles in the Daily Telegraph and The Times, as well as a half-hour television documentary, for Channel 4's Late Show. In April 1988, a provisional order to wind up the Thelnetham Mill Preservation Trust was made by a petition presented to the High Court, but after the shareholders of the Trust sent a letter to the Secretary of State for the Environment requesting the petition to be withdrawn, the order was withdrawn in May. Local businessman John Good of Bowaters-Mercury expressed interest in purchasing the mill, but after carrying out a survey and failing to obtain planning permission to retain the mill as a working mill, he sold the property to the mill Trust in June 1988. The restoration was completed by July 1988. The restoration of Thelnetham Windmill was made possible by the efforts of 135 individuals and 61 organisations. This was achieved by the donation of labour, plant, materials or grants of money, or by giving discounts for materials purchased or providing publicity for the project. The mill was taken out of steam in 1930, but remained in use as a gas mill, until it was sold to the Royal British Legion as a hall. It was purchased by the Preservation Trust in 1974 for £1,500, on condition that the Trust opened the mill to the public and restored the mill to working order. The Thelnetham Mill Preservation Trust was formed in 1975, with John White as Chairman, in 1977, Hervey Benham was appointed as a trustee. In the US the film premiered in New York City on 11 December 2002 at the Ziegfeld Theatre. Over 400 guests attended the red carpet gala event, hosted by MGM and Sony. Peter Lamont said that "because of the extreme weather during filming, the producers decided to add to the end titles a visual postscript, 'Bloody Cold!'". The film then went into general release on 20 December 2002. The film made US$47,067,225 in its opening weekend, breaking the record for December, until it was beaten in 2007 by I Am Legend. It was a huge financial success, grossing $431.9 million worldwide, making it the fifth-highest-grossing Bond film at the time, behind Die Hard, Tomorrow Never Dies, Licence to Kill and GoldenEye. ### Die Another Day Q&A
How to Write a Good Summary: When you write a summary, you take a short section of text (such as a story, article, or essay) and boil it down into just its most important points. Your goal is to provide a brief and concise overview of the text, making it easy for the reader to understand it. In this tutorial, you will learn how to write a summary. What Is a Summary? Writing a good summary requires understanding the importance of a summary. To understand that, let’s discuss some of the reasons why summaries are useful. Summary is an extremely common writing task and one of the most useful skills you can develop. Not only do summaries help you digest and retain information, they also allow you to convey your own thoughts in a coherent and meaningful way. Here are a few reasons why writing summaries is important: A good summary should achieve 2 goals: Give the reader a basic understanding of the text Provide your own opinion, judgment, or evaluation of the text 4. Judging the overall point and/or tone of the text 5. Summarize the text (use quotes to provide some support for the summary, and avoid changing the author’s original tone or point of view) Here are a few important tips to remember: Try to understand the author’s purpose, and what message he/she is trying to convey Give the overall tone and point of view Use direct quotes to support your summary Read the entire text before writing the summary Use the original text, not a summary of the original text Be concise and cover only the main points Here are the steps to writing a good summary: 1. Read the text Once you’ve decided which text you want to summarize, read the text multiple times, taking notes as you go. First, get the general idea of the text. Then, pick out the key points and support material for your summary. Finally, make a list of your observations, but don’t forget to include your own evaluation as well. 2. Create a list of notes and quotes for your summary Next, you should create a list of your notes and quotes that support your summary. You should make sure you understand the author’s point of view, tone, and purpose. 3. Write the first draft Your first draft should be written as a summary. Remember to stay focused on the text and provide only the most important information. 4. Evaluate your first draft This step is extremely important. You should go through the draft to evaluate your writing, making sure you’ve followed the tips mentioned earlier. You should also check for spelling and grammatical errors. You should also make sure you included the most important points. 5. Write the final draft After you’ve evaluated your first draft, it’s time to write the final draft. This should be the version you’re planning to hand in or submit. If you have to send it to someone, be sure to include a word count, and any additional instructions or requirements. The case became known as the "Meridian Speedway Trial" after charges against others were dropped. The 186th Air Refueling Wing of the Mississippi Air National Guard is located in Meridian. Originally established in 1941 as the 167th Fighter Group of the Mississippi Air National Guard, its predecessor units date to 1941. Its major flying base has been Meridian's Key Field, since 1969. For much of the Cold War, the 167th was a squadron of the Active Air Force's 509th Fighter-Bomber Wing at Riverside Air Base, Riverside, California. The 167th was a Nuclear strike unit and flying the North American F-100 Super Sabre (1956-1961) and Republic F-105 Thunderchief (1961–1969). In 1969, the 167th returned to Mississippi, and its flying mission became the Atlantic Air Command's Aeromedical Airlift Unit until 1992. In 1993, the 167th returned to the combat mission in the new Air Force Objective Organization when it became the 167th Air Refueling Wing (1993-1994) and then the 186th Air Refueling Wing (1995–Present). The wing presently flies the Boeing KC-135R, a 1950s jet aircraft with a 2007 modernization. Current missions include support to NASA, Army Unmanned Aerial Vehicle testing, and the Northeast Army National Guard mobilization center for deployment in Iraq and Afghanistan. Mississippi College School of Law is the only law school in Mississippi and serves approximately 420 students.

The Chinese took advantage of the situation and invaded in 1287. Pagan fell in May 1287. But the invasion proved a Pyrrhic victory. The war took a severe toll on the Mongol forces in Burma. The Mongol sources report that 90% of the original army died. It was a lesson which the Mongol Emperors would never forget. It was the last attempt to establish a permanent Mongol presence in mainland Southeast Asia.

Naka designed the music, and directed Nakamura. Nakamura helped the team through some of the score's problems, and wrote the "Gotta Go Fast" theme that would go on to be used in other media. The chiptunes of the game impressed audiophiles and gave rise to a cult following. The music was limited by hardware, with Naka saying that he wished the Yamaha YM2612 was more flexible. Naka, who knew nothing of programming at first, described the programming of Sonic as a "sophisticated and complex work". Naka was reluctant to try to create the effects of a rotating object in the game, until programming on the Sega Mega Drive was done and it was possible to create 3D effects. After Sega released the first demo of Sonic, they did not tell developers or their rivals about the game's contents. This caused those in the industry to assume Sonic was a bad game. Before Sonic was released, Sega were planning on making Sonic a TV anime; a pilot of the show was made. The game was also the inspiration for the early series Archie Sonic comics. The game's success caused Naka to believe the time was right to create a new genre of games, and he wanted to design an original and "fun" game. His goal was to create "the world's most exciting game".

watermarked:
Naka designed the music, and directed Nakamura. Nakamura helped the team through some of the score's problems, and wrote the "Gotta Go Fast" theme that would go on to be used in other media. The chiptunes of the game impressed audiophiles and gave rise to a cult following. The music was limited by hardware, with Naka saying that he wished the Yamaha YM2612 was more flexible. Naka, who knew nothing of programming at first, described the programming of Sonic as a "sophisticated and complex work". Naka was reluctant to try to create the effects of a rotating object in the game, until programming on the Sega Mega Drive was done and it was possible to create 3D effects. After Sega released the first demo of Sonic, they did not tell developers or their rivals about the game's contents. This caused those in the industry to assume Sonic was a bad game. Before Sonic was released, Sega were planning on making Sonic a TV anime; a pilot of the show was made. The game was also the inspiration for the early series Archie Sonic comics. The game's success caused Naka to believe the time was right to create a new genre of games, and he wanted to design an original and "fun" game. His goal was to create "the world's most exciting game".

original:
Although under repair at Sasebo, she was mobilized in mid-1904 as part of a special commission sent to Europe for a bombardment of several Russian ports, including Reval (Tallinn), Finland, and Libau, Germany. Prior to this, Asahi had been involved in the earlier stages of the war, under the command of Captain Noboru Mizuno. She was involved in the capture of the Formidabale, which had been in contact with Russian troops in North Korea.

$\begin{array}{l}\text{Answer:}\\\text{Asahi went through a period of significant upgrades to her machinery from 1905–1906, the most notable of which was the installation of triple-expansion steam engines and armament consisting of four 12-inch guns and twelve 6-inch guns. In 1909, a third mast was added and a tripod mast was installed for radio antennae. Beginning in 1913, an additional pair of 4.7-inch and six 3-inch anti-aircraft guns were added. Asahi was replaced by the modern battleship Yamashiro in the Second Fleet and then the Third Fleet in 1918, the following year she was converted into an unmanned lighthouse. Her superstructure was removed and a rotating light was installed on the foremast to act as a replacement for the deactivated Kashiwara Lighthouse. Later, a station for naval auxiliary communications was established on the ship, although she remained disarmed and unable to operate under her own power. In 1928 she was towed to Yokosuka Naval Arsenal for scrapping. All her major parts were dismantled for scrap, although her stem and mainmast were moved to Hashirajima, Japan for preservation as a war memorial to the Russo-Japanese War.}\end{array}$

In May 2013, Scientology spokesman Tommy Davis called on the German government to end "hysteria", stating that the government's conduct had put Scientology in a situation where it would have to suspend relations with Germany "because of the ongoing hate campaign". On May 16, 2013, the German magazine Stern published an interview with German Scientology spokeswoman Heike Fischer. Asked whether there would come a time when Scientology had to formally withdraw from Germany, Fischer responded, "Definitely not".

Xenophobia as such is a cognitive bias, of course, but often arises in situations of transition of transition from one group to another or one nation to another. The general argument is that the newer and more flexible group or nation will tend to adapt to the older and more rigid, whereas the reverse will not happen. How do you think that this dynamic would play out between the established German nation and the incoming culture of Scientology, or any new arrival culture for that matter?

However, it rejected the comparison of the treatment of Scientologists with that of Jews during the Nazi era. In 2000, the German Stern magazine published the results of its investigation of the asylum case. It asserted that several rejection letters which the woman had submitted as part of her asylum application – ostensibly from potential employers who were rejecting her because she was a Scientologist – had in fact been written by fellow Scientologists at her request and that of Scientology's Office of Special Affairs, and that she was in personal financial trouble and about to go on trial for tax evasion at the time she applied for asylum. On a 2000 visit to Clearwater, Florida, Ursula Caberta of the Scientology Task Force for the Hamburg Interior Authority likewise alleged that the asylum case had been part of an "orchestrated effort" by Scientology undertaken "for political gain", and "a spectacular abuse of the U.S. system". German expatriate Scientologists resident in Clearwater, in turn, accused Caberta of stoking a "hate campaign" in Germany that had "ruined the lives and fortunes of scores of Scientologists" and maintained that Scientologists had not "exaggerated their plight for political gain in the United States." Mark Rathbun, a (former) top Church of Scientology official, said that although Scientology had not orchestrated the case, "there would have been nothing improper if it had." In 2003, Joachim Güntner, writing in the Swiss Neue Zürcher Zeitung, noted that Gerhard Besier, a German Christian theologian, director of the Hannah Arendt Institute for Research into Totalitarianism in Dresden and recipient of an honorary doctorate from Lund University, Sweden, for his championing of religious freedom, had been pressured to forego publication of his scientific study of Scientology after having found himself the subject of widespread criticism in the German media for advocating a more tolerant attitude towards Scientology. Güntner concluded that "alarmism" had "triumphed" over science and noted an apparent lack of confidence in Germany's ability to engage in open public discourse on the matter. Courtship rituals are involved, including the female responding to the tapping of the male's antennae, and the male then offering her a ride on his back, which she can reject. After mating, the female releases thousands of fertilised eggs on to a rock surface or structure. She then holds the eggs close to her pleopods, on the underside of her abdomen. Here the eggs are oxygenated by the water pumped through the brood chamber by the gills. The female carries the eggs with her for 9–10 months until the eggs hatch. During this period, she does not eat, and only rarely will she leave her shelter to feed. Eventually, the eggs hatch into nauplius larvae. They moult three times, becoming ala, nyhalids, and finally into miniatures of the adult. The young are then free-living, and may shelter with adults, or congregate in their own schools. These young are vulnerable to epibiosis, and once the pleopods are lost, they will often attach themselves to seaweed or on the bodies of other crustaceans, although once they have developed large chelipeds, they will aggressively prevent attachment. The growth rate of juvenile lobsters depends on temperature. At temperatures of 20 °C, they grow rapidly, whereas those kept at 10 °C grow more slowly, though live longer.

Use an article on agriculture  for example the following one : Farmers learn how to battle emerging pest ( http://www.cornandsoybeandigest.com/soybean-farmers-learning-how-battle-emerging-pest-soybean-cyst-nematode-040317).

Identify the 3 major factors that affect the pest growth and cause the cycle of pest outbreaks.

Which of these factors are direct or indirect?

Which of these factors can be corrected?

Which of these factors cannot be corrected?

Make a figure (pest growth cycle) with these factors that will illustrate the pest growth. (Add the text to your word document and upload it to turn-it in)

3. Explain the mode of action of the Bt toxin.

4. Search for the mode of action of a insecticide in wikipedia and compare with the Bt toxin.

5. What are the advantages of Bt toxin compared with insecticide?

Exercise 7:

Bt toxin is produced by a bacterium (www.bacillusthuringiensis.com/index2.htm) for instance Bacillus thuringiensis. Some Bt strains are specific to pest and are called toxins. The toxin are used as biopesticides as an alternative to the chemical pesticides to control pests.

As pests become resistant to toxins, new toxins are discovered and isolated from other Bt strains and are used to control them.

For example, pests become resistant to the Bt toxin Cry1Ab (from Bt strain Israel) that was used to control the cotton bollworm. Then, another toxin was discovered in a Bt strain called Cry1Ac (from Bt strain Kansas) that is effective against the same pest species (cotton bollworm).

Make a powerpoint presentation that illustrate the following:

1. Bt toxins in the larva (spores)

2. Examples of new toxins being found

3. How new toxins could be more effective against resistance?

4. Conclusions: why does resistance exist and what can we do against it?

“Cabbage white butterfly is a pest. How would you control it? Present the different possible control options”.

Make a powerpoint presentation.

Which bacteria do you think? Give the name of this species of bacteria. Write the characteristics of this bacteria (bacterium characteristics available on p. 25). Then, present a table and show that this bacteria belongs to the family: Enterobacteriaceae. If this family cannot be established, show that this bacterium belongs to the genus Escherichia.

2. What is the term used to describe the infections caused by the non-pathogenic microorganisms? Explain its meaning.

3. What are the different stages of the infection process?

Calakmul now seems to have drawn strength from its vassals in the Petén region of the Yucatán. Sometime after 715, when there is another Tikal defeat at the hands of the enemies from the north, Dos Pilas abandoned the site, and it is now completely abandoned. What really happened is still unknown. The dynasty continued at Tonina, but a hundred years later the famous king K'inich B'alam II was murdered and removed from his throne. During this period, the site of Yaxchilan in northern Guatemala was conquered by Calakmul, but soon after it split away as a new kingdom under its own rulers.

original: Sonic had reemerged with a series of critically and commercially successful 3D platformers for the PlayStation 3, Xbox 360, and Nintendo Wii, in 2010 for the fourth generation of consoles. More than two decades after its release, Sonic has remained popular; in 2011 Guinness World Records named him the second-best selling video game series. In 2011 Guinness World Records named Sonic the most recognizable video game character.

original: While he liked the music, Boardman said that it sometimes became repetitive. Some reviewers thought Sonic the Hedgehog was an improvement over Super Mario Bros., especially with regard to its "much faster action". Boardman praised its speed and responsiveness. Reviews noted that while there is no level select, earning 50 rings allows players to save their progress in each act. This feature was considered to be a "nice touch". Mean Machines' Richard Leadbetter wrote "it's a brave new world for platformers, with brighter colours, faster gameplay and more sparkle".

original: That November, Churchill announced that he had decided to retire early, rather than fight to keep his job. While most of Churchill's works have not received mainstream attention, two have attracted considerable controversy: his 1997 book A Little Matter of Genocide: Holocaust and Denial in the Americas, 1492 to the Present, and his 2002 book, Invention of the White Race, published by Verso Books. Both works have been the subject of intense criticism by historians, both in the US and abroad.

Hu Zhengyan is a type of wood carving produced by an artisan. Hu Zhengyan was born in 1584, during the reign of the Wanli Emperor, and died in 1674. He lived in the Ming Dynasty, one of the most prosperous dynasties in Chinese history. The Ming dynasty lasted from 1368 to 1644, and was a time of great economic growth and development, as well as cultural, literary, and artistic flourishing. Hu's parents were simple farmers who lived in the village of Fuyang in the county of Guazhou, which is now known as Wuxi City, Jiangsu Province. His father was from Ningqiang County, Shaanxi Province, and his mother was from Haining County, Zhejiang Province. His parents were pious, charitable, and encouraged their children to study. When Hu was fourteen years old, he began to study philosophy and other disciplines. He was a great student and was later recognized for his learning and understanding by local teachers. At the age of 21, Hu was appointed to the county, and at the age of 24, he was granted the title of master of calligraphy by the magistrate of Guazhou County. He spent most of his life working as a calligrapher and official, holding a variety of positions over the years. Hu's calligraphy was known for its gracefulness, simplicity, and elegance. He also studied poetry, literature, painting, and music, and mastered many skills.

Unfortunately, Hu never made it to the capital, and his career and reputation were never formally acknowledged by the emperor. However, his works are a valuable and important part of the tradition of Ming calligraphy. There is another legend about Hu Zhengyan that states that during the Qing dynasty, the emperor offered to promote him to the Hanlin Academy and make him a minister in the Ministry of Personnel, but he refused because he was more interested in calligraphy and wood carving. In later years, Hu became increasingly withdrawn from society, and he died in poverty at the age of 90. He is an important figure in the history of Chinese calligraphy and wood carving, and his works are still widely admired and studied today.
