original: As with Kokusho, the pre-attack bombardment was extremely inaccurate, but their target was closer, so the battalion was undaunted. By 23:45, they were well into the assault, moving against the Marine right flank. After fierce fighting, they fell back toward the jungle. The following morning, Edson met with Marine commanders in the jungle and ordered them to "strike eastward through the swamps" and attempt to take the Japanese flank. His plan was to cause a "collapsing line of retreat" for Kawaguchi's men in the coming battle, as well as to prevent them from withdrawing to the south, where they could be resupplied by submarine. The plan was for Marine units to push into the swamp, then "burn bridges and blow craters" in front of them, while the 1st Raider Battalion "fought their way from 123" to support them. Once the eastward thrust was underway, the Raiders would turn eastward to take the Japanese flank, but they found it "difficult" to move against the defenders due to the dense brush. As their effort stalled, Colonel Watson ordered them to stay where they were. Meanwhile, Colonel Vidar Eriksen's 1st Battalion, 5th Marines, "attacked with bayonets" towards the river and the swamp to the east, against the 2nd Battalion, 4th Regiment, under Lieutenant Colonel Toshinari Shoji, and were nearly wiped out. On the ridge's left flank, the 3rd Battalion, 5th Marines fought off Japanese counterattacks. Meanwhile, Kawaguchi continued to reassemble his dispirited and battered troops. He moved Tamura's battalion to the ridge's left flank. With Eriksen's battalion effectively neutralized, the Japanese were able to push forward with their attack. Meanwhile, the 2nd Battalion, 4th Regiment was able to occupy the ridge's left flank, at Hill 35. During the early morning hours of 14 September, the 4th Regiment's 2nd Battalion attacked against the right flank of Company C, 1st Raider Battalion, from the east, and made slow progress. As the morning wore on, they renewed their assault, employing flamethrowers and demolitions. They pushed Company C back off Hill 80, taking many prisoners. By the end of the day, Kawaguchi had lost 500 men, while the Raiders had suffered 95 casualties. [7] At about 06:00, the Japanese again attacked Eriksen's 1st Battalion, and again came close to wiping them out. By 09:00, the Japanese had assembled their troops for a massive assault on the ridge. First Lieutenant Elmer Pope, who was to take command of Company C, 1st Raider Battalion, after Captain Gerald C. Thomas' wounding, decided to "sweep" some of his men around to the ridge's left flank, where they "took most of the Japanese force in the rear". At around 09:30, the Japanese began their "biggest" attack of the battle. On the ridge's left flank, Kawaguchi's force had drawn back to Hills 35 and 3, just to the east of the ridge. Here they were able to occupy Hill 3, while repulsing Marine counterattacks from Hill 35, and attempting to take the ridge's western edge, at Hill 1. The Japanese battalion was supported by four tanks that got "within 50 yards of the U.S. perimeter". The tanks' movements were slowed by poor roads and a lack of fuel. The battalion was broken up and driven back after suffering heavy casualties in what a Japanese officer described as a "deluge" of Marine machine-gun fire. While the battle raged on the left flank, Tamura's battalion attacked the ridge's right flank, sending a reconnaissance party against Hill 80. The main body of the battalion attempted to cut the ridge from the east and from the north, using a route through the swamp. The battalion was repeatedly repulsed by Marine artillery and naval gunfire, and was finally broken up and driven back by Company B, 1st Raider Battalion. During the assault on Hill 80, Tamura was killed by machine-gun fire. His replacement, Major Hidehiko Ishigaki, was wounded early in his command and was carried off the field. By this point, the attackers' numbers had been depleted to around 150 men. The 1st Battalion, 5th Marines continued to withstand heavy Japanese attacks against the northwestern portion of the ridge until nightfall. At this point, the Raiders and Marines undertook a "concentrated counterattack", sending their troops into the swamp east of the ridge, following which the Japanese attacked with artillery and tanks. The Japanese, who had failed to occupy Hill 1, slipped south into the jungle, leaving an estimated 1,500 dead. The battle had been lost for them, and Kawaguchi ordered the withdrawal of his remaining troops. The small unit of reconnaissance men on Hill 80 remained until 15 September, fighting on until it was reinforced and could finally hold out until 16 September. The 1st Battalion, 5th Marines, had also been "virtually annihilated", suffering 240 casualties. Other losses had been 195 men and 30 Marine aircraft. [8] The fighting at Bloody Ridge, or "The Slot", as the Guadalcanal campaigns were known to Marines, was over. Over a period of 26 days, in vicious close-range combat in thick jungle and dense undergrowth, the Japanese had lost an estimated 1,500 men, and the Marine dead numbered 621. On the 15th, the Marines relieved the battered Raiders and began a slow process of digging in to begin the campaign for the long term occupation of the island. General Vandegrift remained on the island to oversee the buildup, promotion, and training of his understrength division to meet the inevitable Japanese attacks, while the Raiders were withdrawn to Tulagi for rehabilitation and reorganization. General Vandegrift was later to tell his Marines, "I am a Soldier. I serve the American people. I do not serve any political party or faction." [1] Analysis In 1943, in the aftermath of Guadalcanal, Colonel Ira C. Eaker, who later became an Allied air commander during World War II, attributed the "lack of success" on Guadalcanal to American public opinion. He noted the public's "growing distaste" for the campaign, which reflected "shoddy" reporting by the American press. While some of the reporting by the American news media on Guadalcanal was fair, much of it was inaccurate. Japanese accounts of the battle tend to minimize the magnitude of the losses of men and equipment. According to the Official Japanese History of the War, 317 soldiers died in the "slaughter" and 368 were wounded. Twenty-one of their dead were supposedly identified and returned to their units. While some sources estimate that the Japanese suffered 1,500 casualties in the battle, the official Japanese count is 2,323, with another 742 killed in the submarine attack. With a total of 3,065 Japanese

original: Adron Doran, born in 1919, former Mississippi State President, 1966-1971; he was president of the College of Wooster in Ohio. Jimmy Rodgers died in 1933 and was buried in Meridian. During World War II, the federal government took over the town's ice plant and turned it into a site that produced the top-secret ingredients needed for the Manhattan Project. Meridian was home to one of the Tuskegee Airmen's primary training bases during World War II, also called the Tuskegee Syphers (after the local community leader), officially Gunter Field. It is now known as Key Field. During the war, the largest troopship ever built was launched at the Meridian Naval Shipyard. The Jefferson Street Yards, located in north Meridian, were the largest employer of African Americans in the South. The yards were run by the Southern Railway. In 1939, Tupelo was chosen by Walt Disney as the setting for his film Song of the South. One year earlier, in 1938, Meridian was chosen as the site for one of the finest hotels in the South, the Edgewood. In 1946, Meridian-born Sidney Lanier (not to be confused with the poet of the same name) became the first African American to play major league baseball in the American League. Lanier's uncle was the famed scholar and civil rights leader Dr. T. R. M. Howard. In 1950, Mississippi's first African American television station, WJMM-TV, came on the air in Meridian. WJMM broadcast from an unassuming studio on Washington Street and was originally affiliated with the National Negro Network. In 1951, the city constructed its first school for African American students since Reconstruction, A. E. Woodard High School. Two years later, Meridian played an important role in desegregating public schools throughout the state. After the U.S. Supreme Court ruled in Brown v. Board of Education that segregation of public schools was unconstitutional, the Meridian Public Schools Board of Trustees voted to adhere to the ruling and integrate the city's public schools. The board's decision had significant ramifications because, as the state's second-largest city, Meridian was seen as a testing ground for the rest of the state. Integration occurred peacefully in Meridian and on July 20, 1960, Woodard High School was integrated when the 6th and 9th grades began with a white and African American class. Woodard High School was renamed John H. Lewis High School. In 1952, Meridian gained its first African American physician, Dr. Marcus McClain. When Dr. McClain began practicing, there were only four African American physicians in the entire state. In 1954, the city's first African American hospital opened on 25th Avenue, the Good Samaritan Hospital. Dr. Marc McCains surgery for cancer of the pancreas was performed on John Wayne (of his legs) in 1966. The operation was the first of its type and was filmed for a news segment of the Mike Douglas Show. Over the next two years, Good Samaritan Hospital became the site of several other surgical firsts. When Dr. McClain retired in 1978, his niece, Dr. Sharon McClain, became the only African American woman doctor in the city and the surrounding area. On August 20, 2003, Dr. McClain celebrated 50 years of medical practice in Meridian. In 1957, John B. McLendon, the first African American basketball coach, was hired by the newly formed segregationist (white) Meridian Bears. The team's first coach was rumored to be Robert "Bob" Johnson. The Bears won the national title in 1962. In 1972, the NBA's Houston Rockets purchased the team, moving them to Texas and renaming them the Rockets. During the 1960s and 1970s, Meridian was the site of numerous civil rights marches and other demonstrations. The Mississippi Freedom Democratic Party convention was held in Meridian in 1964. Other events included the campaign for voter registration and literacy tests for African Americans by SNCC and CORE. The city's key leaders included activist Henry (Hank) Gamble, a leader in the civil rights movement in the city. He was involved in all facets of the movement, including sit-ins, the voter registration campaigns, and countless other activities. He was one of the first African Americans to be appointed to the city's Planning Commission and was one of the founders of the local NAACP chapter. He organized Freedom Schools and Voter Education Projects and was involved in the successful effort to bring racial desegregation to the city's public schools. In 1988, he was instrumental in the establishment of the Meridian African-American Heritage Association (MAHA). The organization's primary purpose was to erect an accurate historical marker at the location of the Woolworth store where Gamble and other protesters were arrested for staging a sit-in. During the summer of 1964, Meridian was the site of the murders of three civil rights workers, James Chaney, Andrew Goodman, and Michael Schwerner, who were accused of violating a segregation ordinance and of inciting a riot. One of the men, Jimmy Lee Jackson, had died while being transported from a nearby county to Meridian, where it was expected he would be tried. In 1989, the remains of three young civil rights workers were discovered in an earthen dam in Neshoba County. After a lengthy investigation, 18 men were indicted for the crime. By 2005, seven of the defendants were indicted in federal court for civil rights violations, while three others were tried in state court on a charge of conspiracy to deprive civil rights. All seven were found guilty by the federal court, and the Neshoba County defendants were found guilty of manslaughter.

By 2005, seven of the defendants were indicted in federal court for civil rights violations, while three others were tried in state court on a charge of conspiracy to deprive civil rights. All seven were found guilty by the federal court, and the Neshoba County defendants were found guilty of manslaughter.

The Boers were determined to continue fighting, but with increasing casualties and diminishing resources they became increasingly reliant on guerrilla tactics. As a result, those Boers who fought alongside de Wet and de la Rey remained out of contact with the regular forces for long periods, while smaller groups would operate independently, and it became difficult to effectively plan attacks. A lack of control was exemplified at the Battle of Groenkloof, where a force under Christian de Wet attacked a railway station defended by the 4th (Rockhampton) Queensland Imperial Bushmen. The Boers were repulsed but claimed they had taken 200 prisoners. De Wet's force turned out to be a number of local commandos led by a number of Boer commanders, including Jochem de la Rey, Jan Smuts, Fouché and the brothers Hendrik and Nicolaas Willem Kotzé. In early August 1900, Louis Botha, the Transvaal president, moved to Pretoria to hold a last meeting of the Transvaal Volksraad. On 27 September 1900, Botha led 3,000 Boers in an attempt to escape to the Portuguese territory of Mozambique. However the commando was spotted by British scouts in the Drakensberg Mountains. Botha surrendered to General Piet Cronjé, who refused to hand him over, and allowed him to escape. Botha, with his wife and a few companions, crossed into Mozambique.

“Fiction in terms of inanimate objects has been the preferred route of describing myself” is an important quote by photographer Diane Arbus. Arbus is an American photographer who is famous for her portraits, in which her subjects usually come from the fringes of society such as dwarfs, nudists, twins, giants, transgender people and people with developmental disabilities. According to Arbus’s definition, what does “fictions” mean?

(There are three works of art I want you to discuss. It’s important to complete these questions in the order they are given.)

A) John Stezaker’s “a man and a woman”: John Stezaker is a British collage artist. In 1982, he made a series of 80 collages in which he spliced images from two different postcards to create new pictures, such as the above one. For this series, Stezaker combines the narrative of a British film poster with the Romantic image of a young woman. In the story behind the poster, this young woman is a British actress named Celia Johnson, and the man with her is an actor. The collage seems to be referring to the end of their love story, but it’s more about the love of Celia for her husband, because the young woman in the story is dying. Here, Stezaker uses Celia to create a romantic image. We can infer that Stezaker’s collage is more like a reinterpretation of the work that is already there.  What role does John Stezaker’s collage play in telling the story of the man and the woman? What kind of emotions does the collage bring to us?

B) Diane Arbus’s “Jennie (Centerfold),” 1969: Diana is a famous photographer.  She shot a series of 36 polaroid photos in 1969 to document the process of photo shoots for Playboy magazines. This work was then sold to Playboy magazines, and some photos were selected for publicity. Jennie (Centerfold), which is one of the photos shot, has captured the sensuality of centerfold models.  What does the photo mean? What kind of emotions does it bring to you? Why do you think this photo can better convey the meaning of the photo shoot?

C) Imogen Cunningham’s “Water Drops on a Blossom” 1908: Imogen Cunningham is an American photographer. She is considered one of the pioneers of portrait photography and the portrait of female nudes. Her subject matter includes landscapes, close-ups of nature, figures and architectural studies. In this photo, you can see the picture that was taken in 1908, which is called “water droplets on a petal”, by looking at the title, it can be seen that the picture is close-up, and the picture is the front view of a petal. What kind of photographic techniques do you think the photographer used when taking this photo? How do you explain this work? How does this work communicate meaning? Why did Cunningham take this photo? Why do you think Cunningham was interested in this work?

D) In this question, I want to help you solve the problem of style.

A) John Stezaker’s “a man and a woman” is a collage. The origin of the collage is in the mixed collage of Cubism. Cubism is a new trend that breaks with impressionism in the beginning of the 20th century, it breaks the traditional painting, and creates the characteristic of collage. Picasso is one of the founders of cubism. In the early days of his work, his collages were all very messy, and he did not leave a complete picture. And a man and a woman is a different approach to collage than that of Picasso. He started with the figures on the British poster, and began to use the romantic image of the young woman on the other poster, and then integrated the two together to make a collage that has a complete image. What is the role of Cubism in art history? Why do you think it is important for artists today?

B) “Jennie (Centerfold),” 1969 is a medium-sized photo shot by Diana Arbus. Diana’s technique is to move close to the subject, then the subject is small and the texture is vivid. Diana Arbus is a pioneer of American photography. Her works express a dark world, challenge the ordinary and standard vision of human beings.  In this photo, the centerfold models, because of the small size of the photo and the standard format of the photo, seems to have been oppressed by the photographer’s feelings of arrogance and disdain. What is the importance of photo size? Why do you think Diana is using small sizes to capture this photo? How do you feel about Diana Arbus’s attitude towards this photo?

C) “Water Drops on a Blossom” 1908 is also a photo, the technique is close-up. However, this is a close-up that Imogen Cunningham has not taken in her life. Because the photo is too beautiful, Imogen Cunningham’s close-up will become a classic. When we talk about the essence

After leading 17 laps, he finished third behind winners Earnhardt and Bill Elliott. The rest of the season would see consistent finishes and a pair of sixth-place finishes at Dover and Martinsville.

After a pair of sixth-place finishes at Dover and Martinsville, Richmond had five Top 10 finishes in the last nine races of the season, finishing the year 8th in points. The season proved a turning point in Richmond's career as a contending driver. In 1987, he won twice. Richmond's first victory of the season came at the Charlotte Coca-Cola 600 on Memorial Day weekend. He had taken the lead from Bill Elliott on a restart with 17 laps to go, and won by 1.54 seconds over Elliott. The next week at Dover, Richmond led 77 laps and earned his second victory of the season. In July, he dominated the Pepsi Firecracker 400 at Daytona. After a poor qualifying effort in which he started 24th, Richmond battled with Earnhardt and the two traded the lead. He won his second pole of the year at Pocono, and finished the season with eight Top 5s and 16 Top 10s, finishing sixth in points. In 1988, Richmond started the season by winning the pole position for the Daytona 500. He led three laps before mechanical problems caused him to finish 31st. Richmond had three runner-up finishes that year at Darlington, Charlotte, and Dover. He also had six Top 5 finishes, and 17 Top 10s. He ended the season 6th in points.

In 1989, Richmond won the pole position for the Daytona 500, but would not run the race because of a broken bone in his ankle. Richmond was again a consistent finisher, and won the pole position for the Budweiser 500 at Dover and the Miller High Life 500 at Pocono. He had five Top 5s and 16 Top 10s, and finished 8th in points. During 1989, he married Amber Dykes on August 11, 1989 at the Jekyll Island Club Hotel. Richmond had his best season to that point in 1990. He won his first race of the season at Dover. He won his 16th career race at Michigan International Speedway. It was the first race in the track's history to go the distance without a caution flag, a fact that Richmond had learned from his crew chief, Scott Kelley. He battled Darrell Waltrip and Bill Elliott for the win. Elliott passed Waltrip for the lead with 11 laps to go, but was caught by a caution for a spin by Rick Wilson on lap 198. Richmond passed Elliott with 10 laps to go, but Waltrip was also on the lead lap and charged to pass both Richmond and Elliott. When Waltrip passed Elliott, Elliott made a tap to his car, and Waltrip bounced off of the wall. On the restart, Waltrip blocked Elliott's race-winning attempt at the white flag, allowing Richmond to take the victory. He had 14 Top 10 finishes, and finished fourth in points. In 1991, Richmond's season started with an eighth-place finish in the Daytona 500. He had 13 Top 10 finishes, and a third-place finish in the season finale at Atlanta. He finished the season 10th in points. Richmond's 1992 season was his last full season with Hendrick Motorsports. He finished a career best third in points, with six Top 5s and 17 Top 10 finishes. In 1993, he had six Top 10 finishes. He finished 17th in points after a 31st-place finish at Martinsville where he and Davey Allison collided with each other on the last lap. The end of the 1993 season also marked the end of Richmond's run at Hendrick Motorsports. He had finished in the Top 10 in points four times in the last five seasons, and had been an every week contender. He had earned nearly $9 million in the last five seasons, and was regarded as one of the best short-track drivers in NASCAR, leading 187 laps at Martinsville in the last five seasons. He scored 36 Top 5 finishes, 74 Top 10s, and won a race at Dover, Michigan, and Pocono. He had competed in 263 races for Hendrick Motorsports, with 21 Top 5s, 73 Top 10s, 13 poles, and 3 victories.

The story follows James Bond (Pierce Brosnan) as he learns of a plot by North Korean colonel, Moon (Will Yun Lee), to hold the world to ransom with an electromagnetic pulse bomb. The film features Rosamund Pike as Miranda Frost, Toby Stephens as Gustav Graves, Rick Yune as Zao, Halle Berry as Giacinta “Jinx” Johnson, and Judi Dench as M.

New Yorker Harry Grub (Elliott Gould), a hapless puppeteer, and his wife Benita (Jane Fonda), a call-girl, go to a darkened peep show in Greenwich Village where a woman peels a banana. Benita has sex with the banana and turns into a banana. To find out if Benita was really a banana, Harry bites her. He then goes to a palm reader, who tells him he is going to meet a woman called Sam, who will be his wife. He meets Sam, and falls in love with her, but she doesn’t like his vulgar friends. Eventually he realises that she is in fact the peeling banana.

50. The balance of £1,156.50 was donated by interested friends. Work completed in 1984 included making the clamps for the stocks and grinding and levelling the pitch pine sails bars. There are several examples of brigs still turning in Suffolk. One of these mills is at Hundon, where the sails are in quite good condition but have been reduced in number. Two other mills at Winston and Nedging are in a state of decay. The last surviving mill of this type was the Unthank Mill at Hinderclay which worked until 1994. This mill retained the four sails on a 40 ft (12 m) drum of elm timber and had the drum balanced by a wooden spur or counter- weight on the opposite side. A picture of this mill may be seen at Chelsworth. More generally, this is the form of mill which gave rise to the name windmill for a number of mills in Norfolk and some parts of Suffolk.

It was decided that the new sails would be identical, at the larger pitch. Four long whips were cut from a baulk of pitch pine obtained from a demolished maltings at Bury St Edmunds. The whips are square at their inner end. Sail bars and uplongs were made from modern pitch pine, selected for quality. The mortices for the sail bars were cut. That at the heel of the sail being at 27° and that at the tip being 15°, decreasing by 1½° at each sail bar. Three of the four sails had been completed at the end of the work in. The fantail and associated gearing was fitted to the mill. At the end of the second work-in, the cap could be turned by means of the hand crank. The fantail itself, with the blades painted red, white and blue was installed shortly afterwards. The clasp arm brake wheel was assembled around the windshaft. It was found that the wallower was eccentric on the upright shaft by ½ inch (13 mm). When this was corrected the brake wheel was within 1/16 th of an inch (less than 1 mm) of true. The clamps for the stocks were sawn from a baulk of pitch pine ready for completion later in the year. Other work included a new frame for one of the ground floor doors, cleaning and painting ironwork and further repointing on the brickwork. The four sails were fitted to the mill with the aid of a mobile crane at the end of the second work-in. The stock, with one sail attached was carefully inserted through the poll end of the windshaft and when wedged in position and the clamps had been attached the second sail was fitted to the stock. The process was repeated for the second pair of sails. The mill turned by wind again on the last day of the second work-in. Work later in the year included the finishing of the fourth sail, balancing the fantail and sorting out teething troubles with the fantail gearing. The brake and brake lever were made and installed and shutter cranks for the sails were cast. Restoration work in 1984 cost £2,918. Grants received were £1,209 from English Heritage, £500 from St Edmundsbury Borough Council, Other donations amounted to £52.50. The balance of £1,156.50 was donated by interested friends. Work completed in 1984 included making the clamps for the stocks and grinding and levelling the pitch pine sails bars. There are several examples of brigs still turning in Suffolk. The last surviving mill of this type was the Unthank Mill at Hinderclay which worked until 1994. This mill retained the four sails on a 40 ft (12 m) drum of elm timber and had the drum balanced by a wooden spur or counter- weight on the opposite side. A picture of this mill may be seen at Chelsworth. More generally, this is the form of mill which gave rise to the name windmill for a number of mills in Norfolk and some parts of Suffolk.

Six hours later, Beatriz strengthened into a category hurricane while in an environment characterized by moderate wind shear and low-to-moderate sea surface temperatures. During that time, the Hurricane Hunters reported winds of over mph (185 km/h; 110 kn) on top of the eyewall. A minimum pressure of was observed during that time as well. However, on that same day, the inner core of the hurricane became elongated, with the eyewall being replaced by a circular wind field. Convection was also seen as being disheveled with only isolated thunderstorms remaining within the central dense overcast. As a result of the inner-core erosion, Beatriz rapidly weakened. On June 22, the circulation of Beatriz was no longer well defined, with tropical storm force winds extending as far north as Punta San Telmo. While tracking along a northwesterly path, the system drifted west-northwest for about 16 hours. Beatriz then began to curve east-northeast, emerging into the southwestern Gulf of California. By 2100 UTC on June 22, convection was again becoming more organized around the center, prompting the Hurricane Center to declare that Beatriz had re-developed a small circular eye and reintensified into a hurricane. Two hours later, Beatriz struck the southwestern Mexican coast near the city of Escuinapa. On the following day, the hurricane gradually weakened while turning westward due to a trough over the United States. On June 23 at 1200 UTC, Beatriz weakened back into a tropical storm, as deep convection waned. About 12 hours later, Beatriz made landfall along the coast of Sinaloa about 20 miles (32 km) southeast of Mazatlán. The storm rapidly weakened after landfall, and the National Hurricane Center issued the final advisory at 2100 UTC on June 23, with the storm located inland about 10 mi (15 km) north of Mazatlán. The remains of Beatriz are then expected to continue moving northwestward and will likely dissipate over the Sonora Desert.

Against the BC Lions in the Western Semi-Final, McCarty had a 21-yard reception and also played on the special teams. In the Western Final, McCarty made a 13-yard catch and was also on the special teams, including kickoff coverage. On February 14, 2012, McCarty re-signed with the Eskimos on a one-year contract. After three years with the Eskimos, McCarty signed a three-year contract with the Ottawa Redblacks as a free agent on January 29, 2014. He was released by the Redblacks on March 11, 2016.

After working for almost four years with Donald Trump, Michael Cohen appeared before a grand jury to testify.

Further aid to the northern army was also blocked by the British capture of Savannah, Georgia, in December 1778. During the summer of 1779, Lieutenant Colonel Archibald Campbell successfully besieged and captured Savannah, Georgia, in December 1778. As the British prepared to attack Charleston in 1779, the French under General Jean-Baptiste Donatien de Vimeur, comte de Rochambeau, were on their way to help, sailing from Boston and landing in Rhode Island in June. The British Army troops embarked from Savannah in February and arrived at Charleston on March 9, 1779. The British forces ashore were strengthened by 2,200 sailors and Royal Marines. The British blockade of Charleston began on March 29, 1779. In April, Governor John Rutledge convened a council of war and received a negative vote on any proposal to send out a fleet to rescue the Savannah garrison. Rutledge asked for additional powers from the South Carolina General Assembly. This call was rejected and Rutledge was forced to resign. He was replaced by Rawlins Lowndes, who voted in favor of a naval action, but who was outvoted by the council. The council appointed Benjamin Lincoln as commander of the Charleston defenses, and the militia force was raised to more than 1,500.

Source: wikipedia

In 1859 control of Australian naval defence was given to a Naval Officer in Charge of the Coast of New South Wales based at Sydney, but in 1865 responsibility for the coast defences of all the Australian colonies was taken over by the British Admiralty. There were, however, only two coastal forts in the colonies with guns large enough to fire at a vessel on the high seas. At the turn of the century the navy's responsibility was passed to the Colonial Naval Defence Act, and control was passed to a Royal Navy Officer commanding in Australia. The development of the Navy as a national institution was hindered by political and economic circumstances that prevented a large and permanent presence. The Second World War was the first in which Australia conducted an independent defence effort. During the war Australian naval, army and air force forces served in all areas of military conflict and were engaged in almost every theatre of war. At home, some 102,000 soldiers from the Royal Australian Army, 40,000 from the Royal Australian Air Force and 4,400 from the Royal Australian Navy, were killed during the Second World War and nearly 33,000 wounded. Australia, with the United Kingdom, France and the United States, was one of the first countries to declare war on Japan on 8 December 1941. Australia then played a major role in the campaign in South East Asia, providing forces in New Guinea and the Pacific Islands as well as making a significant contribution to the Normandy campaign in Western Europe. The allies' massive bombing raids in Europe were paid for with Australian money. Australia was subject to air raids from Japanese forces, initially on Darwin and later on most major cities. In 1942 and 1943, Japanese submarines operating out of Singapore regularly struck at ships in the Australian harbours of Sydney and Melbourne and attacked troops and supplies at ports in northern Australia. Although there were a number of engagements and actions between the two forces, Australia was never invaded.

Australia was colonized by the British in the late eighteenth century, and it remained a British colony until 1901. Since its independence, Australia has undergone a period of remarkable growth and development. Today, it is one of the world's most prosperous and advanced nations.

Despite its vastness, Australia is home to just over 24 million people, making it the sixth most populous country in the world. The majority of these people live in urban areas, and the largest city, Sydney, is home to over 5 million people. Australia is also known for its natural beauty, with its stunning beaches, vast deserts, and pristine forests.

Thanks to its commitment to education and innovation, Australia is home to some of the world's leading universities and research institutions. It is also a leader in the fields of science and technology, with a strong focus on renewable energy and sustainable development.

Australia is also a major player on the global stage, with strong diplomatic and military ties to the United States and other allied countries. It is also a member of the United Nations and other international organizations, and it plays an important role in promoting peace and security in the region.

Overall, Australia has come a long way since its colonial days, and it is now a thriving and prosperous nation that continues to make significant contributions to the world.

The first stock was the one for Patent sails and this was made during the first week of the first work-in. The fantail stocks were made during the second week of the first work-in, but the sails were not started because of the inclement weather at the beginning of the second work-in. The two great spur wheels were dismantled to check that the stone nuts were properly fitted, and as they were they did not need attention. As the gear-train was being checked a small bronze pin came loose from the tail wheel, so it was decided to dismantle the tail wheel. When the tail wheel was taken down the bronze bearings on the upright shaft were found to be so badly worn that a substantial amount of iron had been lost. It was estimated that when the bearings had been complete they were so worn that the shaft had moved 1.5mm over 10 months.

Answers

In the Democratic primary, he again faced former governor Stanley, who had returned to the legislature and also challenged Governor Flem D. Sampson. Beckham and Stanley split the vote, and Stanley emerged the victor. Stanley won the Democratic nomination, and no Republican entered the race. Stanley was elected without opposition, and he became governor for the second time in December 1927. Beckham did not run for office again. Instead, he became president of the American Bar Association in 1928 and 1929, served on several corporate boards, and resumed his legal practice. Beckham was diagnosed with stomach cancer in 1934 and died on August 5, 1937. He was buried in the Cave Hill Cemetery in Louisville. http://www.britannica.com/EBchecked/topic/547601/William-Jefferson-Beckham-WJ-Beckham

0
5 months ago

Answer: The passage of the Seventeenth Amendment meant that the Senate would no longer be elected by the legislature but instead by popular vote. In the Democratic primary, Beckham defeated Augustus O. Stanley, a 12-year veteran of the House of Representatives. The Republican nominee was former Governor Augustus E. Willson. Bolstered by his support of President Woodrow Wilson, Beckham won the election by 32,000 votes. Beckham served as chairman of the Senate Committee on Expenditures in the US Department of Labor from 1915 to 1917 and on the Senate Committee on Military Affairs. In the latter position, he was influential in securing two large military training posts for Kentucky: Camp Zachary Taylor and Fort Knox. Though Camp Zachary Taylor was abandoned after World War I, Fort Knox became the home of the US Bullion Depository. After the United States entered World War I, Beckham continued to back Wilson and later supported the League of Nations. True to his prohibitionist stance, Beckham supported passage of the Eighteenth Amendment, which enacted Prohibition in the United States. The amendment was ratified and became effective in January 1920. Believing that women should be protected from involvement in politics, Beckham opposed the Nineteenth Amendment, which granted women's suffrage. The amendment failed on February 10, 1919 but passed on June 4, 1919. Beckham voted against it both times. The Democrats renominated Beckham without opposition in 1920. His opponent in the general election was Republican Richard P. Ernst. Prohibition had destroyed the distilling industry and the saloon business in the state, and in areas that those industries were prominent, Beckham received more than 5,000 fewer votes than Democratic presidential nominee James M. Cox. He was also hurt by the women's vote and by his support of Wilson, who had lost popularity since Beckham's election, in 1914. Ernst won the election by fewer than 5,000 votes, winning the race with 50.3% of the vote to Beckham's 49.7%. During his only term in the Senate, Beckham served alongside three other US Senators from Kentucky: Ollie M. James, George B. Martin, and Augustus O. Stanley. After his term in the Senate ended, Beckham resumed his legal practice in Louisville. He sought another term as governor in 1927. In the Democratic primary, he again faced former governor Stanley, who had returned to the legislature and also challenged Governor Flem D. Sampson. Beckham and Stanley split the vote, and Stanley emerged the victor. Stanley won the Democratic nomination, and no Republican entered the race. Stanley was elected without opposition, and he became governor for the second time in December 1927. Beckham did not run for office again. Instead, he became president of the American Bar Association in 1928 and 1929, served on several corporate boards, and resumed his legal practice. Beckham was diagnosed with stomach cancer in 1934 and died on August 5, 1937. He was buried in the Cave Hill Cemetery in Louisville. https://www.britannica.com/biography/William-Jefferson-Beckham-WJ-Beckham

In 1994, French and Italian mycologists Patrice Beauger and P. Bernardi reported the presence of a new species, M. inclinata var. major, in Borneo. The variety is characterized by having gills that are narrowly attached, yellowish-brown spore print, smaller spores (mean size 7.4 x 4.6 µm), and larger caps up to mm in diameter. The variety has also been reported from Australia. M. inclinata is a widespread saprobic fungus, and has been found in Europe, North Africa, Asia, Australasia, and North America, where it grows in small groups or tufts on fallen logs and stumps, especially of oak. British mycologist E.J.H. Corner has described two varieties of the mushroom from Borneo. Lookalike species with which M. inclinata may be confused include M. galericulata and M. maculata. First described as Agaricus inclinatus by Swedish mycologist Elias Magnus Fries in 1838, it was assigned its current name in 1872 by Lucien Quélet. Mycena galericulata var. calopus (named by Karsten in 1879), and its basionym Agaricus galericulatus var. calopus (named by Fries in 1873), are synonyms. In a molecular study of the large subunit ribosomal DNA sequences of mycorrhizal fungi of the orchid Gastrodia confusa, M. inclinata was found to be closely related to M. aurantiomarginata, M. crocata, and M. leaiana. The specific epithet inclinata means "bent in". In 1994, French and Italian mycologists Patrice Beauger and P. Bernardi reported the presence of a new species, M. inclinata var. major, in Borneo. The variety is characterized by having gills that are narrowly attached, yellowish-brown spore print, smaller spores (mean size 7.4 x 4.6 µm), and larger caps up to mm in diameter. The variety has also been reported from Australia. original: Elbert's base is quite rounded, indicating very slow erosion. The summit has excellent views of the rest of the Sawatch Range and its myriad peaks and valleys. The best times for climbing Elbert are the months of July through mid-October, though September and October are the most popular. In summer, the high country is dry and mild; thunderstorms develop rapidly and strong winds are common. Snow storms can occur anytime, and severe weather can rapidly come upon climbers even during the summertime. The winter season is very dangerous, with avalanches, wind chills of −40 °F (−40 °C), and often only a few hours of daylight.

The Shops at Station Park, north of Uptown, are under construction and the largest development project since the Uptown project began in 2001. Another major employer in the county is manufacturing, which employed 5,130 people in April 2010. In 2010, the Mississippi Development Authority named Meridian as a leader in green manufacturing. Military is another major industry, as Meridian Regional Airport is home to the headquarters of the 186th Air Refueling Wing of the Mississippi Air National Guard. The hospital is adjacent to Meridian Regional Medical Center and Rush Health Systems' Specialty Hospital of Meridian and the Mississippi State Hospital. In 2011, two newly constructed federal buildings opened: the Meridian Federal Building and the new United States Post Office. These replaced an older post office, a courthouse annex, and a courthouse that were all located across 7th Street and North. The Meridian Police Department headquarters was also constructed, designed by Crosby Pierce Architects in Hattiesburg, Mississippi. In 2008, the City of Meridian partnered with Mississippi State University and the East Mississippi Business Development Corporation to form the East Mississippi Innovation Center. The center is designed to house and nurture the startup of technology-based companies that are spun off from academic institutions. It houses several tenants, including an engineering firm, two software development companies, and a fiber optic-based broadband company, offering research space to scientists and engineers. It is also home to the NOVA Computer Learning Center. Meridian is served by two Mississippi state universities, a branch of the East Mississippi Community College, and a few private institutions. Meridian Community College offers two-year degrees and is accredited by the Southern Association of Colleges and Schools. Mississippi University for Women's College of Business offers four-year and graduate degrees through its partnership with East Mississippi Community College. In 1994, Mississippi State University opened its first Mississippi campus, Mississippi State University – Meridian. Located at the former air base, the university offers a bachelor's degree in electrical engineering. Other colleges and universities that are located in or near Meridian include the University of Mississippi School of Pharmacy and Meridian Beauty College.

# Capture, Salpetriere

On the other hand, when an insane person regains his reason, it is very seldom that he admits it, not for want of conviction of it, but on account of the false or acquired opinions that he has formed, in consequence of a mind disordered for so long a period. Hence we find that, in respect of this passion of vanity, there is a natural agreement in our thoughts, which must be dependent on the conformity of the organs of the body. The power of comparison does not allow us to form two judgments at the same time. The same effect, or the absence of the same effect, must be produced on the imagination, whether by the conception of the external cause, or the idea of the external cause, when it is conceived as a principle of unity....... Thus we may be certain that, in the process of making their perception of their own insanity objective, they use all their reasoning powers in order to arrive at an understanding of the fact of their having been insane. As a result, they are able to produce a system of reasoning which is peculiar to them. They can no more doubt that their senses have not deceived them than they can doubt that their reason has not deceived them. And they can only be deceived by their senses, or their reason, inasmuch as their reason is the one reason which has produced the error. Thus they form a system of reasoning which is peculiar to them, and which is based on the belief that their insanity is the result of their reason, rather than on the opinion that it is a consequence of the external cause, or that it is the effect of the influence of external causes on their body.

The system of reasoning which is peculiar to an insane person is an effect of the reason which is the cause of the insanity. We should therefore understand that the reasoning of a person who is insane, is a combination of two elements. There is the external cause, or the influence of the external cause on the body, which is the cause of the disease, and there is the effect of the external cause on the body, which is the result of the external cause on the body. This effect, or the influence of the external cause on the body, is nothing but the effect of the external cause on the mind. This effect is the product of the mind, and it is the result of the mental reason. We should therefore understand that the reasoning of a person who is insane, is the effect of the reason which is the cause of the insanity. Therefore, the reasoning of a person who is insane is not a result of the external cause, but is the result of the reason which is the cause of the insanity.

Thus, the reasoning of a person who is insane is the effect of the reason which is the cause of the insanity, and is not a result of the external cause, but is the result of the reason which is the cause of the insanity. It is the effect of the reason which is the cause of the insanity, and is not the result of the external cause, but is the result of the reason which is the cause of the insanity. Thus, the reasoning of a person who is insane is not the result of the external cause, but is the result of the reason which is the cause of the insanity. Thus, the reasoning of a person who is insane is not the result of the external cause, but is the result of the reason which is the cause of the insanity.

## Memory, Perseverance

The persistence of the disorder of memory, which occurs in all cases of organic insanity, must be explained by the fact that the disease is due to the condition of the mind which is the cause of the disorder. This is clear, if we consider that the disorder is a result of a disturbance of the mind, which is the cause of the disease. It is this condition of the mind which is the cause of the disorder of memory. The persistence of this disorder must therefore be due to the persistence of the condition of the mind which is the cause of the disorder. This is what we call the persistence of the condition of the mind which is the cause of the disorder.

In the persistence of the disorder of memory, which is the result of a disturbance of the mind, the condition of the mind which is the cause of the disorder must be persistent. It is therefore persistent. This is what we call the persistence of the condition of the mind which is the cause of the disorder.

## Two-Sided Memory

The following case is particularly interesting. A young man was committed to the Hôtel Dieu, on account of his delirium. When he came to himself he did not remember anything of the events of the preceding night, but it was a quarter of an hour before he could recollect anything of the events which had occurred since the time of his first awakening. At the moment of his coming to himself he was in the midst of a crowd of persons, and he had only a vague recollection

original: Although reinforcements were subsequently sent from Australia, the war in the Sudan was essentially over: by the time the contingent returned to New South Wales in June, the last British forces had left the Sudan. An Indian Mutiny that broke out in 1857 resulted in the death of more than 10,000 British and Indian soldiers, with the Indian Army rendered largely useless as a result. As there was a British army in India, there was not a subsequent ground war in the region, but a smaller-scale naval campaign in the North Sea was initiated by the Russian Navy as a part of a plan for invasion. The British Baltic Fleet under Lord Michael of Berkeley, was assembled in the Mediterranean, but the Russians did not respond to the threat. For the next 20 years, the British focussed on colonial policing, particularly in Malaya and China. As there were no longer any Russian ships in the area, the fleet returned to England, arriving at Portsmouth on 5 October 1855. Later, the Australian Naval and Military Expeditionary Force was sent to suppress a rebellion that began in German New Guinea in 1914. The fleet took part in the bombardment of Tripoli in September 1855, but was withdrawn to Malta because of the threat of cholera. When news of the outbreak reached the British government, it was decided that all the troops would be brought home, and they departed Alexandria on 4 September. As the British Navy was the dominant naval force in the area, they used their ships to facilitate peace negotiations, to which the Russians agreed. As a result, in January 1856, the Treaty of Paris brought the Crimean War to a close. In May 1885, 46,000 British troops were sent to Egypt in response to a threat by Khartoum in the Sudan. This force was able to drive the rebels back, but General Sir Garnet Wolseley ordered a withdrawal, later to reinforce his argument that the expedition should not proceed. Lord Palmerston, the British Prime Minister at the time, ordered that a force be sent to Khartoum and reinforcements were sent from Britain. On 25 May, Captain George Warburton set out from his home at Kalka to determine the limits of the Barimah country. By 3 June, they had reached the River Shiwalik and were joined by a party of Punjabi Cavalry. During the Crimean War in 1854, a small detachment of Australian volunteers was sent to Turkey with the understanding that they would be under the control of British forces. However, in the chaos of the fighting in the Black Sea, they were unable to make contact with the British troops that they were sent to serve alongside. In response, the colonial forces were given a nominal position with the British force and were placed under the command of General Airey, who appointed Lieutenant Colin Mitchell as the second in command of the New South Wales contingent. From 4 September, the fighting around Sevastopol became intense and was spread out over a larger area than had been the case in the earlier months. Although the government expressed regret at this action, it did not affect their attitude towards the question of an Australian contingent in the Sudan. Their military activities were short-lived, and as was the case with the New Zealand troops, they spent most of their time in railway construction and guard duties. In 1879, the gunboat HMCS Protector was commissioned to suppress a rebellion by rebel Indigenous Australians in the Gulf of Carpentaria, but was unsuccessful in defeating the raiders. A British force was sent to Khartoum on 27 September 1885. Before the force could arrive, the city was captured by forces under the command of Muhammad Ahmad, leader of the rebellion and known as the Mahdi. The troops, under General Charles Gordon, held out in Khartoum for several months, but were unable to break out of the city and they were eventually killed. The British government was reluctant to send troops to rescue the city, but pressure from the news media led to a force being assembled and sent. This force was placed under the command of General Charles Wolseley, who was given the power to take command of any British troops in the area.

However, Harken gets an allergic reaction after a bee flies into his mouth and has to leave to inject himself with an EpiPen. The trio flee by foot, with Harken in pursuit. However, a message left by Kurt is shown on Rhonda's phone, causing Rhonda and Julia to find Harken and help him find the trio. War continued to be waged with the fall of the Naranjo ruler in 849, defeated by either Yich'aak B'alam or Yik'in Chan K'awiil, and the defeat of Calakmul by Caracol in 859. This was the last historical victory of Tikal's rivals. In 869, there was a failure of maize crop which led to widespread hunger and the collapse of dynasties in a number of Maya city-states. At Tikal, this seems to have been a factor in the disappearance of rulers at that time, but the city continued to be occupied after the 9th century. Following the collapse of central rule, the population at Tikal declined rapidly and the city entered a period of slow decline into a protohistoric period. Tikal was only loosely organized at this time with little evidence of state-level administration. Excavation of burials shows that during the Postclassic, Tikal may have been controlled by three different groups during three different time periods, the last group being the Kaqchikels, who migrated to the Lake Petén Itzá area in the 17th century, before they were driven out by the Kowoj, another group of the K'iche' Mayan people. The first Postclassic period began with the arrival of foreigners known as the Ch'ol Maya from Petén to the north. These people gradually took over the abandoned sites of the Classic Maya and built their own settlements. One of these, El Pilar, is close to Tikal but separated by a ridge. Little is known about the history of El Pilar. Early excavations produced more Maya pottery but no foreign objects, showing that El Pilar was established before the arrival of the Spanish and that its inhabitants had connections with the surrounding Classic Maya towns. The next group was the Kejache, a Ch'olti' Maya people. They used similar burials to their predecessors but also incorporated some Ch'olti' Maya items into the burials. By the time of the arrival of the Spanish in the 16th century, this area was ruled by the Kaqchikels.

The Ancient Maya City of Tikal, Guatemala
Demography, Economy and Society of the Maya
The Maya City of El Mirador

Tikal is in northern Guatemala. It is the largest of the Classic Maya sites. It dates back to 800 B.C. Tikal was built on the site of an earlier town of its kind in the area. But, the city that we know of today, was largely built during the Classical Maya period.

Tikal reached its height of power and influence from 400 to 900 AD. It covered around 60 square miles, with a population of 100,000 people. This ancient Maya city had palaces and temples of the "birdman" kings who ruled the area. You can still find the remnants of their rule today, scattered among the dense jungle surrounding the city.

Tikal's ruins lie on a dense forest in the middle of a jungle in the Petén region. It is difficult to reach, and dangerous at that. In the early 20th century, access was practically impossible due to the large presence of wild animals in the area. Today, access to the ancient city is regulated in order to protect the fragile environment. The grounds are located in a very dense rainforest, which makes it difficult to access the ruins without a tour guide.

As you visit the ruins, you can wander for hours through the complex of many buildings, temples, pyramids, and the grand plazas which are scattered around the ancient city.

Once you're here, you might encounter the howler monkeys which have a habit of startling tourists. You might even see a jaguar and even hear them in the jungle. The weather here is hot, humid and rains frequently. But, you will still find millions of tourists visiting Tikal each year.

There is a very high amount of rare species of plants and animals in this area, which has a tropical climate. In the forest of Tikal, one of the best-preserved rain forests in the world, there are over 320 species of birds and 220 species of trees.

There are also more than 50 species of mammals and over 70 reptile species found here, including the endangered peccary, a species of wild pig.

https://www.tikal.org/en/history/

In short, the ancient Maya civilization was built, mostly in the region of Mesoamerica, by indigenous people in the Pre-Columbian Americas. The Maya civilization developed in the area of southeastern Mexico and northern Central America. The Maya peoples lived in villages, cities, and polities that were influenced by the 8 Maya city states of El Mirador, Nakbe, Kaminaljuyu, Calakmul, Tikal, Copan, and Yaxchilán.

The Maya had complex art, architecture, astronomy, and mathematics. The Maya were famous for their use of the zero, which they used in their numbering system. This is the only known zero in all of pre-Columbian America. The Maya used the zero as a place-holder for values less than 1 in their complex calculations of numbers. They created the concept of a zero to use as a place-holder.

The Maya civilization had a writing system that utilized over 700 characters. It was an excellent system for recording information. Some of the records have been found to be important in reconstructing the Mayan history. Their calendar, also known as the Maya calendar, is still used today, especially for planning festivals and the celebration of religious rituals.

The Maya produced many monuments, especially to their gods. The monuments were mostly monuments to their king. The monuments have been important in helping to reconstruct the history of the Mayan civilization. The monuments were made of stone and were found on many Mayan buildings and monuments.

Tikal is one of the largest of the ancient Maya cities. It is located in Guatemala and was a major Maya site during the Classic Period (250 to 900 A.D.). Tikal has been designated a UNESCO World Heritage site and is home to one of the largest surviving Maya pyramids.

Tikal reached its height of power and influence from 200 to 800 A.D. The city was built on the site of an earlier town of its kind in the area. The site is part of the Tikal National Park and is open to the public for tours. The Tikal Museum houses some of the best-preserved ancient Maya artifacts. Tikal is located on the north side of the Peten Basin.

The city of Tikal is located on the north side of the Peten Basin, in the area known as the heart of the Maya Lowlands. The area is rich in limestone outcrops and many ancient Maya sites are in this area.

The ruins of the ancient Maya city of Tikal are located in the Maya Biosphere Reserve in Guatemala. The Tikal National Park covers an area of 378 square miles (

War continued to be waged with the fall of the Naranjo ruler in 849, defeated by either Yich'aak B'alam or Yik'in Chan K'awiil, and the defeat of Calakmul by Caracol in 859. This was the last historical victory of Tikal's rivals. In 869, there was a failure of maize crop which led to widespread hunger and the collapse of dynasties in a number of Maya city-states. At Tikal, this seems to have been a factor in the disappearance of rulers at that time, but the city continued to be occupied after the 9th century. Following the collapse of central rule, the population at Tikal declined rapidly and the city entered a period of slow decline into a protohistoric period. Tikal was only loosely organized at this time with little evidence of state-level administration. Excavation of burials shows that during the Postclassic, Tikal may have been controlled by three different groups during three different time periods, the last group being the Kaqchikels, who migrated to the Lake Petén Itzá area in the 17th century, before they were driven out by the Kowoj, another group of the K'iche' Mayan people. The first Postclassic period began with the arrival of foreigners known as the Ch'ol Maya from Petén to the north. These people gradually took over the abandoned sites of the Classic Maya and built their own settlements. One of these, El Pilar, is close to Tikal but separated by a ridge. Little is known about the history of El Pilar. Early excavations produced more Maya pottery but no foreign objects, showing that El Pilar was established before the arrival of the Spanish and that its inhabitants had connections with the surrounding Classic Maya towns. The next group was the Kejache, a Ch'olti' Maya people. They used similar burials to their predecessors but also incorporated some Ch'olti' Maya items into the burials. By the time of the arrival of the Spanish in the 16th century, this area was ruled by the Kaqchikels.

The episode was produced and aired as a compilation with the season two episode "The Secret Box", and aired on September 27, 2002 on Nickelodeon in the United States. In the episode, SpongeBob is told by Mrs. Puff to use sailor terms around the boating school, in order to instill discipline in him. SpongeBob initially resists the concept of sailor talk, but eventually warms up to it, and applies his newfound sailor jargon to everyday conversation. SpongeBob's actions result in trouble for both Mrs. Puff and Squidward, who are forced to speak in sailor talk after being accused of using language which was inappropriate for children. The episode's title refers to terms commonly used among sailors.

The song contains the phrases "there ain't no Jim Crow in Europe," and "New York City has no Jim Crow," leading many to believe that the song was written with New York City in mind. The song was included in 1958 on the album Lead Belly Sings for Children, as well as in the 1994 soundtrack to the movie Nobody's Fool.

His birth name is Huddie William Ledbetter. He was born in Mooringsport, Louisiana, on January 20, 1889. As an adult, he lived in the Deep South and worked various jobs as a farmer, a cowboy, and a field hand. His musical talents were recognized early in his life, and as a young man, he was exposed to many musical styles, including ragtime, cowboy, and gospel.

"Blythe was going up the stairs and he was actually holding his guitar on his chest, he was talking to the fans. He was standing there and was talking about how he loves his Czech fans. He was talking and he turned around and looked at Daniel," testified Vlach. Blythe, however, told Nosek that he had to get down from the stage. The band members were not dressed in their costumes and were visibly irritated, Vlach further noted. After the break, as the band returned to the stage, another fan from the crowd went on the stage and Blythe, using his guitar, hit the fan in the back. Nosek then tried to talk to Blythe, while Blythe waved him off. At that point, Nosek went to the side of the stage and tried to climb up again, and at that point Blythe gave Nosek a push and he fell off the stage. Vlach testified that Blythe seemed to have had enough energy to kick or punch Nosek, but there were two bodyguards on the stage and one of them was positioned next to Nosek. Nosek was wearing a white T-shirt, and when he fell, his T-shirt got wet in the front. They offered him assistance but he declined, and they called the ambulance. Vlach further testified that Nosek said that Blythe had pushed him after the concert. Vlach and another friend offered to drive him to hospital but Nosek decided to be driven by the ambulance and to cancel the appointment with the band members. He went into coma for four days, and spent three weeks in hospital. Nosek suffered from a brain injury and lost the ability to speak. On February 6, 2013, his father testified that his son was a huge fan of the band and had enjoyed concerts in the Czech Republic for the last seven years. He had never seen anything like this before, he said. Nosek's doctor testified that Nosek's was in a critical state with traumatic brain injury, and he needed to be transferred to a university hospital in Prague to undergo surgery. However, because of Nosek's initial condition, his chances of survival were at 30-50%. In spite of two surgeries, Nosek's condition did not improve. He was transferred to another hospital, and placed on a respirator. He became paralyzed on the right side of his body. The doctor further testified that Nosek is currently in a vegetative state, and may remain in that state for a while, although he is not brain dead. His prognosis, according to the doctor, is very poor. Nosek's mother also testified at the hearing. She said she was worried about Nosek because he was missing from home on February 1, and she was not able to contact him either by phone or by e-mail. They were both huge fans of the band and had seen them at several concerts in Prague. They went to all their concerts in Prague, even though it was a long way for Nosek's parents to go from the town in the mountains. When they heard the concert was being moved to O2 Arena, they decided to go for Nosek's 21st birthday. They went to the concert on February 1, 2013, because Nosek promised his parents that if he was not going to go to the show, they would have to take him to the concert and pick him up. They went to the concert with three friends of Nosek. Nosek had gone to the concert because he had heard that the band was going to do a secret gig at O2 Arena. Nosek had won a ticket for the show in an internet contest, and a chance to meet the band. Nosek's friend was sent to look for Nosek in the crowd during the concert. When he returned he reported that Nosek had a chance to take an autograph from the guitarist. Nosek's friend testified that he did not know whether Nosek would have the chance to take the autograph because the line was so long. After the show had started, a security guard came to Nosek and pushed him, and then he pushed two more people and then the concert had started. His friends tried to bring him out of the crowd. When they got into the elevator, Nosek started complaining about his head, and it took him a long time to get out of the elevator. His friends took him to the hospital, and left him there. Nosek's friend further testified that the security guards had been very aggressive. One of them pushed him twice, and they were very badly dressed. They had jeans, and they were too late. Nosek's friend further testified that a female fan had been raped by a security guard during the concert. He said that his parents had seen Blythe run away from the bodyguards. They got out of the elevator and went to the hotel, but then returned because they heard someone playing the guitar. When they returned, a security guard told them to sit on the floor. Nosek's friend said they wanted to get out of the crowd, and Nosek wanted to get his autograph. The security guard pushed him. The friend also denied any knowledge of any interaction with the band. He said the band had given them three bottles of Jack Daniels. Nosek's father, however, testified that they were not contacted by the band and they never met them. Nosek's father also said that his son had never been in a bar. The hearing has not been concluded at the time of writing. Lamb of God is alleged to be liable for damage caused to Nosek. The band denies the liability and argues that the fans' climbing up the stage was a violation of the contract, which resulted in injury to Nosek. They further argued that they had no way to predict the concert goers' behavior.

His manager claims that Nosek went into a state of epilepsy and became excited. The defense team further claimed that Nosek was a difficult and at times aggressive person. They claimed that he fought and pulled security guards with him during his fall. Blythe's lawyer said that Blythe was shocked to find a fan climbing on the stage with another fan. The defense argues that the band asked the fans to get down several times, but that they refused to do so. They claim that Nosek had previously been removed from another show and thrown into the crowd.

The Lamb of God's lawyers tried to convince the judge that Nosek climbed on the stage for the purpose of an autograph. The band denied any knowledge about Nosek. They also denied any knowledge about the security guard who had been accused of raping a fan. The defense team argued that the alleged rape was in contradiction with the contract.

The plaintiff claims that he never tried to climb on the stage in order to get an autograph from the band members. He said that Blythe had already given him an autograph before the show, and he never knew any members of the band. He denies any knowledge of the autographing line.

The defendant also claims that the plaintiff asked security guards to help him in order to climb on the stage. He denies any attempt of an autograph. He said that Blythe had never pushed him and that the alleged rape by a security guard never happened.

### Money is the root of all evil!

Money is the root of all evil!

As mentioned by Christian Bible (Timothy 6:10) and attributed to some Jewish sources, the real root of evil is not money, but desire for money. How can a person avoid that desire? Can a person avoid that desire? Does avoiding that desire help to reduce evil?

## Begin the last section of your body paragraph with the above introductory sentence. In the paragraph include some research into the cause of and reasons for embezzlement. You must quote at least 3 sources.

Embezzlement is the theft of assets by a person in a position of trust, typically by a company's officer or an employee. William Shakespeare's tragedy Macbeth features a fictional character of the same name, who is portrayed as a military general who gradually begins embezzling money from his masters. Macbeth had an insatiable desire to acquire wealth and power, which ultimately led to his downfall. Lord Acton's often quoted phrase, "Power tends to corrupt, and absolute power corrupts absolutely. Great men are almost always bad men," has become something of a cliche when speaking about people with significant power. A major difference between Macbeth and embezzlers in the modern day is that Macbeth didn't have any true control over his actions. He was manipulated into betraying his country and murdering his king through the use of trickery by his wife. The term "power corrupts" is often used to describe people with embezzlement charges. In Shakespeare's Macbeth, the theme of absolute power corrupting absolutely is represented in many ways, through Macbeth's greed for power, his own ambition, and the influence of his wife. The development of the theme of absolute power corrupting absolutely begins with Lady Macbeth's suggestion to Macbeth to kill Duncan in order to take his throne. Lady Macbeth, who is portrayed as a cold and calculating woman, begins to manipulate Macbeth and convince him that it is his duty to become king. The fact that he has to commit murder in order to do so does not seem to bother her. She even compares the murder of Duncan to something as simple as ridding oneself of an old and useless garment. From Lady Macbeth's first words to her husband in the play, we see that she is a woman who is willing to use any means necessary to get what she wants. She is portrayed as someone who is completely in control of her emotions and actions, even when she is confronted with the consequences of her decisions. Her use of the Bible as a justification for murder is a clever ploy to get her husband to do her bidding. As Macbeth's wife, she is used to getting what she wants from her husband, and she is not afraid to use whatever means necessary to get it. However, she is not the only one in the play who is willing to use power corrupting absolute language to get what she wants. As Macbeth's power increases, he begins to feel more and more invincible. He starts to think that he can do no wrong, and he becomes increasingly detached from reality. As his power increases, he becomes more and more isolated from the people around him. He begins to lose touch with what is right and what is wrong, and he begins to lose his humanity. This can be seen in the way that he treats the people who are close to him, such as his wife and his friends. The theme of absolute power corrupting absolutely is also represented in the way that Macbeth begins to see himself as a god. He becomes so confident in his own power that he begins to believe that he can do anything. This can be seen in the way that he begins to refer to himself as a king, and he begins to take on the characteristics of a king. He starts to think that he is above the law, and he begins to believe that he is invincible. The theme of absolute power corrupting absolutely is also represented in the way that Macbeth begins to lose his morality. original: In his book, Driven, Dr. Jerry Punch admits that he discussed the story with NASCAR's former Director of Racing Operations Gary Nelson in 1990. While both men knew details, they discussed the implications, and agreed that it would be a foolhardy decision to discuss the matter with the press. This was ultimately because NASCAR was uncomfortable with the subject, and Richmond had died within the year. The 1999 biography NASCAR: The Steel Green and Gold outlined the circumstances of Richmond's death. His family and close friends knew of his illness long before it was made public in August 1989, and were quite familiar with his prognosis. Despite a blood transfusion in March 1989, Richmond had been bedridden since the prior summer. The fatigue that led him to an earlier retirement from racing was due to his AIDS infection, and the doctors who had treated him never diagnosed him with multiple sclerosis as had been widely believed, despite that his physician stated that Richmond's family wanted him to have the multiple sclerosis diagnosis. "He'd always been a private person," said Jerry Punch. "It had been two years since he'd raced. He hadn't told anybody outside his close family and his friends in racing what was really wrong with him. That was why he wanted to be remembered as he was in the hospital, as the young handsome racer he was. That was what was important to Tim." Shortly after Richmond's death, the Salem News' Bob DeRosa named Richmond to its "Top 10 All-Time Athletes". This controversy ended after the rumor that Richmond had died from liver failure was made public. By 1991, several newspaper columnists accused the organization of keeping silent regarding Richmond's AIDS-related death, and writer James King stated that it would have made little difference if the truth had been made known earlier. He also blamed "the quiet self-imposed ban against AIDS" for a lack of national public recognition of Richmond's death, saying, "Tim Richmond's talent and personality deserved more than to be shunted to the back pages." Richmond's death received a relatively little amount of national press coverage at the time, while Michael Wagner Jr.'s death from AIDS-related causes in 1995 received much more media attention. Richmond has been honored on the 2004 NHRA season-ending Winternationals (first race of the 2004 NHRA Winston drag racing season) held at the Pomona Raceway with a "Tire by Fire" race in his memory. The race consisted of two cars racing around the raceway to promote the upcoming Indy 500 race. The goal of the race was to be the first car to cross the finish line. The winner received a million dollars and the losing car would explode. The two drivers were NASCAR drivers Tony Stewart and Jeff Gordon. The race had to be terminated as the two drivers both came to a complete stop in the same location. A large display at Bristol Motor Speedway celebrating Richmond's victory in the spring race in 1986 includes his 1985 Cup championship trophy and his suit that he wore during that 1986 victory. The suit was a gift from Terry Labonte.

"He'd always been a private person," said Jerry Punch. "It had been two years since he'd raced. He hadn't told anybody outside his close family and his friends in racing what was really wrong with him. That was why he wanted to be remembered as he was in the hospital, as the young handsome racer he was. That was what was important to Tim." Shortly after Richmond's death, the Salem News' Bob DeRosa named Richmond to its "Top 10 All-Time Athletes". This controversy ended after the rumor that Richmond had died from liver failure was made public. By 1991, several newspaper columnists accused the organization of keeping silent regarding Richmond's AIDS-related death, and writer James King stated that it would have made little difference if the truth had been made known earlier. He also blamed "the quiet self-imposed ban against AIDS" for a lack of national public recognition of Richmond's death, saying, "Tim Richmond's talent and personality deserved more than to be shunted to the back pages." Richmond's death received a relatively little amount of national press coverage at the time, while Michael Wagner Jr.'s death from AIDS-related causes in 1995 received much more media attention. Richmond has been honored on the 2004 NHRA season-ending Winternationals (first race of the 2004 NHRA Winston drag racing season) held at the Pomona Raceway with a "Tire by Fire" race in his memory. The race consisted of two cars racing around the raceway to promote the upcoming Indy 500 race. The goal of the race was to be the first car to cross the finish line. The winner received a million dollars and the losing car would explode. The two drivers were NASCAR drivers Tony Stewart and Jeff Gordon. The race had to be terminated as the two drivers both came to a complete stop in the same location. A large display at Bristol Motor Speedway celebrating Richmond's victory in the spring race in 1986 includes his 1985 Cup championship trophy and his suit that he wore during that 1986 victory. The suit was a gift from Terry Labonte.

original:
Australian troops had returned to South Africa as part of the Commonwealth contingent, replacing New Zealanders. In July the Boer commando leaders began a campaign of attrition against the British supply lines. On 25 July, troops from the Central Column, including 2nd and 3rd Australian Commonwealth Horse, formed part of the Anglo-Boer force that surprised and routed 300 Boers near Vet River. After a pursuit by the Mounted Rifles and Western Australians, the Boers were caught in a kraal at Holspruit, and nearly all were killed or captured. Later in July, a contingent of 200 Australians, including 2nd and 3rd Australian Commonwealth Horse, fought a skirmish near Vlakfontein where 80 to 100 Boers were killed. Although this was one of the last pitched battles of the war, the guerrilla war continued. In September, the Queensland Mounted Infantry left for home, while British forces reformed for further campaigning.
