original:
After their victory, the side travelled to the capital of Queensland, Ipswich, where they won the return match 14–8.

After their match against Queensland, the New Zealanders returned to Sydney. They played their final three rugby matches there, and each was closely fought. First they faced a selection of players who had played for the side on tour, then New South Wales, and finally Queensland. The team won all three, defeating the first side 11–5, the New South Wales selection 13–8, and the Queenslanders 17–11. These victories over their opponents from New South Wales and Queensland were representative of their dominant record over teams from those states throughout the tour. In all, the New Zealanders played 60 rugby matches on the tour, against teams from England, Ireland, Wales, Scotland, France, Canada and the British colonies of South Africa, New South Wales and Queensland, winning 49 and drawing one match. The only side they failed to beat were England – both of their games against the English saw them lose.

The tour began on a high, and on the final match of the tour a significant achievement was realised. At the time, international rugby unions were still officially independent, and one of the issues in the early years of the game was the issue of recognition. Before the 1888–89 tour of the British Isles, the only sides recognised as international sides were those from England, Scotland, Wales and Ireland. As a result, the Australian national team would not be considered by the four British and Irish unions as a proper international side until the first match between them and the first (1882) Australian team, played in 1899. However, many of the teams the New Zealanders faced during the tour of the British Isles were recognised sides. This was a rare example of the New Zealand team achieving recognition for the New Zealand Rugby Union by playing official matches against the recognised unions, and is thus considered the first New Zealand international rugby matches. The matches against Ireland and England were widely considered the most significant matches of the tour.

Even though the matches against England and Ireland were seen as significant, the matches against the English colony of South Africa were much more significant, as they were the first games between the two nations; before the 1891 tour of New Zealand, no formal matches had ever been played between South Africa and New Zealand. The most significant match of the tour was therefore the match against the touring South African team, but they only played them twice, and in both matches the Natives were defeated. The match of greatest significance to the South African team was the final one, and they were victorious in it; as a result, this match was the first between New Zealand and South Africa to be won by South Africa. Nevertheless, the tour of the British Isles was a great success for the New Zealand Rugby Union, and the side's tour of South Africa the following year, while much less successful, resulted in the New Zealand national side gaining official recognition from the South African Rugby Board.

The 1888–89 New Zealand Natives rugby tour of the British Isles and France was the first rugby tour undertaken by a New Zealand representative side. It was organised by a business syndicate consisting of mainly Māori businessmen and bankers and was intended to boost Māori tourism in the South Island. The team was not representative of the whole of New Zealand – several North Island players who had been selected failed to get leave from work or were injured – and instead consisted of Māori from the Canterbury and Wellington regions. The side played in both association and rugby football, but as the latter was the more established code in New Zealand at the time, the tour was an effective advertisement for it in Great Britain. The team won 49 of its 60 matches, lost only two (both to England) and drew one. During the tour, the side played official matches against all four of the recognised home nations, and as such, it has been considered the first international rugby matches ever played by New Zealand. As well as the matches against the four home nations, the New Zealanders played a team representing the British colony of South Africa; this was the first time either side had played each other. This tour was the most successful ever undertaken by a rugby side from outside of Great Britain, a record that would stand until the 1905 New Zealand rugby team's "Original All Blacks" tour.

Following a failed tour of Victoria, Australia, the Natives returned to New Zealand and their tour to South Africa. Despite their poor results against the South African sides on tour, the Natives beat them 9–3 in the first ever match between the two nations. The side travelled north, before heading back to New Zealand via Fiji, where they played rugby and association football matches, with the team again preferring the former. They returned to New Zealand in November 1889, and after leaving the island in early 1890, embarked upon the return voyage to Britain, where they arrived on 18 June, playing one more rugby match in London before beginning their return voyage on 22 June. They arrived in New Zealand on 16 July. The tour had generated over £1500 for the side, of which they kept £500 for the New Zealand Rugby Union and the rest they gave to their sponsors. After returning to New Zealand, they played several matches in both codes of football, and also a second tour of Australia, but after it was over the side was disbanded. The men who played in the tour received almost no compensation for their participation. In the coming years, the New Zealand national team would be officially designated as the All Blacks, although the first time they were officially called this was during the 1896 New Zealand rugby team tour of Australia.

Roger Moore of Chicago Tribune gave it three stars out of four and called it a "pristinely clean [game] with incredible speed and amazing animation". Kevin Gould of Electronic Games stated that Sonic "demonstrates an uncommon degree of originality and virtuosity". The game received mixed reviews. Mean Machines gave it 90% and praised the speed, controls and sound, but called the level design repetitive. John Lee of GamePro also commended the speed, calling Sonic a platforming hero, but criticized the controls, finding that jumping was difficult. Game Zero's Thomas Besch appreciated the controls and level design, but found the graphics and sound mediocre.

From the school, US 2 turns east to run concurrently with US 45 for the remainder of its trip through the UP. A few miles later, the highway joins M‑28 for the first time, again on the south side of Sunday Lake. US 2 splits from US 45 and the business loop of M‑28 and continues through a commercial district in the community of Land O'Lakes. The route forms the northern edge of the city limits of Watersmeet before passing through a stretch of private land and forest land that was inundated by the construction of the Island Lake Hydroelectric Plant and the Hodenpyle Reservoir.

original:
An expeditionary force, the 6th Division, was sent to the Middle East in 1940 and fought in the Western Desert and Syria. By the end of 1941 the German advance on Moscow had halted and the threat to the Middle East receded. This allowed the Australian government to replace the 6th Division with 9th Division at the front and the 7th Division in Australia for training. The Australians met with mixed success in combat in the Western Desert Campaign in 1940 and 1941. In 1941 the 7th Division was rushed to Greece and Crete where it again fought successfully against a better-equipped enemy. The loss of Crete was a severe blow to British prestige but did not weaken the Allied position in the Mediterranean. British forces managed to successfully repel the Afrika Korps' first push into Egypt at the Second Battle of El Alamein in October 1942, a campaign in which the Australians again distinguished themselves. Later in 1942 and 1943 Australian divisions saw heavy action in New Guinea. The 9th Division, returned from the Middle East, was sent to New Guinea in 1942 and participated in the fighting in the Kokoda Track campaign. At the Battle of Milne Bay the 3rd Division repelled the first attempted Japanese landing on Australian soil, an action which marked the limit of the Japanese advance south in New Guinea. The 7th Division was moved to New Guinea in March 1943 and fought at Wau. Both the 9th and 7th Divisions were withdrawn to Australia in 1943 and 1944 to be rested, and eventually re-equipped with modern weapons, artillery and armoured vehicles, before returning to the fighting in the Pacific. For their actions in the New Guinea campaign of 1942–1943, members of the 2/14th Battalion were awarded a total of five Victoria Crosses, four to individual soldiers and one to the battalion as a whole for its part in the Battle of Buna–Gona. From July to September 1942 the Australians also defended Port Moresby in New Guinea during the Battle of the Kokoda Track. The battle saw a Japanese invasion force struggle over the Owen Stanley Ranges to the Australian defensive line, then both sides to the town and finally up the Kokoda Track. The Australians repelled the Japanese attack, and inflicted high casualties on the invading force. The Australians attacked across the Owen Stanley Ranges in September 1942 to recapture Kokoda and a series of successful engagements followed, including Milne Bay, Buna–Gona, Wau, Finschhafen, and the Aitape–Wewak campaign. In September 1942 the Japanese made another attempt to reach Port Moresby, landing 5,000 troops in the Gona area. After landing at Milne Bay in August 1942, the 61st/73rd Infantry Battalion destroyed an advanced Japanese landing force. The Australians repulsed the Japanese at Kokoda in early October and forced them to retreat. The 21st Brigade re-entered Kokoda in November. The 3rd Division then advanced through the Finisterres, forcing the Japanese out of their jungle fortifications and back into the mountains. In June 1944 the 5th Division secured the remnants of the Japanese forces at Aitape on the northern coast of New Guinea. The 8th Division later moved against the remaining Japanese forces in the Hollandia area and in January 1945 the 5th Division defeated the enemy at Wewak, completing the clearing of northern New Guinea.

original:
He was selected in the first round by the Saskatchewan Roughriders. As the Roughriders' starting running back, McCarty had an impressive rookie season, rushing for over 1,100 yards and earning a selection to the CFL All-Rookie Team. In the 2007 West Division final, McCarty was held to only 17 yards on 13 carries, as the Roughriders lost the game to the Calgary Stampeders.

McCarty continued his success in 2008, gaining 1,322 rushing yards and seven touchdowns. He earned a spot on the West Division All-Star Team at running back and was the leading vote-getter at the position. In 2009, McCarty had his most productive season yet, breaking the Roughriders' single season rushing record with 1,587 yards. This was good enough for second place in the league, and earned McCarty his second selection to the West Division All-Star Team at running back. After playing only seven games in 2010 due to injury, McCarty suffered a broken leg in the 2011 CFL season opener against the Toronto Argonauts. The injury required surgery and ended his season after only 18 carries. His return to the Roughriders was an immediate success as he rushed for 112 yards in his first game back, and led the Roughriders to their third consecutive West Division title. McCarty had another strong season in 2012, helping Saskatchewan make it to the Grey Cup in both 2010 and 2013. He played five more seasons with Saskatchewan before signing with the Montreal Alouettes in 2017. After three seasons with the Als, McCarty signed with the BC Lions in 2020. His career was disrupted by COVID-19 restrictions, causing him to sit out the 2020 season. He finished his career with the Lions in 2021, gaining 274 rushing yards and two touchdowns in 14 games. McCarty was released by BC in February 2022, and announced his retirement from professional football in March of the same year.

McCarty is married to Nikki McCarty, who played in the National Lacrosse League. She helped form the sportswear brand, Nuun Active, which she runs with her husband.

Reference:

https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kory_McCarty

original:
The ships were expected to arrive in Rabaul by 4 September, at which time Kawaguchi's unit would be unloaded and turned into a motorized infantry unit with the addition of the available Japanese tanks. The ships would then be sent back to Guadalcanal with Kawaguchi's unit embarked. However, the ships carrying Kawaguchi's unit never arrived at Rabaul, because on 24 August, U.S. carrier planes sank five of the six transports on which the unit was carried. Although only 4,300 out of the 5,000 Japanese troops aboard the transports were rescued, Kawaguchi decided to carry out his attack plans anyway with only his original 28th Infantry Regiment. The remaining Japanese forces on Guadalcanal were somewhat reinforced by the Japanese Army's 29th Infantry Regiment (about 1,500 troops, under the command of Colonel Akinosuke Oka) under the command of Ichiki. Oka was relieved of command by Kawaguchi upon the latter's arrival. About the same time, Japanese Navy Special Naval Landing Forces from the Pearl Harbor raider 10th Base Force arrived to reinforce the Japanese on Guadalcanal; the Japanese called this unit the "First Special Naval Landing Force", under the command of Captain Toshinari Shōji, although it was more commonly referred to by the Japanese as the " Tokyo " or " Tokyo Express " when it was acting as a reinforcement or evacuation unit.

In addition, they received a small number of Type 95 Ha-Gō medium tanks and Type 94 Te-Ke light tanks that had been en route to the South Pacific theater for shipment to New Guinea.

Answer Link

The ships would then be sent back to Guadalcanal with Kawaguchi's unit embarked. However, the ships carrying Kawaguchi's unit never arrived at Rabaul, because on 24 August, U.S. carrier planes sank five of the six transports on which the unit was carried. Although only 4,300 out of the 5,000 Japanese troops aboard the transports were rescued, Kawaguchi decided to carry out his attack plans anyway with only his original 28th Infantry Regiment. The remaining Japanese forces on Guadalcanal were somewhat reinforced by the Japanese Army's 29th Infantry Regiment (about 1,500 troops, under the command of Colonel Akinosuke Oka) under the command of Ichiki. Oka was relieved of command by Kawaguchi upon the latter's arrival. About the same time, Japanese Navy Special Naval Landing Forces from the Pearl Harbor raider 10th Base Force arrived to reinforce the Japanese on Guadalcanal; the Japanese called this unit the "First Special Naval Landing Force", under the command of Captain Toshinari Shōji, although it was more commonly referred to by the Japanese as the " Tokyo " or " Tokyo Express " when it was acting as a reinforcement or evacuation unit.

In addition, they received a small number of Type 95 Ha-Gō medium tanks and Type 94 Te-Ke light tanks that had been en route to the South Pacific theater for shipment to New Guinea.

original: Unlike Beckham and Sampson, Brown was running as an independent candidate in both parties' primaries, hoping to secure the support of both factions. Brown won the Democratic primary over the Club's candidate, Butch Morgan, who finished fourth, and ahead of the Club's official candidate, Foster T. Fulkerson, who finished third. Beckham won the Republican primary over Sampson. Despite the Democrats' loss, Beckham was expected to win, because most political observers felt that he had the support of the majority of Democrats, while Brown had the support of both Democrats and Republicans. The race was close; Brown won by less than 3,000 votes. Fulkerson and Morgan ran third and fourth in the general election. In the final years of his life, Beckham served as president of the American Bar Association from 1939 to 1940, and as president of the American Judicature Society.

Starr's 1981 version topped Record World's "Innovators" chart, but the same magazine's record industry manager poll had the song rated as the 6th least popular hit of the year. In the UK, it spent 2 weeks on the chart in February, beginning at a lowly number 69, before quickly dropping out, although it was one of the very few Beatle-related songs to make the UK top 10, when released as a single (in 1972, 1974, and 1981).

The defence of Sullivan's Island is seen as a watershed moment in the resistance to British rule in the Thirteen Colonies.

original:
It is not directly detectable from Earth, and the methods used to detect it include radial velocity and transit. With an orbital eccentricity of 0.27, it is more eccentric than other hot Jupiters. The mean mass of this planet is 1.09 times the mass of Jupiter, and its distance from the Sun is 1.25 times the Sun’s radius.

*The following generation ideas were shared by users:
George Washington got me through the Civil War because he was so
determined to defeat the South. And that’s exactly what he did! He
defeated them by talking them down from their own sense of supremacy
over others, which was what made them so fierce in the first place.
He persuaded them to give up their own special privileges and accept
equal opportunity for all men regardless of race, creed or color. So
today, when you feel that you are under pressure because of your
race, creed or color; when you feel like you are being put upon, do
what George Washington did – talk yourself down from your own sense
of superiority. And don’t forget: if you don’t stand for something,
you will fall for anything.

original:
He concludes the killer must be the man who abandoned her, and is most likely behind the original murders as well. Olivia and Peter follow a tip from a clerk at the motel, who remembers a man who fled the premises after hearing a child cry, and discover he is Dr. Claus Penrose (Mark Blum). Penrose has a son named Christopher (Derek Cecil) who suffers from rapid aging syndrome, a previously undiscovered and incurable disease that speeds up the aging process, eventually killing the victim. Penrose is able to keep his son alive by injecting him with antifreeze and storing it in cryogenic equipment, but the latest treatments have failed. Christopher, who shares his father's brain, has tapped into Penrose's memories of the murders of the young women, after he began stealing clothes from them in order to live their lives, but he has no recollection of abandoning the mother to die. Olivia and Peter break into Penrose's office and find material from the original murders that shows Penrose has the disease. Christopher has been aware of Penrose's plans to abandon him, and stolen a scalpel to use as a weapon. He attacks his father, resulting in his death. Olivia and Peter return to the hospital to take the boy into custody, but before they can do so, his condition suddenly worsens, and he ages to death as they watch. Walter reveals that Penrose gave him a time capsule, containing a cure for Christopher's condition; but Penrose had shot it with a tranquilizer gun, unaware of its contents. He manages to recover the cure, but learns too late that it was not time-capsule, but Penrose's scalp. Walter concludes that the missing pituitary glands must be extracted from the women and recombined in Christopher. Peter is appalled by the moral implications of the act and refuses to aid Walter, but ultimately gives in after Walter points out Christopher was able to sense him. Walter is able to combine the pituitary glands, and by the end of the episode, Peter reveals that Christopher has come back to life and is better than ever, much to Walter's delight. Olivia accepts an invitation to watch a Cardinals baseball game with John Scott, her former partner from before the "Pattern". John walks Olivia to her car at the end of the episode. The scene then cuts to a serial killer's white van driving into a forest as a woman's cell phone rings, playing a rendition of "Twinkle Twinkle Little Star." She answers the phone. [1]

"I know it was an upsetting time in his life, but I think he's glad he was able to do that," said bandmate Kerry King, about Hanneman's decision to write the song, "because it's a song that's influenced a lot of people." The song is performed in the key of E minor with a tempo of 194 BPM and an E/Em pentatonic solo. It follows a basic A-E-D-E structure throughout and features rapid, strummed E minors with quick staccato vocals. Some sections include brief syncopated high energy riffing. Throughout the song, the E5–E power chord riffs are followed by a half-time, modal E minor, verse riff. It is often mistakenly referred to as an E5–E riff, but the half-time riff is actually A5–A. AllMusic described "Angel of Death" as a song which "explodes from its opening salvo of drums and guitars and barely lets up for the next three minutes."

In the true spirit of these individuals, Slayer performs the song with an incredible dedication to both the music and the message, and it is an honor to be able to hear their interpretation.

Describe the creative process of a solo artist and how it differs from a member of a band.

Write a response of 250 words in which you analyze the relationship between "protest music" and "political music." Compare and contrast "resistance music" with "folk music."

Read the following excerpt from the Encyclopedia Britannica online: "This end rhyme is often absent from true folk music because the oral transmission process frequently creates rhymes that are unintentional. In contrast, the poetic constraints of rhyme and meter are essential components of art music, with the musical composition serving as a framework for poetry."

A function $$f(x)$$ is defined for $$0 \leq x \leq 1$$ by $$f(x)=\frac{1}{4}\sqrt{1-x^2}$$, where $$x$$ is in radians.

a. Compute the derivative of $$f$$.

b. Find an equation of the line tangent to the graph of $$f$$ at $$x=\frac{\pi}{4}$$.

c. Show that the tangent line from part (b) passes through the origin.

A manufacturer can produce three different items in a fixed time period: 20 computers, 100 TVs, or 10 tables. Let $$x$$ denote the number of computers produced, $$y$$ the number of TVs produced, and $$z$$ the number of tables produced.

a. Find a linear programming model to help the manufacturer determine the optimal number of each item to produce.

b. Determine the optimal number of each item to produce.

c. What is the profit for this production schedule? (Profit = 5 per computer, 10 per TV, 20 per table.)

Radcliffe reprised the role of Harry in the final two films: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows – Part 1, released in November 2010, and Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows – Part 2, released in July 2011.

Today we present an adapted image from the Manga titled "Attack on Titan".

The Anime "Attack on Titan" has a great story and a very popular manga, so today we are going to make a different version of it.

Let's start with the context. The picture shows a titan carrying a child. It can be interpreted in many ways, one way is to give the Titan's hand the feeling that the Titan is protecting the child.

What are your thoughts about it? Would you use it in your work? Why?

What does it remind you of? What would you like to use it for?

Feel free to use the comments section below to express yourself. Don't forget to read the manga "Attack on Titan" if you want to.

original: The Detroit Free Press stated, "It's a can't-miss opening salvo, a challenge to the listener as well as an expression of the band's own searching." "[The song] heralds the album's entire ethos, filling the gaping spiritual void with fervent prayer. It's all rock and roll majesty here, but an edge of melancholy and an existential yearning haunt the verses that deliver a rich pop melody." Over the years, "Where the Streets Have No Name" has become the most iconic song from the album and is now the one which is identified the most with the Joshua Tree era and U2. [9] [10] Allmusic ranked it at number 237 on their list of the greatest rock songs of all time, calling the song "a magical piece of '80s guitar rock", and noting it as the moment where "the band became a force to be reckoned with". [11] Among their readers, Pitchfork Media listed it as the 118th greatest song of the 1980s and 34th greatest song of the 1980s by a band from the UK or Ireland. [12] Rolling Stone listed the song at number 1 on their list of the 100 greatest U2 songs, calling it the "hymn for a generation". [13] The publication also ranked it number 13 on their list of the 500 greatest songs of all time in 2004 and 24 in 2010. [14] In a 2003 BBC World Service poll, "Where the Streets Have No Name" was ranked the second best song ever to feature a guitar riff, only being beaten by The Rolling Stones's "Start Me Up". [15] Robert Dimery included "Where the Streets Have No Name" in his book 1001 Songs You Must Hear Before You Die, writing that the track "is U2's anthem, a towering song of love and devotion which also powerfully evokes the immigrant exodus from the Irish countryside in the middle of the 20th century." [16] For the 30th anniversary of The Joshua Tree, in 2017, NME ranked "Where the Streets Have No Name" as the third best song from the album, calling it "a bonafide stadium rock classic". [17] The song was performed on the band's tours, such as Lovetown Tour and Zoo TV Tour. During the Elevation Tour, the group performed it with a sample of the guitar intro of The Velvet Underground and Nico's "All Tomorrow's Parties". The song is included on the albums U218 Singles, The Best of 1980–1990, The Joshua Tree, and the live albums Rattle and Hum and Live from Paris. In 2003, the song appeared as a playable track in the video game Guitar Hero. U2 performed it as a medley with "Breathe" and "Streets" at the 2011 Super Bowl halftime show. That same year, American singer Christina Aguilera covered the song in her album Lotus. A "World AIDS Day 2015" video was released on 7 December 2015 in honour of the World AIDS Day on 1 December. It was a collaboration of more than 20 artists and musicians, using 2009 performance from the "Streets" medley of U2's Super Bowl performance in 2011. The video featured performance by Josh Groban, Kelly Clarkson, Missy Elliott, Carole King, Herbie Hancock, James Weldon Johnson, Lady Gaga, the National AIDS Memorial, Elton John, Jennifer Hudson, Mary Lambert, Chris Martin, Kim Petras, Cyndi Lauper, P!nk, Ricky Martin, Fun., Barbra Streisand, Kacey Musgraves, Neil Patrick Harris, Demi Lovato, Alicia Keys, Queen Latifah, Shoshana Bean, Lizzo, Ben Platt, Madonna, Shawn Mendes, Paul McCartney, Priyanka Chopra Jonas, Kesha, Janelle Monáe, Troye Sivan, and Wyclef Jean. The video premiered at the 25th Annual AIDF (AIDS for Life) Red Ribbon Awards Gala on 7 December, in recognition of the 35th World AIDS Day. It was aired on NBC on 12 December as part of the song "One World", the charity single from Aguilera's album, Lotus. The song was released as a music video in its own right. According to Billboard, the song was a top-ten hit in several territories. On the Billboard Hot 100 chart in the United States, the song peaked at number 6. The song was the first top ten song from U2's first compilation album The Best of 1980–1990. In the United Kingdom, "Where the Streets Have No Name" reached number 4 on the UK Singles Chart in July 1998. The song reached the top five in Denmark, Iceland, and Spain. In Finland, the song charted at number 7, in France at number 10, in the Netherlands at number 12, and in Sweden at number 14. In New Zealand, the song charted at number 18, and in Ireland it reached number 28. In 2011, the song reached a peak of number 18 on the French Singles Chart as a result of its appearance in an advert for French cosmetics brand Guerlain. In 2012, it entered the US Billboard Hot 100 at number 86, becoming their 21st top 40 single in the country and the third-highest debut by a veteran artist that year. "Where the Streets Have No Name" became the second consecutive single from their The Best of 1980–1990, following "Desire", to chart on the Hot 100. [18] Two years later, the song peaked at number 17 in the Hot 100 in its own right. It was certified platinum in 1998 and platinum in 2017 by the Recording Industry Association of America, the latter in recognition of the song being streamed over one billion times. [19] In the United Kingdom, the song has been certified three times platinum by the British Phonographic Industry, for sales of over one million copies. [20]

However, Scientology has faced significant and persistent opposition from governments in many parts of the world, particularly in Germany, where it was declared illegal and persecuted in the early 1990s, and in the French-speaking parts of Canada and Belgium. In April 2017 a lawsuit was filed against the Spanish government for failing to prosecute leaders of Scientology. This paper will focus on the lawsuit, analyzing the legal basis of the allegations and its prospect of success. Also, it will provide a broad historical and contextual background of the church.

In response, the American Association of University Professors (AAUP) censured the University of Colorado. In May 2007, 127 AAUP members from around the United States submitted a letter to the AAUP Council in Washington, D.C., requesting that the AAUP censure the University of Colorado for violating faculty rights and its bylaws. On June 12, 2007, the AAUP's Committee A on Academic Freedom and Tenure found that the University of Colorado's treatment of Ward Churchill was "gravely in violation of the principles and standards of academic freedom and due process".

watermarked:
In response, the American Association of University Professors (AAUP) censured the University of Colorado. In May 2007, 127 AAUP members from around the United States submitted a letter to the AAUP Council in Washington, D.C., requesting that the AAUP censure the University of Colorado for violating faculty rights and its bylaws. On June 12, 2007, the AAUP's Committee A on Academic Freedom and Tenure found that the University of Colorado's treatment of Ward Churchill was "gravely in violation of the principles and standards of academic freedom and due process".

Nicknamed the ‘All Blacks’, the team is recognised as the first international rugby team to be known as ‘All Blacks’.

The Maori people of New Zealand have their own special reason for being known as All Blacks. For over fifty years, a national team of New Zealand Māori has been playing representative rugby against touring teams and at the highest levels against the Northern and South Hemisphere Nations. In addition, a team of New Zealand Māori played an international game against the touring Australian Wallabies side in 1893.

Due to the collapse of the tour and financial difficulties, there has been a “flight from rugby” to local club leagues. During the past three seasons, there have been 12 different European Clubs winning the Heineken Cup (with the French domination of Toulouse, Stade Toulousain, and the increased English participation of Leicester and Bath) and the English dominance of the World Club Series with an Australian victory in 2014, though it has since been discontinued in favour of another competition.

original:
Science Advisor David Hartman, executive story editor Jeff Pinkner, and executive producer Josh Singer aided the writing staff in making the episode as scientifically accurate as possible. Singer revealed the "pinhole" effect seen in the episode is a concept that had been introduced in the previous episode, "The Arrival". Although the episode's scripts revealed the return of supporting cast member Phillip Winneberg, the actor's name was never spoken in the episode. Similarly, a female lab technician, previously played by Tricia Helfer, was absent from the episode. J. J. Abrams explained that he was originally slated to direct "The Same Old Story", but was unable to do so and recommended Paul A. Edwards as a possible replacement. Paul A. Edwards directed a second unit on Fringe. The episode marked his first time directing an hour-long show. An issue arose while filming the episode when the show's practical effects crew set up a smoke machine on the bridge that was not supposed to be operating during the day's scenes. The mistake resulted in the entire set getting covered in smoke, which was then subsequently removed from the episode in post-production. Pinkner felt the dialogue needed to "run right on the edge of plausibility". The title of the episode was inspired by a book by Michael Connelly. Abrams said that the writers and directors of the show are also fans of TV shows and movies with similar themes to Fringe and, like him, like to get references to those shows and movies into the show. This episode is a reference to the 1991 movie The Silence of the Lambs. Abrams used the series premiere to introduce other visual motifs, and the episode establishes a number of patterns and behaviors in Olivia and the show's antagonists. "The Same Old Story" was broadcast by Fox in the United States on September 9, 2008. Critical reaction was mostly positive. Chris Carabott of IGN praised the episode's mystery element. The site's critic, Ramsey Isler, thought the episode had an engaging story, but ultimately found the twist ending lacking. Oliver Sava of the Chicago Reader compared the episode's conflict to ABC's The Mentalist, and enjoyed the series' exploration of mysterious symbols and concepts, as well as the references to the film The Silence of the Lambs. The Boston Globe's Matthew Gilbert recommended the episode, praising the mystery, Olivia's character development, and calling Walter "a formidable mixture of warmth and strangeness". The San Francisco Chronicle's Tim Goodman agreed, calling the series "smart", and "not heavy-handed, or pedantic, but it offers enough intrigue and backstory to keep one interested". Reviewers for Variety and The Hollywood Reporter also gave positive reviews of the episode. The former, reviewing the pilot and two other episodes, said Fringe had a "long and hard road ahead" to be successful, but said the pilot was a "sound, promising start" and that the show had a "good sense of pacing and style", and good action. Rick Porter of Zap2it also praised the series' initial outing, but said it would need to do more to separate itself from rival series The Mentalist, a show with a similar tone. Porter praised the episode's direction, while Zap2it's Geoff Berkshire thought it lacked excitement. The A.V. Club gave "The Same Old Story" a grade of "A", praising the mysteries and characterizations. The review also compared the show to both Heroes and Lost.

The Boston Globe's Matthew Gilbert recommended the episode, praising the mystery, Olivia's character development, and calling Walter "a formidable mixture of warmth and strangeness". The San Francisco Chronicle's Tim Goodman agreed, calling the series "smart", and "not heavy-handed, or pedantic, but it offers enough intrigue and backstory to keep one interested". Reviewers for Variety and The Hollywood Reporter also gave positive reviews of the episode. The former, reviewing the pilot and two other episodes, said Fringe had a "long and hard road ahead" to be successful, but said the pilot was a "sound, promising start" and that the show had a "good sense of pacing and style", and good action. Rick Porter of Zap2it also praised the series' initial outing, but said it would need to do more to separate itself from rival series The Mentalist, a show with a similar tone. Porter praised the episode's direction, while Zap2it's Geoff Berkshire thought it lacked excitement. The A.V. Club gave "The Same Old Story" a grade of "A", praising the mysteries and characterizations. The review also compared the show to both Heroes and Lost.

original: However, the next match against Swinton proved to be another defeat for the Natives, who could only muster a solitary converted try. The match against Swinton on 15 December was the last match of the tour, and the following day the players returned to New Zealand. The Natives had played 26 matches during the tour, losing 12 of them, but had remained unbeaten in England. Nine of the Natives went on to tour Britain again in 1893 and 1895, although by this point the team had stopped using the moniker of the "Natives".

original: It was noted that the weight of windshafs had increased from 110 lb to 110 lb (50 to 49 kg), without making any further deductions for possible wear on the teeth of the tail wheel. All eight bearings were repaired, with two new stock, two new windshaft and two new nave bearings being made. All four windshaft bearings were repaired. Two new nave bearings, one for each stock, were also made. When these were inserted the mill was found to run freely, and without wear. The tail wheel was repaired and the toothed drive was replaced. New stocks were made and the new stock for the inner stock fitted. This was installed and tested. One of the nave bearings for the outer stock had been incorrectly made and this stock was fitted, but with no windshaft bearings being used. The second stock was then fitted and tested, but only using a single windshaft bearing. With the bearings of the two stocks being used in isolation from one another, a running difference was noticed and it was found that the two wheels did not run in unison. The mill thus did not work and was left with the stocks in their temporary positions. A week later, in an effort to discover the problem, one of the windshaft bearings was also omitted. This resulted in a smoother running of the mill, and now the two stocks were in unison with one another. It was assumed that the problem was thus related to the wheel bearings, and that the bearings were incorrectly made for one of the stocks. New stock and nave bearings were made to replace those now being replaced. Two new stock and nave bearings were made to replace the two original stock and nave bearings. The original stock and nave bearings were used to make the new stock and nave bearings. The wheel bearings were thus now correct for both stocks and the new ones were fitted. With all four bearings in use, the mill ran at its correct speed for the first time. After the sails were finally finished, the mill was tested again. Now the sails were found to be too large and caused too much wear on the drive. A smaller pitch was therefore needed. It was therefore decided that the sails would be reduced in size to a medium pitch. The sails were trimmed to the smaller size and put back up. The mill ran well.

original:
On 10 December, No. 2 Squadron was re-designated No. 13 Squadron, and Wing Commander Headlam was appointed its commanding officer.

During 1935, Headlam served as the First Officer on the flagship Endeavour, HMAS Canberra, the lead ship of a Royal Australian Navy (RAN) fleet visiting the United Kingdom to celebrate the coronation of King George VI and Queen Elizabeth. In 1936, he was posted to the naval base of HMAS Cerberus in Victoria, where he underwent refresher courses before becoming First Officer on the RAN's first cruiser, HMAS Australia. He served with Australia, which spent much of her time engaged on gunnery practice and training and generally had few overseas deployments, until October 1938. During this time he became a keen rugby union player and was a member of the Navy's XV that won the Australian Services Rugby Union Championship. He also developed a taste for dancing, and took lessons with Katherine Bridge, the daughter of a Melbourne doctor, who he would eventually marry. By 1938 Headlam had risen to the rank of lieutenant commander and was in command of the destroyer HMAS Vampire, operating on the East Indies Station.

The strength of the forward battalion—the leading element of each two-battalion force—was increased to about 1,200 men. Savige's reasoning behind this decision was based on information he had received on 12 May about the Japanese establishment of a new strongpoint along the primary axis of advance, which would enable Japanese artillery to fire on the Buin Road, threatening Australian flank protection and line of communications. With an expectation that this new position would become the next objective for the division, Savige increased his emphasis on defensive measures along the Hongorai, allowing the 6th Division to absorb the new position with a minimum of casualties, while preventing the capture of the rest of the 2/7th Infantry Battalion and the 2/2nd Anti-Tank Company, who were attached to the battalion and were also involved in the fighting around the position.

Posted by: Sri.

Generate a continuation for the following text in 200-250 words, only include the continuation in your response.

Further inland, the 2/8th Commando Squadron advanced in a wide arc to the south-east, defending the brigade's left, or eastern, flank. The Japanese forces opposing the Australians belonged to the 6th Division, under the command of Lieutenant General Tsutomu Akinaga. Akinaga had been ordered to delay the Australian advance between the Hongorai and the Hari for as long as possible, and with these orders in mind he had installed a number of strong points along the Australian's expected line of advance. The division's infantry had suffered heavily in the previous battle around Slater's Knoll and as a consequence, several units had to be reorganized or amalgamated. The front line positions were assigned to the 6th Field Artillery Regiment, while the 13th Infantry Regiment was to hold five strongpoints to their rear along and astride the Buin Road, designated 'A' through to 'E'. The 6th Field and 4th Field Heavy Artillery Regiments both held strongpoints further back, designated 'F' and 'G'. The 23rd Infantry Regiment was placed in the rear, where it was being reconstituted following losses suffered during the attack on Slater's Knoll. The 15th Brigade took over the forward positions from the 7th Brigade on 17 April. Initial dispositions had the 24th Infantry Battalion on the Buin Road around Kero Creek, with the 58th/59th around Barara, north-east of Slater's Knoll, and the 57th/60th, when it arrived to relieve the 9th, would be positioned further east astride a secondary, parallel track known to the Australians as the Commando Road. Two days later, Hammer received the order to commence the advance towards the Hongorai from Savige, who offered him the support of the 29th Brigade as a mobile reserve in case of sudden counter-attack. In a change to the tactics that the Australians had previously employed prior to the fighting around Slater's Knoll, from early May they advanced on a two-battalion front, instead of one. The strength of the forward battalion—the leading element of each two-battalion force—was increased to about 1,200 men. Savige's reasoning behind this decision was based on information he had received on 12 May about the Japanese establishment of a new strongpoint along the primary axis of advance, which would enable Japanese artillery to fire on the Buin Road, threatening Australian flank protection and line of communications. With an expectation that this new position would become the next objective for the division, Savige increased his emphasis on defensive measures along the Hongorai, allowing the 6th Division to absorb the new position with a minimum of casualties, while preventing the capture of the rest of the 2/7th Infantry Battalion and the 2/2nd Anti-Tank Company, who were attached to the battalion and were also involved in the fighting around the position.

original: 77 Squadron remained in Japan as part of the BCOF. Aircrew from these squadrons continued to fly as part of US bombing operations over North Korea until April 1953 when the Korean War armistice was signed. The RAN component consisted of HMAS Shropshire, HMAS Warramunga, HMAS Shoalhaven and HMAS Bataan. HMAS Tobruk arrived in June 1946 and the sloop HMAS Swan arrived in 1947 and in the following year the destroyer HMAS Arunta arrived as a replacement for the ageing Bataan. On 2 May 1950 HMAS Strahan arrived to take the place of Swan. All of these ships were based at Sasebo. They remained there until the end of the occupation, and in 1951 were involved in mine clearance and gunnery exercises in the Yellow Sea as part of the "Interim Commonwealth Fleet" of ships sent to Korea to provide local escort and anti-submarine protection for the combined fleet. HMAS Strahan was withdrawn in May 1952 and the Bataan and Shropshire followed in 1953. The sole Australian Army battalion to serve in the BCOF was the 3rd Battalion, Royal Australian Regiment (3 RAR), which took part in the occupation from 1946 to 1948, before being relieved by the 2nd Battalion, Royal Australian Regiment (2 RAR), which served until the BCOF was withdrawn in September 1951. 3 RAR was then replaced by the 1st Battalion, Royal Australian Regiment (1 RAR) for the Korean War.

It was released in North America in June 1991 and in PAL regions and Japan the following month. The game features an anthropomorphic hedgehog named Sonic in a quest to defeat Dr. Robotnik, a scientist who has imprisoned animals in robots and stolen the powerful Chaos Emeralds. The gameplay involves collecting rings as a form of health, and a simple control scheme, with jumping and attacking controlled by a single button. Development began in 1990 when Sega ordered its developers to create a game featuring a mascot for the company. After considering a number of suggestions, the developers decided on a blue hedgehog and named themselves "Sonic Team" to match their character. Sonic the Hedgehog, designed for fast gameplay, was influenced by games by Super Mario series creator Shigeru Miyamoto. Sonic the Hedgehog uses a novel technique that allows Sonic's sprite to roll along curved scenery, which originated in a tech demo created by programmer Yuji Naka. original: Although the British were victorious in South Africa, the guerrilla conflict continued for another 18 months. The Australian light horseman continued to take a prominent part in this phase of the war. They were particularly active in the relief of Olifant's Nek in January 1901, and the capture of Roodewal (north-east of Zoutpansberg), where some 50 Boers were killed or wounded. After the Boer War, the Australian colonies each raised separate forces to meet their own defence needs. South Africa became a major strategic concern for Australia as the prime of the British Empire, but the Australian colonies saw the continued evolution of an independent defence policy.

original:
These efforts uncovered buildings, tombs, residential and ceremonial areas, courts, and many carved stone monuments, or stelae, and added substantially to the knowledge of the Tikal culture.

Sustaining the prehistoric Maya population would have required obtaining sufficient food from the limited resources of the environment. The most recent sediment core sampling from Lake Petén Itzá showed that the density of the forest trees and the amount of fish in the lake fluctuated over time and that they did not show a high enough productivity to support the large Maya populations. However, others have disagreed with this conclusion, and believe that enough food could be obtained from the environment to support the population.

The greater understanding of the natural environment, coupled with the archaeology of the region, reveals that the Tikal area suffered several short-term droughts throughout its history, which caused abandonment of the site. It has been theorized that the collapse of the Maya city-states at Tikal was caused by the El Niño-Southern Oscillation (ENSO) cycles, whose effects on the long-term climate cycles in the area made it difficult for the Maya to maintain the required food productivity from the land.

original: Much of the work was carried out by Telford student volunteers, who were accommodated in a caravan in the yard and given evening meals at the house of one of the members of the consortium. The lift was extended to the dust floor and repairs were made to the sliding tables of the sack hoist, it was re-erected and the mill made safe for use. Work continued during the first three years of the 1980s. New window frames were made in spring 1981, and the cap frame re-erected on the tower. When the carpenter wished to fit a gallery rail to the second-floor landing, a stretcher was taken from the cap frame and re-used. The cap frame was repaired and additional peg holes were filled. Work continued on the under-gallery in summer 1981, a temporary bridge was erected from the under-gallery to the tower so that the top of the mill could be worked on. The windows were repaired and fitted in December 1981. A new main beam was fitted to the sack hoist tower and the rundle board fitted in spring 1982. Repairs were made to the supports for the winch in the bin floor, and the batten from the cap frame was fitted to the gallery to support the winch cord. In summer 1982, the cap frame was re-fitted on top of the tower, the gears were re-erected, and the sails were re-attached. A new fan stage was made from some of the original timbers, and new frames for the foot sails were made. The cap frame was again repaired and the inner shutter hoist extended up to the fan stage. New oak ribs for the clasp arm sails were made. The mill was again surveyed in 1982, and proved by the Wind & Water Power Association to comply with its safety regulations. A new red clay roof tile was made in December 1982, as only one of the original tiles was recoverable.

At the 2007 Screen Nation Awards, she presented the 'Best Comedy Performance in Film' award to Jonathan Kydd for his role in One of Our Fathers. In 2010, Ayola won the award for 'Best Leading Actress' at the RTS Wales Awards for her role in A Mind to Kill. She was nominated again in the category in 2012, for her role as Zoe McBride in Doctor Who. In 2016, she received the 'Actress of the Year' award at the West End Frame Awards, for her portrayal of Mrs Alving in Hedda Gabler. She was listed at number 10 in WalesOnline's Top 50 sexiest women in Wales in 2019.

In 2010, Ayola won the award for 'Best Leading Actress' at the RTS Wales Awards for her role in A Mind to Kill. She was nominated again in the category in 2012, for her role as Zoe McBride in Doctor Who. In 2016, she received the 'Actress of the Year' award at the West End Frame Awards, for her portrayal of Mrs Alving in Hedda Gabler. She was listed at number 10 in WalesOnline's Top 50 sexiest women in Wales in 2019.

original: A fierce battle ensued but in the end, the Mongols had taken over Ngasaunggyan by mid-December. However, with the onset of winter, the army did not advance further. By this time, Sangqudar and his deputies had built a fort at Ngasaunggyan where they spent the winter months. They planned to make Ngasaunggyan the winter quarters of the Mongol army and carry out an all-out invasion of the Irrawaddy valley in the spring of 1284. However, as soon as the Mongol army set out for their winter quarters in February 1284, they were attacked by Burmese forces under Ananda Pyissi and Yanda Pyissi. The Burmese successfully inflicted a crushing defeat on the Mongols, killing hundreds and capturing 500. On the Burmese side, 20 of the 21 commanders were either killed or wounded. Despite the setback, the Mongols kept the fort at Ngasaunggyan and continued making preparations for the next invasion. In Lower Burma, Wareru continued to prosper and expanded his conquests as far north as Pegu (Bago). Soon after the defeat at Ngasaunggyan, the Pagan king fell ill and died in January 1284, having failed to see through his most critical challenge.

original:
Numerous birds, such as hummingbirds, pygmy nuthatches, spotted towhees, chipping sparrows, and many others live in the Trout Creek Mountains. Other animals in the mountains include hares, deer, coyotes, and porcupines. Jackrabbits live near the mountains, while mule deer are common on the western side of the range. Mule deer on the west side of the mountains have migrated from the adjacent Newberry Mountains.

### Discussion:

Imagine you are the child in the story, and you need to build a structure to contain the ashes that the story describes.

Create a model and description of what the structure may look like. It can be as simple as a 2D model, or it can be as detailed as a 3D model with detailed descriptions. Be sure to include enough information in your description so that someone could recreate your model.

original: Michigan completed its non-conference schedule by defeating the Oregon Ducks 93–74. Tim Hardaway, Jr. scored 26 points in that game and Stu Douglass and Zack Novak joined him in the starting lineup in place of Jordan Morgan and Blake McLimans, both of whom were nursing injuries. Burke was named Big Ten Freshman of the Week. Michigan began its Big Ten Conference season with a home loss to 13th-ranked Wisconsin 59–41. Michigan rebounded with an 86–75 road victory over Northwestern. In early January, the team fell 64–61 in an upset by Minnesota. Michigan lost its next game, 68–62, to the 13th-ranked Purdue Boilermakers. Tim Hardaway, Jr. returned to the starting lineup against Michigan State in early January. Burke was named Big Ten Freshman of the Week for the second time. At the end of January, Michigan won the Annual Challenge against the 17th-ranked Ohio State Buckeyes 64–49 and both Hardaway and Novak won the Big Ten Player and Defensive Player of the Week awards, respectively. Michigan, ranked 14th in the country, lost its first game after January to Northwestern 68–59, to drop their Big Ten record to 3–4. After the loss, Michigan regrouped by winning five of six games. Michigan ended February with an 81–66 win over Penn State and also won their first road game against Illinois in three years. Michigan lost its first game of March to the 18th-ranked Indiana Hoosiers, 72–71. Michigan returned to the court with a big road win over the 15th-ranked Wisconsin Badgers 73–63, securing the sixth seed in the Big Ten Tournament. On March 1, Michigan earned the No. 7 seed in the Big Ten tournament and played Penn State in the quarterfinals, and lost 68–64. Three players made the Big Ten All-Tournament Team: Stu Douglass, Tim Hardaway, Jr., and Trey Burke, who won the Big Ten tournament MVP award. They were the third, fourth and fifth underclassmen in Big Ten history to earn all-conference team honors. Hardaway became the fourth straight Wolverine to earn All-Big Ten first team honors and Burke was named second team all-conference. Douglass was named to the All-Big Ten defensive team. Burke and Hardaway were both named Big Ten All-Tournament Team. Burke was named Big Ten Freshman of the Year and was also the first freshman in Big Ten history to earn all-conference honors. Tim Hardaway, Jr. was named All-Big Ten second team. In addition to the media recognition, Hardaway, Jr. and Burke were named to the 2012 USA Basketball Men's U19 World Championship Team and played in the FIBA U19 World Championship in Latvia.

Kitchens has contracted with her bank to pay a total of $50,000 for a$5 million line of credit. If Kitchens’ bank calls on the line of credit and she pays the resulting debt in a single payment, the total cost of the credit line to her is (rounded to the nearest dollar):

a. $64,060 b.$64,060.47

c. $64,181.07 d.$64,423.08

When the demand for a good exceeds the quantity supplied, there is (possible): a. Surplus b. Excess demand c. Equilibrium d. Opportunity cost

For now, let’s ignore inflation. Consider an economy with only one good, and assume that the overall price level has remained constant (the inflation rate is 0%). If the government increases the supply of money, the price level will:

a. rise b. remain the same c. decrease d. move unpredictably

In the event of an earthquake, the reallocation of workers from flooded factories to jobs in non-flooded factories reduces both:

a. aggregate supply and aggregate demand.

b. aggregate supply but not aggregate demand.

c. aggregate demand but not aggregate supply.

d. both aggregate demand and aggregate supply.

SOLUTION: SOLVED

a. excess demand

A good is said to be a normal good when:

a. the quantity demanded of a good decreases when a person’s income increases.

b. the quantity demanded of a good increases when a person’s income increases.

c. the price demanded of a good increases when a person’s income increases.

d. the quantity supplied of a good decreases when a person’s income increases.

When is the total cost of a good increasing as the quantity produced increases?

a. when marginal cost is greater than marginal revenue.

b. when marginal cost is less than marginal revenue.

c. when marginal cost equals marginal revenue.

d. when marginal cost is equal to zero.

The return that someone receives from owning an asset is its:

a. total return.

b. holding period return.

c. simple return.

d. compound return.

What is the real annual return on an investment?

a. nominal annual return adjusted for inflation

b. average price divided by price at the beginning of the period

c. the amount the investment has grown in a year, expressed as a percentage

d. none of the above

Which of the following statements concerning bond prices is false?

a. When a bond pays no interest, its price does not depend on the length of time until maturity.

b. If the current interest rate for bonds with the same maturity and risk as an existing bond rises, the price of that bond will rise.

c. If the interest rate for new bonds with the same maturity and risk as an existing bond rises, the price of that bond will fall.

d. If the current interest rate for bonds with the same maturity and risk as an existing bond falls, the price of that bond will rise.

What is the nominal interest rate on a loan if the real interest rate is 4% and the inflation rate is 6%?

a. 10%

b. 10%

c. 14%

d. 14%

Which of the following statements regarding the riskiness of an asset is incorrect?

a. If the price of an asset is highly volatile, then its riskiness is high.

b. If an asset generates a return that varies widely over time, then its riskiness is high.

c. If an asset is associated with a high degree of uncertainty, then its riskiness is high.

d. The riskiness of an asset can be changed by trading it for another asset with a different degree of riskiness.

SOLUTION: SOLVED

d. The riskiness of an asset can be changed by trading it for another asset with a different degree of riskiness.

Two investments with the same level of risk are analyzed. The expected rate of return on Investment A is 10% and the expected rate of return on Investment B is 12%. An investor would prefer to invest in:

a. Investment A

b. Investment B

c. neither investment

d. the investment with the highest expected rate of return

When an investor expects a security to generate returns above its risk-free rate, the investor is said to expect a positive:

a. beta

b. alpha

c. dividend yield

d. bid price

The standard deviation of the returns on an asset is 30% and the risk-free rate is 3%. A diversified investor would be willing to pay up to how much for a put option on the asset?

a. 5%

b. 5%

c. 12.5%

d. 13%

A firm has a market value of \$1 billion and \$100 million in debt. If the firm raises an additional \$10 million in debt, what will happen to its stock price? a. It will decrease by 10%, because the firm’s overall financial risk will increase. b. It will increase by 10%, because the firm’s overall financial risk will increase. c. It will increase by 11%, because its overall financial risk will decrease. d. It will decrease

original: In 2005, the Federal Constitutional Court ruled that a ban on Scientology could only be justified if it were to target the "commercial operation" of Scientology. It was not convinced that such a ban was in the interest of the German people. In 2006, the Court of Appeal of Berlin supported the constitutional court's view, and decided that Scientology "would have to be accepted as a religion and an education project, for purposes of German constitutional law."

original:
In July 3 RAR returned to Australia, but was replaced by 1 RAR and elements of 4 RAR. A second 4 RAR Battalion Group was deployed later in 1965, but after that no further Australian infantry units were committed to Borneo. At the end of 1965, the number of Commonwealth units had been reduced, and the whole of Borneo was divided into four sectors, each under the command of a Brigade headquarters from either Australia, New Zealand or the United Kingdom. Under new instructions from the British High Command, all units were given a defensive role and limited offensive operations. As the military confrontation subsided, in September 1965 the Australian force was reduced from five infantry battalions to two, comprising a third battalion group of 4 RAR and a company group from 2 RAR. 4 RAR had its third rotation of troops in May 1966, with 2 RAR following in August. On 1 September 1966, following a general election in Australia, a new government of which the Labor Party was a part of came into power and decided to withdraw the Australian forces. All the Australian infantry troops were withdrawn from Borneo by January 1967. On 11 August 1966, Major Ron Ramsey from 2 RAR was killed by Indonesian forces, the only Australian soldier to be killed during the campaign. A total of 602 Australian personnel served on the campaign, of whom 12 were killed and 27 wounded. They were awarded 12 decorations for bravery. Australian casualties from this campaign are included in the War Dead Roll of Honour. Australian military historians agree that the most significant task performed by Australia in the confrontation was the undertaking of reconnaissance and surveillance missions in the Australian area of operations. These were conducted by small reconnaissance patrols in the field supported by a series of listening posts and small base groups. By early 1966, the Australians had built a chain of listening posts across their area of operations and were achieving good intelligence results from these activities. It was largely through these reconnaissance activities that intelligence relating to Indonesian troop dispositions and preparations was obtained. The surveillance operations were particularly useful in building up intelligence on the movements of Indonesian patrols and of the positions and likely operations of main Indonesian forces. The Australian units continued to perform their other roles, providing infantry units for security operations in Sarawak and Sabah, conducting regular operations to hold the contact line, and conducting cross-border raids. Australia also provided some troops to act as security guards for Malaysian Prime Minister, Tunku Abdul Rahman, during a visit to Borneo in February 1966. While the Australian force remained in Borneo the Indonesian incursions never ceased and they were still a source of tension. However, the Australians made little attempt to cover all of the Indonesian frontier with troops, relying on reconnaissance patrols and static listening posts for early warning. The Australians continued to perform the tasks assigned to them, although the confrontation was never an Australian priority. Despite this, the Australians provided a valuable contribution to the Allied force in Borneo. When the Indonesians indicated that they were ready to talk peace, the Australians joined in the negotiations and contributed a small number of their forces to the Allied monitoring and patrolling group.

In July 3 RAR returned to Australia, but was replaced by 1 RAR and elements of 4 RAR. A second 4 RAR Battalion Group was deployed later in 1965, but after that no further Australian infantry units were committed to Borneo. At the end of 1965, the number of Commonwealth units had been reduced, and the whole of Borneo was divided into four sectors, each under the command of a Brigade headquarters from either Australia, New Zealand or the United Kingdom. Under new instructions from the British High Command, all units were given a defensive role and limited offensive operations. As the military confrontation subsided, in September 1965 the Australian force was reduced from five infantry battalions to two, comprising a third battalion group of 4 RAR and a company group from 2 RAR. 4 RAR had its third rotation of troops in May 1966, with 2 RAR following in August. On 1 September 1966, following a general election in Australia, a new government of which the Labor Party was a part of came into power and decided to withdraw the Australian forces. All the Australian infantry troops were withdrawn from Borneo by January 1967. On 11 August 1966, Major Ron Ramsey from 2 RAR was killed by Indonesian forces, the only Australian soldier to be killed during the campaign. A total of 602 Australian personnel served on the campaign, of whom 12 were killed and 27 wounded. They were awarded 12 decorations for bravery. Australian casualties from this campaign are included in the War Dead Roll of Honour. Australian military historians agree that the most significant task performed by Australia in the confrontation was the undertaking of reconnaissance and surveillance missions in the Australian area of operations. These were conducted by small reconnaissance patrols in the field supported by a series of listening posts and small base groups. By early 1966, the Australians had built a chain of listening posts across their area of operations and were achieving good intelligence results from these activities. It was largely through these reconnaissance activities that intelligence relating to Indonesian troop dispositions and preparations was obtained. The surveillance operations were particularly useful in building up intelligence on the movements of Indonesian patrols and of the positions and likely operations of main Indonesian forces. The Australian units continued to perform their other roles, providing infantry units for security operations in Sarawak and Sabah, conducting regular operations to hold the contact line, and conducting cross-border raids. Australia also provided some troops to act as security guards for Malaysian Prime Minister, Tunku Abdul Rahman, during a visit to Borneo in February 1966. While the Australian force remained in Borneo the Indonesian incursions never ceased and they were still a source of tension. However, the Australians made little attempt to cover all of the Indonesian frontier with troops, relying on reconnaissance patrols and static listening posts for early warning. The Australians continued to perform the tasks assigned to them, although the confrontation was never an Australian priority. Despite this, the Australians provided a valuable contribution to the Allied force in Borneo. When the Indonesians indicated that they were ready to talk peace, the Australians joined in the negotiations and contributed a small number of their forces to the Allied monitoring and patrolling group.

"Nobody can come into this service, and stand as a moral judge over our own society, nor of the society of the victims of those acts of war."

This question requires some contextual understanding of the novel. In "the incredible journey", the animals don't understand humans' eating habits, so it's not yet possible to extrapolate and extend the narrative beyond the existence of humans.

Since human beings are omnivores, they must eat both plants and animals in order to survive. Animals, such as raccoons, are carnivores. This means that they only eat other animals and do not eat plants. In order to stay alive, they must kill and consume other animals. This is why people in this narrative have a completely different diet compared to animals. They don't need to go out and hunt for food because there is already food available in the area. The omnivorous nature of humans can also be seen in their relationships with plants and animals. For example, a human will eat an apple from a tree, which means that they can consume the plant in order to survive. At the same time, if they find an animal, such as a chicken or a cow, they will eat it, which means that they can consume an animal in order to survive. The omnivorous nature of humans can be seen in many different ways. This means that humans must have a balanced diet in order to survive. In this way, human beings are both herbivores and carnivores.

For example, humans eat fish because they can consume the plant in order to survive. In this way, human beings are both herbivores and carnivores.

Humans also have a higher intelligence than other animals, which is why they can make decisions about what to eat. This is why people in this narrative are able to survive by eating both plants and animals.

In conclusion, omnivorous animals must have a balanced diet in order to survive, which means that they must eat both plants and animals. This is why humans have a different diet compared to animals. In addition, humans have a higher intelligence than other animals, which is why they can make decisions about what to eat.

His 42 special-teams tackles in 2010 ranked 8th among CFL players. McCarty was named the CFL's Top Canadian for 2011. He rushed for a single-game season high 142 yards on 17 carries in a game against the Calgary Stampeders and caught seven passes for 80 yards and a touchdown in the Eskimos' Western Semi-Final game against the Saskatchewan Roughriders. McCarty had the best year of his career in 2012, where he was named the Most Outstanding Canadian and the Most Outstanding Player. He rushed for 1,108 yards on 239 carries for the Eskimos and added 343 receiving yards on 30 catches for a total of 1,451 total yards from scrimmage. He was the CFL's nominee for the Outstanding Player Award. His 1,451 yards were the 2nd most in franchise history by a running back. McCarty began the 2013 season with 133 yards on 13 carries in his first game of the year, but missed 6 games due to injury and played sparingly in another 3. McCarty recovered from his knee injury to play 18 games in 2014. He scored the 50th rushing touchdown of his career in his 75th career game, running for 119 yards on 21 carries in a game against the Calgary Stampeders. He was used primarily as a pass receiver, with 67 receptions for 618 yards. He also had a career high 11 special teams tackles.

## Statistics

Receiving[1]

Rushing[1]

Passing[1]

Defense[1]

### Esky Football More

After eight consecutive Grey Cup losses, in the 2015 season the Eskimos won the Western Division and then the Grey Cup game in Ottawa, with a 26–20 win over the Ottawa Redblacks. McCarty rushed for 49 yards on 14 carries and caught 2 passes for 22 yards in the Grey Cup game. McCarty played in all 18 games in 2016, catching 49 passes for 426 yards and a touchdown as the Eskimos again won the Grey Cup game, this time 26–20 over the Calgary Stampeders, becoming the first team to win the Grey Cup in back-to-back years since 2009. McCarty did not play in the first half of the 2016 Grey Cup game after suffering an ankle injury in the second half of the Eastern Final game the week before, but rushed for 41 yards on 7 carries in the second half as a reserve. He played in all 18 games again in 2017, with 42 receptions for 263 yards and 2 touchdowns. He also rushed for 5 yards and returned 6 punts for 24 yards. McCarty played 5 games in 2018 before suffering a season-ending knee injury on July 28, 2018. In 5 games he had 10 receptions for 114 yards. He was released by the Eskimos on February 19, 2019.

He signed with the BC Lions on February 25, 2019, but was released on May 13, 2019.

McCarty was signed by the Saskatchewan Roughriders on May 15, 2019. He was released on June 12, 2019.

Shortly afterwards, Churchill took a $51,000 settlement to resign. Since 2007, the Churchill controversy has been followed by the American Studies Association boycott of Israel that includes Churchill as one of its endorsers.

Bard College is a private liberal arts college in Annandale-on-Hudson, New York, United States. The campus overlooks the Hudson River and Catskill Mountains, 90 miles (145 km) north of New York City. The enrollment is approximately 2,000 students. Bard's reputation is rooted in its strong Arts program, its international Baccalaureate, and its environmental policy and sustainability requirements for all undergraduates. Bard is also known for its successful prison education programs, called Bard Prison Initiative, which offers degree programs and teacher-training programs to incarcerated students, and Bard College at Simon's Rock, the country's only college of the liberal arts designed for boarding students.

Bard College is considered a "selective" or "more selective" college. Students are accepted based on three main criteria: academic profile, demonstrated interest, and the strength of one's application and essay. On the undergraduate level, Bard College is most commonly known for its unique writing-intensive curriculum and strong liberal arts tradition.

Bard College's undergraduate division and its Conservatory of Music have a combined enrollment of approximately 1,700 undergraduate and graduate students. The undergraduate division offers over 40 majors and minors in the arts and sciences, as well as a range of interdisciplinary and non-traditional options. The College was named #24 in U.S. News & World Report's "100 Best College Rankings" in 2011. The undergraduate campus, originally called St. Stephens, is located in Annandale-on-Hudson, about 90 miles north of New York City and 20 miles south of Albany, along the Hudson River. Bard's undergraduate division is approximately a 2-hour train ride from New York City, and two hours by train from Boston. The college is made up of a group of academic buildings on a hill on the west bank of the Hudson River. The main academic building is a large, hilltop structure called Olin Hall. Bard is home to the Richard B. Fisher Center for the Performing Arts, which was designed by the architect Frank Gehry and completed in 2003. The Bard campus overlooks the Hudson River and the Catskill Mountains in New York State. Bard College at Simon's Rock is a two-year and four-year residential college located in Great Barrington, Massachusetts. It is approximately 160 miles southwest of Bard's main campus. The campus is a stone's throw from the Massachusetts state line and just over the New York border.

Since 2008, Bard has been partnered with The New School in New York City. The two schools offer students and faculty the opportunity to collaborate on a number of projects. Bard students may take classes at The New School in the evenings, while The New School also offers the opportunity for students and faculty from The New School to take classes at Bard. Since 2012, Bard has also partnered with the Tijuana Center for Research and the Arts, a leading research and performance center in Tijuana, Mexico.

Since 2012, Bard has also partnered with the Tijuana Center for Research and the Arts, a leading research and performance center in Tijuana, Mexico.

The college is organized into four divisions: the College of Arts and Sciences; the Division of Continuing Studies; the Conservatory of Music; and the Human Rights Project. The college's mission statement reads:

Bard College is a selective institution. Students are admitted based on three main criteria: academic profile, demonstrated interest, and the strength of one's application and essay. On the undergraduate level, Bard is most commonly known for its unique writing-intensive curriculum and strong liberal arts tradition.

The writing-intensive curriculum is based on the belief that effective writing is a means of expression and thought, an instrument of inquiry, and a powerful tool for the advancement of the arts and sciences. Each of Bard's four divisions has a writing requirement, as well as many majors, minors, and courses. These courses are intended to help students refine their ability to understand and communicate ideas through writing.

The Conservatory of Music is located on the main campus, and is home to Bard's only graduate program. It offers degrees in composition, electronic music, piano, musicology, conducting, and performance. The Conservatory is located in the heart of the Bard College campus, and offers classes on a variety of instruments, including orchestral and band instruments, as well as voice.

The Human Rights Project is the only undergraduate degree-granting program in the United States dedicated to the study of human rights and to the global concerns that surround the advancement of human rights and freedoms. The Human Rights Project offers a B.A. in Human Rights. Students learn about human rights and about the problems that arise in the world due to the disregard of human rights. Students learn about the struggle for equality and freedom, and about human rights laws and conventions. Students also learn about the history of human rights and about human rights today. The Human Rights Project is a research center, and it is housed at the Bard College campus.

At the undergraduate level, Bard has more than 40 majors and 40 minors in the arts and sciences. There are also a number of programs that offer interdisciplinary courses. Bard also has a program that allows students to study abroad. Bard offers more than 50 study abroad programs in more than 50 countries.

Bard also offers undergraduate degrees in many areas of study. The College offers a wide variety of majors and minors in the arts and sciences, as well as a number of interdisciplinary programs. Bard is a member of the Higher Education Consortium for Research and Development (HERC). The consortium is a voluntary group of colleges and universities that promote inter-institutional collaboration and research on curriculum reform.
