Although he only rushed for 64 yards, he had the best season of his career, catching 36 passes for 280 yards. On defense, McCarty had four special-teams tackles. In Week 13 against the Stampeders, he scored his first defensive touchdown of his career after returning an intercepted pass for 43 yards. He scored another defensive touchdown in Week 19 on a 45-yard interception return. In the final game of the season against the Argonauts, McCarty set a franchise record for most special-teams tackles in a single game with five. The season ended in a 56–18 loss to the Saskatchewan Roughriders in the Western Semi-Final, McCarty finishing with five special-teams tackles in the defeat.

In 2011, McCarty became a starter at the Canadian position, filling in for departed Brian Robison, and remained in that role for the following two seasons. In Week 3 against the Alouettes, McCarty had 122 all-purpose yards as well as his first receiving touchdown of the season. In Week 9 against the Blue Bombers, McCarty scored the final touchdown of the game on a four-yard run, helping the Eskimos earn a 37–20 win. In Week 11, McCarty was forced to leave the game against the Stampeders early with an injury, and sat out the next game. In 2011, he had a career-high 850 all-purpose yards, as well as four special-teams tackles. He improved his numbers in 2012, rushing for 354 yards and scoring one rushing touchdown, and also catching 18 passes for 181 yards and three touchdowns. He also had 29 special-teams tackles in his third year with the Eskimos, earning him a second team All-Canadian special-teams selection. In the Eastern Final, he had four special-teams tackles in the 52–29 win over the Alouettes. In the 100th Grey Cup, McCarty finished with four special-teams tackles in the 20–16 loss to the Tiger-Cats. He finished the year with 74 special-teams tackles, the most in the league. McCarty was re-signed by the Eskimos to a two-year contract on February 4, 2013. On June 15, 2014, the Edmonton Eskimos placed him on the injured list. On July 24, 2014, he was released.

McCarty signed with the Ottawa Redblacks on July 25, 2014. After spending all season on the practice roster, McCarty was placed on the team's suspended list.

The film was released on VHS in 1998, however, it would not be released on DVD until March 2009, after many requests and urging from fans.

## 3 Answers

Found the solution!

"During the shows in Japan, Carey performed her holiday classic "All I Want for Christmas Is You", alongside various male and female dancers on stage who performed light dance routines alongside Carey. During the song, Carey donned a Santa suit and matching hat, while being carried on a large stage prop by the dancers. The show at Hawaii's 50,000 capacity Aloha Stadium made her one of the few acts in the stadium's history to sell out the entire venue. Aside from its commercial success, fans and critics raved about the show's visuals, as well as Carey's vocal delivery. During the tour, several bits and performances were filmed and later edited into a VHS and DVD entitled Around the World. The VHS featured performances from Tokyo Dome, Aloha Stadium as well as few other skits and scenes that were later compiled into the video. The film first begins with performances in Hawaii, where the song's recitals are cut into halves, excluding the second verses and bridge to shorten the bulk length of the video. Afterwards, Carey's performance of "My All" is shown in inter-cut scenes from Japan and Taipei. After the conclusion of the song, scenes of Carey conversing with Brenda K. Starr are shown, which eventually lead to a tribute to her at a small and intimate New York club, where Carey performs "I Still Believe". Soon after, Carey's performance in Japan with Lorenz for "I'll Be There" is shown, leading to scenes of Carey swimming with dolphins in Australia. The film was released on VHS in 1998, however, it would not be released on DVD until March 2009, after many requests and urging from fans."

Ian Wallace of the London-based Culture24 website observed that "perhaps most interestingly" in "Exit Through the Kwik-E-Mart", Springfield "literally goes hipster for a day" in reference to the popularity of hipsters among street artists. According to television critic Ileane Rudolph of TV Guide, The Simpsons staff "understands the appeal of the phenomenon (at least for young people) and makes fun of it but in a way that doesn’t make you want to sic a mall cop on them." Rudolph observed that in the episode, there is a lot of "hipster lingo" and "references to unsavory projects with silly names" such as Dumb Project, Dumb Art and Dumb Project.

#2

Beckham took control of the executive branch and set up a state militia, preparing to use force to block Taylor's supporters. However, federal troops arrived to keep order. The case, Taylor v. Beckham, eventually reached the United States Supreme Court, which ruled that Beckham had to leave office to allow Taylor to take over. The elections of 1903 saw both Taylor and Beckham reelected, and in 1904, Taylor took office. After the election, Beckham served in the state Senate, and then joined the U.S. Senate in 1914. He was reelected three times and served until 1926.

continuation
A generation later, John C. Wickliffe Beckham was a trailblazer in his own right. He was one of Kentucky's first delegates to the Constitutional Convention of 1891 and one of the state's early public health advocates. His tenure in the state Senate saw him spearhead the fight against the effects of the great influenza pandemic of 1918 and other threats to the public's well-being. During his 12 years in the U.S. Senate, he was active in international affairs, even rising to the post of Majority Whip for a time.

The reader may be confused as to how Beckham managed to remain in the governor's mansion for 6 years, if at all, in the face of court rulings. Did Beckham use the authority of the state militia to intimidate members of the General Assembly? And just how was the congressional fight he was having with Taylor going? How did the candidate whose election the General Assembly disputed manage to remain in office for that length of time? You will fill in the blanks below with the missing information in your response. The first two lines are provided for you.

A generation later, John C. Wickliffe Beckham was a trailblazer in his own right. He was one of Kentucky's first delegates to the Constitutional Convention of 1891 and one of the state's early public health advocates. His tenure in the state Senate saw him spearhead the fight against the effects of the great influenza pandemic of 1918 and other threats to the public's well-being. During his 12 years in the U.S. Senate, he was active in international affairs, even rising to the post of Majority Whip for a time.

Beckham was appointed secretary of state by Taylor as soon as he took office. In the state Senate, Beckham served on the Judiciary Committee, sponsoring bills to improve mental health and sanitation laws. In 1912, he proposed the construction of a new state capitol building to replace the fire-damaged one, which was completed in 1915. He was among the first national leaders to speak out against the "Prussian Practices" of Germany in World War I. In 1914, he was elected to the U.S. Senate and took his seat the following year. A conservative Democrat, he was reelected in 1920, 1926 and 1932, but declined to run again in 1938, resigning effective January 4, 1939. He died two weeks later in Washington, D.C.

A conservative Democrat, he was reelected in 1920, 1926 and 1932, but declined to run again in 1938, resigning effective January 4, 1939. He died two weeks later in Washington, D.C.

Taylor named Beckham his successor, but Beckham declined. Taylor instead appointed Tom C. McDowell, a member of the legislature, and McDowell was inaugurated later in the day. Taylor appointed Beckham to the post of secretary of state, and Beckham pledged to follow Taylor's policies as governor. In the state Senate, Beckham served on the Judiciary Committee, sponsoring bills to improve mental health and sanitation laws. A conservative Democrat, he was reelected in 1920, 1926 and 1932, but declined to run again in 1938, resigning effective January 4, 1939. He died two weeks later in Washington, D.C.

It is interesting to note the conservative positions Beckham took on issues. He fought efforts to reduce the voting age to 18, proposed making Sunday a day of rest, and supported prohibition. As a Christian Scientist he once tried to get the U.S. Congress to declare Wednesday as an official national prayer day.

A conservative Democrat, he was reelected in 1920, 1926 and 1932, but declined to run again in 1938, resigning effective January 4, 1939. He died two weeks later in Washington, D.C.

Beckham's tenure in the U.S. Senate saw him advocate public ownership of power, hydroelectric projects and toll roads. As president of the American Liberty League, he took the lead in opposing the repeal of prohibition, an act of which he strongly disapproved. Beckham tried to become Kentucky's lieutenant governor in 1919 but was defeated in the Democratic primary. In 1926, he led a movement for the U.S. to become a member of the League of Nations, and later supported the administration of Franklin D. Roosevelt.

original: A significant proportion of the troops were of Muslim origin. They were accompanied by quite a few Chinese as well. These Chinese and foreign soldiers clearly outnumbered the native peoples of the region. These foreign soldiers fought bravely for the Mongols, as will be shown by the following three stories, taken from the Yuan Shi, the Official History of the Mongols.The first story describes the defense of Yingjiang against a Burmese attack. The Burmese forces came in three armies, the first two being the vanguard. They had been fighting for some days without achieving much, so the Mongols in the city sent a senior Chinese general, Mu Chengshun, to attack the last of the three armies. Chengshun saw that it was a bad idea to confront the enemies by himself, so he recruited some Han Chinese (ex-Song) soldiers who had surrendered, and then selected some reliable Mongol guards. He put them in a forward position to fight the enemy while he went to the rear to help train the local levies. They went through the plan twice. He was just finishing the training, and the food had not arrived, when he heard that the enemy was already pressing on the rear. He ordered the cavalry to attack, while he went to the front of the men he had recruited. He wanted to stop the fighting so that he could reorganize the men. But by the time he arrived, most of the troops were dead, and the survivors could not stand the pressure. Seeing this, he forgot all about saving the town and went to help the soldiers who were still holding their position. He took command of the center position, sending some soldiers to reinforce the right and left flanks, while he himself continued to command the center. The flanks could not withstand the enemy's onslaught. Some of the soldiers who had escaped from the center joined the flanks and fortified their position. Mu Chengshun himself fought with them, until he saw that they were about to lose their position. In this way, the defenders lost their center and both flanks. When they retreated to the gate of the city, Chengshun put some officers in charge of holding the gate. Then he ordered some soldiers to organize into four ranks, and then organized them again to charge at the enemy. Seeing that this maneuver was out of the ordinary, the enemies held back. Chengshun led his soldiers to defeat them. The battle ended. He took the position that had been lost, took some prisoners, and sent the news back to the city. The governor of the city was not at all pleased with him. Mu Chengshun asked him, "I don't know whether I should be killed or not." He immediately beheaded the soldiers who had deserted their position, and then beheaded the deserters himself. He burnt the bodies and fed them to dogs. The Burmese army also beat a retreat.The second story describes the battle of the Han and Li Rivers. After the border war ended, the Burmese and Mongol armies both withdrew. But both sides were full of distrust. Burmese agents sent by Pagan and Xiancheng to attack some Mongol soldiers at Puping (in modern Luxi County, Yunnan), and fought the Mongols at Longtian (modern Ruili, Yunnan), where they had also stationed some troops. Thus, the Mongols saw the need to strengthen the garrison. The plan was to build a garrison at the entrance to the Burmese territory at the junction of the Han and Li Rivers, so that the enemies would have to pass through a narrow pass. Also, the area of the Han and Li Rivers would be the most effective in deterring attacks against the capital, Puping. To gain confidence of the local chiefs, the Mongols selected men from among the local residents as leaders. At first, they came with their families. But soon the Burmese army came and attacked the Mongol troops. Since they had heard of the Burmese army's military power, the Mongol leaders became panicked and started to slip away from the battle field. The soldiers also saw their leaders slipping away and became worried. After seeing this, a local chief from Longtian came and begged the soldiers to listen to him. Then he said, "A hero does not run away from the battle field. Even if he dies, he can become an immortal." He went back to Longtian and gathered together the people of Longtian. He also recruited some Han Chinese and other foreign soldiers who were in the region. He asked them to wait until the Burmese attacked. They did not allow the Burmese to enter the town, but instead, all came to fight the Burmese at the entrance to the town. They broke through the ranks of the enemies, and saw that there were only about a thousand of them, and their leader was sitting on a deer. The chief of Longtian called them "the enemies of the Mongols". He ordered his men to surround the enemy. As a result, the Burmese leader died. The chief of Longtian then asked the Han Chinese soldiers to form four lines, and directed his own men to be the front line. Then he ordered them to advance, and the enemies retreated. The soldiers kept after them, but the enemies went up the Li River, and then turned to the Han River. The Mongols caught up with them at the Han River. They put all the soldiers in two lines, one at the river and one above the river, and did not allow the Burmese to pass through. The Burmese finally ran away. The Burmese king immediately reported to the Song that the Mongols had conscripted native residents to defend the region, and asked the Song government to fight back against the conscripted soldiers. The Song court did not know the details of the military situation, so it did not take any action. When the king of Pagan found out, he immediately came with another army to attack the border area. His army met the Mongols, and they fought one another until the Burmese army retreated. The governor of the border region asked the court to reinforce the army, so the military commissioner of Yunnan sent some generals to the border area. At that time, the Mongol governors in the region of the Han and Li Rivers came to join forces with each other. They attacked the enemies again and killed the leading generals of the Burmese army. They even killed some of the local chiefs of the enemies. They also killed many of the enemies in battle. Seeing this, the king of Pagan had to retreat.The third story describes the battle of a village called Jiangnan, and is similar to the first story. These Chinese and foreign soldiers clearly outnumbered the native peoples of the region. These foreign soldiers fought bravely for the Mongols, as will be shown by the following three stories, taken from the Yuan Shi, the Official History of the Mongols.The first story describes the defense of Yingjiang against a Burmese attack. The Burmese forces came in three armies, the first two being the vanguard. They had been fighting for some days without achieving much, so the Mongols in the city sent a senior Chinese general, Mu Chengshun, to attack the last of the three armies. Chengshun saw that it was a bad idea to confront the enemies by himself, so he recruited some Han Chinese (ex-Song) soldiers who had surrendered, and then selected some reliable Mongol guards. He put them in a forward position to fight the enemy while he went to the rear to help train the local levies. They went through the plan twice. He was just finishing the training, and the food had not arrived, when he heard that the enemy was already pressing on the rear. He ordered the cavalry to attack, while he went to the front of the men he had recruited. He wanted to stop the fighting so that he could reorganize the men. But by the time he arrived, most of the troops were dead, and the survivors could not stand the pressure. Seeing this, he forgot all about saving the town and went to help the soldiers who were still holding their position. He took command of the center position, sending some soldiers to reinforce the right and left flanks, while he himself continued to command the center. The flanks could not withstand the enemy's onslaught. Some of the soldiers who had escaped from the center joined the flanks and fortified their position. Mu Chengshun himself fought with them, until he saw that they were about to lose their position. In this way, the defenders lost their center and both flanks. When they retreated to the gate of the city, Chengshun put some officers in charge of holding the gate. Then he ordered some soldiers to organize into four ranks, and then organized them again to charge at the enemy. Seeing that this maneuver was out of the ordinary, the enemies held back. Chengshun led his soldiers to defeat them. The battle ended. He took the position that had been lost, took some prisoners, and sent the news back to the city. The governor of the city was not at all pleased with him. Mu Chengshun asked him, "I don't know whether I should be killed or not." He immediately beheaded the soldiers who had deserted their position, and then beheaded the deserters himself. He burnt the bodies and fed them to dogs. The Burmese army also beat a retreat.The second story describes the battle of the Han and Li Rivers. After the border war ended, the Burmese and Mongol armies both withdrew. The plan was to build a garrison at the entrance to the Burmese territory at the junction of the Han and Li Rivers, so that the enemies would have to pass through a narrow pass. Also, the area of the Han and Li Rivers would be the most effective in deterring attacks against the capital, Puping. The ninth person, Mohammed Ali, was not identified in the police reports, but may have been someone from the Muslim community in Portland, Oregon. The first target was David Frohnmayer, but in the end all on the list were spared. The third case involving Oregon Attorney General David Frohnmayer was scheduled to begin on October 17, 1985, when Hagan drove to McMenamin's Brew Pub, and got a clear shot at Frohnmayer, as he was about to enter the pub's banquet hall for a meeting, but her gun jammed. The case was subsequently postponed and rescheduled for December 16. Although these attempted assassinations never occurred, a successful poisoning was carried out. Turner and Green were targeted in the plot as well as Wasco County Planning Director Daniel Durow and Oregon State Representative Mel Pennington. Also implicated in the conspiracy was the Soviet bloc diplomat Pyotr Akopovich Zhivago, who became a naturalized citizen of the United States in 1966. Zhivago had, according to the court records, given them a Browning.22 rifle and later a carbine. Zhivago claimed to have been a British Army Major who helped to defeat Adolf Hitler, and also claimed to have been a Swiss industrialist with ties to IBM. Zhivago admitted to having conspired with Rajneeshees, and to having given them a.22 rifle and.22 carbine. Although the United States Government alleged that Zhivago was a KGB agent, the United States Department of Justice withdrew the charge against Zhivago as part of a plea bargain agreement. Zhivago pleaded guilty to an immigration charge and was deported back to the Soviet Union. Subsequently, Zhivago was awarded the Order of Lenin and promoted to the rank of Major General in the Soviet Army and also given the Stalin Prize. The biography of Zhivago provided by the United States Government was also withdrawn in the plea bargain agreement.

Sheela hoped that by removing Turner's influence they would be able to thwart the federal immigration investigation which could have resulted in deportation of Rajneeshee leaders. Three former leaders of the commune including Ma Anand Sheela, Dianne Yvonne Onang (Ma Anand Puja), a registered nurse from the Philippines who managed the Rajneeshee medical corporation, and former treasurer of Rajneesh Foundation International and Catherine Jane Stork (Ma Shanti Bhadra) of Australia, put together a hit list which included U.S. Attorney Charles Turner and Oregon Attorney General David Frohnmayer. Susan Hagan (Ma Anand Su), a top official in the Rajneeshpuram hierarchy, was also a participant in the assassination conspiracy. Hagan was in charge of the security force at Rajneeshpuram, ran the Rajneesh Investment Corporation, and supervised construction on the commune. Other conspirators in the assassination plot included Ann Phyllis McCarthy (Ma Yoga Vidya), president of the Rajneesh commune, and Alma Potter (Ma Dhyan Yogini), Ma Anand Sheela's bodyguard and traveling companion. Potter was manager of the Hotel Rajneesh in Portland, Oregon, and a member of the commune's security force. Byron (Makima), and Rajneesh's former secretary Laxmi Thakarsi Kuruwa (Ma Yoga Laxmi). original:
He raced motorcycles during high school, with his stepfather, Harry Hyde, his crew chief. He moved from drag racing to stock car racing. He graduated from John Marshall High School in 1967. In the 1960s, Richmond's father moved the family from Ohio to Texas and then to California in the hopes that Tim could learn to drive. Al purchased a two-seater car and drove to the racetrack himself, with Tim in the passenger seat, on the nights of races. After Tim's father fell into bankruptcy, the family moved to Daytona Beach, Florida, where he could drive stock cars and borrow a car to practice. According to his family, by age 12 he was driving the company car, without a license, from Daytona to Daytona Beach for high school, and back. In 1969, he entered his first race, a U.S. Southern Pro Late Model stock car race in Greensboro, North Carolina, on the Saturday before Easter. He entered the race without any prior experience driving a stock car and won by a lap. His stepfather became his crew chief. He practiced daily, occasionally riding in the passenger seat of a race car with Dale Earnhardt as a passenger in the driver's seat.

He won seven races that season, more than any other driver on the tour. When he missed the season-opening Daytona 500 in February 1987, media reported that he had pneumonia. The infection most likely resulted from his compromised immune system, which was weakened by AIDS. Despite the state of his health, Richmond competed in eight races in 1987, winning two events and one pole position before his final race in August of that year. He attempted a comeback in 1988 before NASCAR banned him for testing positive for excessive over-the-counter drugs, ibuprofen and pseudoephedrine; NASCAR later announced they gave Richmond a new test and tested negative. Richmond filed a lawsuit against NASCAR after NASCAR insisted they wanted access to his entire medical record before they would reinstate him. After losing the lawsuit, Richmond withdrew from racing. NASCAR later stated their original test was a "bad test." Richmond grew up in a wealthy family and lived a freewheeling lifestyle, earning him the nickname "Hollywood". In describing Richmond's influence in racing, Charlotte Motor Speedway president Humpy Wheeler said, "We've never had a race driver like Tim in stock car racing. He was almost a James Dean-like character." When Richmond was cast for a bit part in the 1983 movie Stroker Ace, "He fell right in with the group working on the film," said director Hal Needham. Cole Trickle, the main character in the movie Days of Thunder, played by Tom Cruise, was loosely based on Richmond and his interaction with Harry Hyde and Rick Hendrick. Richmond grew up in Ashland, Ohio. His parents, Al and Evelyn (née Warner) Richmond, met in the course of their work. Al was a welder for pipe construction companies and Evelyn was a field office manager. Noticing that highway crews had to dig up the entire highway to lay pipe, Al designed a machine to bore underneath the highway. To market this invention, he founded Richmond Manufacturing, which eventually exported machines worldwide. Tim's driving days started as a toddler when he was given a go-kart that he often drove inside buildings and across his lawn. He raced motorcycles during high school, with his stepfather, Harry Hyde, his crew chief. He moved from drag racing to stock car racing. He graduated from John Marshall High School in 1967. In the 1960s, Richmond's father moved the family from Ohio to Texas and then to California in the hopes that Tim could learn to drive. Al purchased a two-seater car and drove to the racetrack himself, with Tim in the passenger seat, on the nights of races. After Tim's father fell into bankruptcy, the family moved to Daytona Beach, Florida, where he could drive stock cars and borrow a car to practice. According to his family, by age 12 he was driving the company car, without a license, from Daytona to Daytona Beach for high school, and back. In 1969, he entered his first race, a U.S. Southern Pro Late Model stock car race in Greensboro, North Carolina, on the Saturday before Easter. He entered the race without any prior experience driving a stock car and won by a lap. His stepfather became his crew chief. He practiced daily, occasionally riding in the passenger seat of a race car with Dale Earnhardt as a passenger in the driver's seat.

The Chinese described them as sparsely populated and inhabited by wild tribes, among which they included the Burmese. Dali Kingdom c. 1200. Note the southwestern outpost at Mogaung, near today's Mansi border town. The Dali Kingdom, now being called the Mogaung Kingdom (after its southwestern outpost, present-day Mansi), was a residual of the Dali Kingdom of the Song period. Its core territory was now smaller (the Dali region alone). It also held sway over the newly acquired lands in present-day Yunnan, including the Mongol-held territory to the north. The Mongol Emperor of China sent a long letter to the Mogaung ruler in the late 1270s, after the Mongols had secured their occupation of Yunnan. It told him to: "surrender and submit to the Great Khan, change his name and throw off his old customs and adopt new ways, turn Buddhist and abandon Shamanism." Mongol envoy Hashatu and Han Chinese Baisimu visited the Mogaung king at his capital, Lincang. The Mongols quickly realized that the Burmese were able to build a navy of 700 warships to counter the Mongol invasion.

The Pagan Empire disintegrated and anarchy ensued. The Mongols, who probably preferred the situation, did nothing to restore order in the next ten years. In March 1297, they accepted the voluntary submission of King Kyawswa of Pagan although he controlled little beyond the capital city of Pagan (Bagan). But Kyawswa was overthrown nine months later, and the Mongols were forced to intervene, leading to their second invasion in 1300–01. Marco Polo reported the first invasions (1277–87) in his travelogue, Il Milione. The Burmese referred to the invaders as the Taruk (after the central Asian Turkic troops that largely made up the Mongol invasion army); today, the term Taruk () refers to the Han Chinese instead. King Narathihapate is unkindly remembered in Burmese history as Taruk-Pye Min, ("the King who Fled from the Taruk"). In the 13th century, the Pagan Empire, along with the Khmer Empire, was one of the two main empires in mainland Southeast Asia. For much of its history, Pagan's neighbor to the northeast was not China but the independent Dali Kingdom and its predecessor Nanzhao, both with Dali as their capital city. Dali-based kingdoms were a power in their own right, at times allying themselves with the Tibetan Empire to their west and at other times with China's Tang and Song dynasties. Indeed, Nanzhao's mounted armies ventured deep into what is today Burma and may have been behind the founding of the medieval city of Pagan and the Pagan Dynasty itself. Between the newly conquered Mongol territory and Pagan were a wide swath of borderlands stretching from present-day Dehong, Baoshan and Lincang prefectures in Yunnan as well as the Wa and Palaung regions (presumably in present-day northern Shan State), which Pagan and Dali had both claimed and exercised overlapping spheres of influence. Then as now, the borderlands mostly consist of forbidding terrains of high mountain ranges. The Chinese described them as sparsely populated and inhabited by wild tribes, among which they included the Burmese. Dali Kingdom c. 1200. Note the southwestern outpost at Mogaung, near today's Mansi border town. The Dali Kingdom, now being called the Mogaung Kingdom (after its southwestern outpost, present-day Mansi), was a residual of the Dali Kingdom of the Song period. Its core territory was now smaller (the Dali region alone). It also held sway over the newly acquired lands in present-day Yunnan, including the Mongol-held territory to the north. The Mongol Emperor of China sent a long letter to the Mogaung ruler in the late 1270s, after the Mongols had secured their occupation of Yunnan. It told him to: "surrender and submit to the Great Khan, change his name and throw off his old customs and adopt new ways, turn Buddhist and abandon Shamanism." Mongol envoy Hashatu and Han Chinese Baisimu visited the Mogaung king at his capital, Lincang. The Mongols quickly realized that the Burmese were able to build a navy of 700 warships to counter the Mongol invasion.

For much of its history, Pagan's neighbor to the northeast was not China but the independent Dali Kingdom and its predecessor Nanzhao, both with Dali as their capital city. Dali-based kingdoms were a power in their own right, at times allying themselves with the Tibetan Empire to their west and at other times with China's Tang and Song dynasties. Indeed, Nanzhao's mounted armies ventured deep into what is today Burma and may have been behind the founding of the medieval city of Pagan and the Pagan Dynasty itself. Between the newly conquered Mongol territory and Pagan were a wide swath of borderlands stretching from present-day Dehong, Baoshan and Lincang prefectures in Yunnan as well as the Wa and Palaung regions (presumably in present-day northern Shan State), which Pagan and Dali had both claimed and exercised overlapping spheres of influence. Then as now, the borderlands mostly consist of forbidding terrains of high mountain ranges. The Chinese described them as sparsely populated and inhabited by wild tribes, among which they included the Burmese. Dali Kingdom c. 1200. Note the southwestern outpost at Mogaung, near today's Mansi border town. The Dali Kingdom, now being called the Mogaung Kingdom (after its southwestern outpost, present-day Mansi), was a residual of the Dali Kingdom of the Song period. Its core territory was now smaller (the Dali region alone). It also held sway over the newly acquired lands in present-day Yunnan, including the Mongol-held territory to the north. The Mongol Emperor of China sent a long letter to the Mogaung ruler in the late 1270s, after the Mongols had secured their occupation of Yunnan. It told him to: "surrender and submit to the Great Khan, change his name and throw off his old customs and adopt new ways, turn Buddhist and abandon Shamanism." Mongol envoy Hashatu and Han Chinese Baisimu visited the Mogaung king at his capital, Lincang. The Mongols quickly realized that the Burmese were able to build a navy of 700 warships to counter the Mongol invasion.
